place_info.title: 2nd Torii
place_info.address: 3 Chome-1 Kudankita, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 102-0073, Japan

reviews.snippet:
The Second Torii – Bronze Gate of Memory

As I walked deeper into Yasukuni Shrine, the first torii behind me, I came upon the Second Torii, towering and heavy with presence. Unlike the wooden gates often seen in neighborhood shrines, this one is made of bronze, giving it a solidity that feels permanent, almost immovable.

History:

The gate was erected in 1887 (Meiji 20), during the time Japan was reshaping itself into a modern state. It wasn’t just built for beauty—it was financed by veterans and supporters as a tribute to the war dead, making it one of the earliest memorial gestures within the shrine. At the time, it was said to be the largest bronze torii in Japan, standing nearly 12 meters tall and weighing close to 100 tons. Its sheer scale reflected both technological progress and the seriousness of purpose: this wasn’t just a gate, it was a statement of remembrance.

Structure:

From a distance, the torii looks simple, but standing near it you notice its massiveness. The dark bronze has aged into a greenish patina, showing the passage of more than a century. The columns are thick, rising straight from the stone foundation, and the crossbar stretches across with a clean, heavy line. It feels industrial, yet dignified—much less delicate than wood, yet no less spiritual.

Reflections:

Walking beneath it, I felt a shift in atmosphere. The torii frames the long gravel path ahead, narrowing your vision toward the shrine’s main hall. In Shinto tradition, passing through a torii means leaving the ordinary world behind and entering a sacred realm. But here, the experience carries another layer: it’s also a crossing into the space of memory, of national grief and pride, where the weight of history lingers as tangibly as the bronze above.

What struck me most was the paradox it represents. Bronze was chosen for strength and permanence—qualities associated with resilience and endurance. Yet permanence also means the memories of war, sacrifice, and loss remain ever-present, etched into the very material of the gate. The Second Torii is not just an entrance, but a silent reminder that the past, once cast in metal, cannot be ignored.

place_info.title: 大燈籠
place_info.address: Japan, 〒102-0073 Tokyo, Chiyoda City, Kudankita, 3 Chome−1

reviews.snippet:
The Great Lantern at Yasukuni Shrine is not just a stone light fixture—it is a storyteller in bronze and granite. At first it blends with the sacred atmosphere, a towering tōrō that might simply guide worshippers through the shrine’s path. But the closer one looks, the more its true nature emerges. The lantern is wrapped in reliefs, each a vivid scene from Japan’s modern wars, capturing the struggles, triumphs, and human cost of a turbulent era.

Unlike ordinary tōrō in gardens or temple grounds, which embody peace and light, this lantern carries a dual burden. It is both memorial and manifesto. On one side it honors the soldiers who fought and died; on another it conveys the national narrative of resilience, faith, and endurance. It is beautiful, yet sobering—an artwork that refuses neutrality.

Standing before it, I felt the tension between reverence and reality. The artistry of the bronze panels is undeniable—figures move with lifelike energy, ships seem ready to sail off the lantern’s surface, and even scenes of ruin are rendered with haunting grace. Yet beyond the artistry lies a reminder: this lantern was built to shape how war is remembered. It preserves grief, but it also projects glory.

For me, the lantern is less about casting physical light and more about illuminating memory—a reminder of how nations narrate their past, and how the act of remembering can itself be both healing and contested.

Bronze Relief Panels – Symbolism & Historical References

Naval Battle Scene. Likely depicts the Battle of Tsushima (1905), where Admiral Tōgō Heihachirō’s fleet decisively defeated the Russian navy. Symbolizes Japan’s rise as a modern naval power and its pride in victory.

Army Soldiers Advancing. Infantrymen marching forward, rifles in hand, perhaps referencing campaigns in the Sino-Japanese War (1894–95) or Russo-Japanese War (1904–05). Represents courage, discipline, and sacrifice of the common soldier.

Medical Relief and Aid. Depicts nurses, medics, or field hospitals treating the wounded. Offers a softer, humane counterbalance to the violence of war, highlighting sacrifice beyond the battlefield.

Destroyed Torii with Survivors. Shows a shattered torii gate amid ruins, but survivors gathered nearby. Symbolizes endurance of faith and tradition despite destruction; perhaps an allusion to the idea that Japan’s spirit survives war.

Departure for Battle. Families or comrades bidding farewell to soldiers boarding ships or trains. Captures the emotional cost of war, the moment of separation between home and front.

Victory & Return. Celebratory imagery, possibly a triumphant army returning home, banners raised. Represents national pride and the reward of sacrifice.

The Daitōrō is both lantern and monument. Its bronze panels do not merely decorate—they narrate. They immortalize victories, honor sacrifices, and carry unspoken grief. To stand before it is to confront history in layered form: beauty in craft, sorrow in memory, and weight in legacy.

It leaves one with a question: Do we see it as light for the spirits of the fallen, or as a reminder of how war was glorified? Perhaps it is both.

place_info.title: Statue of Ōmura Masujirō
place_info.address: 2 Chome-1 Kudankita, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 102-0073, Japan

reviews.snippet:
Reflection on the Ōmura Masujirō Statue

Standing before the bronze figure of Ōmura Masujirō, I could not help but feel that I was looking at more than just a statue. This monument, cast in 1880, holds the distinction of being Japan’s first Western-style bronze statue. Its very existence speaks of the turbulent but ambitious dawn of the Meiji era, when Japan was determined to step out from centuries of isolation and align itself with the modern powers of the world.

Ōmura’s background makes his story compelling. Born in 1824 as the son of a village doctor in Chōshū, he originally trained in medicine and rangaku (Dutch learning). His early focus was healing, not warfare. Yet, it was this same grounding in Western science that shaped his understanding of military strategy. Through his exposure to Dutch texts on artillery and European warfare, Ōmura grew into a thinker who recognized that Japan could no longer rely on its outdated feudal armies of samurai if it was to survive in the modern age.

This statue, with its calm but firm posture, captures the image of a man who dared to propose something radical for his time: a national army built on universal conscription, where all men, regardless of birth, could serve the state. It was an idea that undermined the centuries-old privilege of the samurai class. While visionary, it also made him a target of resentment. In 1869, in Kyoto, opponents to his reforms struck him down. He would not live to see his vision realized.

Yet, history vindicated him. The Imperial Japanese Army that later rose was built precisely on the principles he laid out. The inscription on the pedestal reminds passersby of this legacy: though he began as a doctor, he became the father of Japan’s modern military. The Meiji leaders who chose to erect his statue just a decade after his death clearly wanted to immortalize him as a symbol of Japan’s new direction—a bridge between the world of traditional Edo and the industrial modernity of Meiji.

On a personal level, standing in front of this monument made me think of how transitions often come through individuals willing to break convention. Ōmura’s transformation from healer to strategist, from provincial doctor to a national reformer, embodies that restless energy of a Japan caught between worlds. His bronze likeness seems to gaze ahead, not just into the past he left behind, but into the uncertain future he helped shape.

For me, the statue is not simply a relic of history, but a reminder that progress often comes at a cost, borne by individuals willing to challenge entrenched systems. Ōmura Masujirō paid with his life, but the Japan of the modern era walked forward on the foundation of his ideas.

place_info.title: 出征を見送る家族の像
place_info.address: Japan, 〒102-0073 Tokyo, Chiyoda City, Kudankita, 1 Chome−15−5

reviews.snippet:
Statue of a Family Seeing Off a Soldier

On my walk through Yasukuni—after the monumental steel of the First Torii and the quieter symbolism of the Memorial Fountain—this bronze group stopped me cold. Unlike martial statues that celebrate victory or leaders, this one faces the cost of departure. The soldier is absent. What remains is the weight of goodbye.

What the Statue Shows (Design & Composition)

1.	Five figures on a high granite plinth: an elderly father, a mother in kimono, a young woman holding an infant, and a school-aged boy.

2.	Forward gaze: most faces look outward, as if toward a train platform or harbor—imagining the loved one already beyond reach.

3.	Everyday clothing, bare feet, simple textures: the choice strips away heroics and places the scene firmly in ordinary life.

4.	Granite base + bronze figures: the cool, immovable stone contrasts with warm, time-softened bronze—endurance versus emotion.

What the Plaque Says:

The inscription explains that the group symbolizes a family united in spirit as they send a relative to the front.

It also honors the resolve of those who stay behind—the ones who keep the household, endure shortages, and shoulder uncertainty.

In short: the statue expands “service” beyond the battlefield to the family’s daily courage.

Historical Lens (Why this Matters Here)
•   Yasukuni enshrines the souls of those who died in service from the Meiji era onward.
•   Wartime Japan cast the household as a moral unit: the soldier fights; the family sustains.
•   By omitting the departing soldier, the statue reframes remembrance around absence—the quiet center of most wars.

Personal Reflection (What it felt like)
•   First impression: a hush. The bronze doesn’t dramatize; it shows waiting—a harder emotion to monument-alize, yet more universal.
•   The infant drew my eye: a future that will grow up with stories instead of a parent.
•   The boy’s posture mixes pride and imitation; he looks up as if rehearsing adulthood sooner than he should.
•   The grandparents’ faces carry the long memory of previous losses and the duty not to falter in front of the young.

Standing there, I realized how departure contains two battles: one at the front, and one at home where the clock moves slowly and news arrives late. This sculpture gives form to the second battle.

Balanced Reading (Honor and Ambivalence)
•   The work respects sacrifice—it is honest about duty, unity, and resilience.
•   It also invites critical empathy: admiration for courage, awareness of the policies and pressures that create such farewells.
•   Holding both truths together is the most responsible way to remember.

Takeaways:
1.	Scope of sacrifice: War alters households, not only armies.
2.	Language of absence: By not showing the soldier, the piece centers those who bear the waiting.
3.	Continuity: The infant and the boy imply that memory becomes upbringing—how a nation teaches the next generation to understand loss.

How it fits my route
•   First Torii = national threshold and collective memory.
•   Memorial Fountain = consolation and purification.
•   Family Statue = the human cost carried home.

Seen together, the path moves from monumentality to intimacy; from steel, to water, to faces.

images.title: 出征を見送る家族の像

place_info.title: さくら陶板
place_info.address: Japan, 〒102-0073 Tokyo, Chiyoda City, Kudankita, 3 Chome−1−1

reviews.snippet:
Walking through Yasukuni on 1 August 2025, I came across the Sakura Ceramic Tiles (さくら陶板), and they instantly caught my attention. Unlike the towering torii or the grand monuments, these works felt quieter and more personal — almost like whispers tucked into the pathway.

Each stone frame held a sakura blossom, carefully crafted from small ceramic tiles. At first glance, I saw them simply as beautiful designs — shimmering petals that glowed differently in the light. But as I leaned closer, the meaning became clearer. The cherry blossom has always symbolized the fleeting nature of life in Japan — short, delicate, and yet profoundly beautiful. At Yasukuni, this symbolism takes on a deeper weight: every fragment of ceramic represents an individual life, a soul enshrined here. Together, they form a complete flower, showing how countless personal sacrifices are bound into one collective memory of the nation.

Some blossoms shone brightly with golden hues, others carried softer or darker tones. It felt as if each design reflected different moods of remembrance — joy, grief, pride, impermanence. I also noticed the plaques: each piece was donated by different prefectures or groups across Japan, a reminder that memory is shared not only by families but by whole communities.

Standing there, I realized these sakura tiles represent more than decoration. They embody the idea that history is not only about generals, battles, or monuments, but also about fragile lives, each as fleeting as a petal. Together, they bloom into something larger, reminding us that remembrance is both personal and collective.

It was a quiet, grounding moment — to see how art, symbolism, and memory all meet in the shape of a flower.

place_info.title: Memorial Fountain
place_info.address: 2 Chome-1 Kudankita, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 102-0073, Japan

reviews.snippet:
Water and Stones – A Different Kind of War Memory

When I reached the Memorial Fountain at Yasukuni Shrine, I was struck by how different it felt from the torii gates and stone monuments I had passed earlier. Instead of traditional wooden architecture or solemn vertical steles, here was a modernist sculpture in concrete, almost abstract in its form. Its layers fan outward like folded wings or waves, and from within, water flows steadily into a dark, rectangular pool. It felt less like a shrine structure and more like something I would expect in a contemporary peace park.

The design is deliberate. Built in 1965, this fountain was not about projecting permanence or grandeur like the steel torii. Instead, it offers a softer symbolism — water as purification, comfort, and renewal. In Shinto and Japanese tradition, flowing water carries away impurity and unrest, and here it seems to whisper: may the spirits find peace, may grief flow onward and transform. Standing in front of it, I found myself slowing down, listening to the sound of the water more than looking at the concrete. It was calming, as if reminding me that remembrance does not always have to be heavy — it can also be gentle.

But just nearby, the mood changes again with the “Stones from Old Battlefields” (戦跡の石). Along a curved wall are small circular alcoves, each holding a rough stone, labeled with names like Leyte, Guam, Wake Island, Kohima, China. These are not symbolic stones — they are actual fragments collected from the places where battles were fought, where soldiers fell. Holding their raw shapes and textures, they feel almost like relics brought home. I found this simple display incredibly powerful: no bronze statues, no heroic inscriptions, just silent rocks from faraway lands, each carrying its own unspoken story.

The juxtaposition of water and stone struck me. The fountain is all about flow and release, while the stones are about weight and memory. One dissolves grief, the other anchors it. Together they create a layered experience: first reminding you of the human cost of war across the globe, then offering you a space to let those heavy thoughts find peace in the sound of water.

For me, this part of Yasukuni was the most moving — not because it was grand, but because it was understated. The stones make the wars real, connecting Tokyo to Leyte, New Guinea, and China in a tangible way. The fountain makes the mourning human, reminding us that beyond ideology, there is a universal need to console the dead and the living alike.

Walking away, I felt that this combination was one of the few places inside Yasukuni that quietly bridged the gap between the past and the present — showing how memory can be heavy like stone, yet also healing like water.

place_info.title: 第一鳥居奉献記念碑
place_info.address: Japan, 〒102-0073 Tokyo, Chiyoda City, Kudankita, 2 Chome−1

reviews.snippet:
A Quiet Stone Beside a Giant Gate

When I visited Yasukuni Shrine on 1 August 2025, my eyes were immediately drawn to the massive steel First Torii, towering above everything. But just off to the side stood something far easier to overlook — the First Torii Dedication Monument. Compared to the gate’s overwhelming size, this stone stele seemed modest, yet it carried its own quiet weight.

The inscription, 第一鳥居奉献記念碑, tells the story simply: this was the commemorative marker for the offering of the First Torii. In other words, it is not just a gate you walk through, but a gate that was given — dedicated by people who believed in making a lasting contribution. It reminded me that even great monuments have roots in community effort, donations, and shared intentions.

I found myself reflecting on the choice of words — 奉献 (hōken), meaning a reverent offering. It wasn’t just “built,” it was offered to the shrine, almost like a prayer in steel and stone. The donors must have imagined the torii standing for generations, outliving them, framing every visitor’s journey into the shrine. In a sense, the monument preserves not just the torii, but also the spirit of giving that made it possible.

It’s easy to walk past this dedication stele without noticing, but pausing there gave me a different perspective. The First Torii isn’t only an entrance into sacred space; it is also a monument born out of human effort and faith. The dedication stone quietly whispers this backstory, turning a giant gate into something more personal, almost intimate.

Sometimes it’s the small stones beside the big monuments that tell the most human stories. The First Torii impresses with power, but the Dedication Monument makes you think about the people — donors, veterans, and citizens — who wanted to leave something behind. Together, they create a layered memory: one of grandeur, and one of gratitude.

place_info.title: Memorial Monument to Tanaka Shitai
place_info.address: 2 Chome-1 Kudankita, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 102-0073, Japan

reviews.snippet:
The Tanaka Shitai Monument – A Stone Testament to Heroism and Tragedy

As I walked further into Yasukuni Shrine after passing the First Torii, one of the most solemn monuments I encountered was the Tanaka Shitai Chūkonhi (田中支隊忠魂碑) — the Monument to the Loyal Souls of the Tanaka Detachment. Rising vertically from a broad stone base, the inscription speaks clearly: this is a tribute to those who perished during the Siberian Intervention (1918–1922), a campaign that carried Japanese troops deep into the chaos of the Russian Civil War.

The story behind this monument is both tragic and heroic. On 25 February 1919, the Tanaka Detachment, part of the 72nd Infantry Regiment, under the command of Major Tanaka Katsusuke, found themselves cut off in Siberia, surrounded by enemy forces that outnumbered them many times over. In what later came to be known as their last stand, the soldiers fought with discipline and desperation, refusing to surrender. Eyewitness accounts described them battling until their ammunition was spent, then engaging in hand-to-hand combat with bayonets, swords, and even bare hands.

Despite the overwhelming odds, they fought to the end. Almost the entire detachment was annihilated — but their stand became immortalized in Japanese military memory as an example of 忠義 (chūgi) — loyal righteousness. In the language of the time, they were remembered as men who embodied the samurai ideal of dying honorably for the nation, their sacrifice cast as a model for later generations.

The monument originally stood near the Ushigafuchi Moat, close to where many military memorials were concentrated in early 20th-century Tokyo. In 1996, it was moved inside Yasukuni Shrine’s precincts to stand among other regimental memorials, ensuring that the memory of the Tanaka Shitai would continue to be honored within the sacred grounds dedicated to Japan’s war dead.

Heroism in Historical Perspective

From one perspective, the Tanaka Shitai’s final battle fits the archetype of heroic last stands — like the Spartans at Thermopylae or the Light Brigade at Balaclava. It was a doomed fight, but one remembered precisely because of its futility. For Japan of the early 20th century, still crafting a national identity tied to military valor, such sacrifices were elevated as a source of pride and inspiration.

Yet standing before the monument today, I felt a mix of admiration and unease. Admiration for the courage and loyalty of men who did not break under pressure; unease because their deaths came in a foreign land, far from home, in a campaign that history now sees as part of Japan’s imperial overreach. Their heroism is undeniable, but so too is the question of what cause it served.

Thus, the Tanaka Shitai Monument is more than a stone stele. It is a mirror of history’s duality — heroism in the face of certain death, but also tragedy born of politics and imperial ambition. Standing before it, I felt both respect for the men and a reminder of the complexity of the wars Japan chose to fight.

place_info.title: Yasuni Shrine - the First Torii
place_info.address: 3 Chome-1-1 Kudankita, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 102-0073, Japan

reviews.snippet:
The First Torii – Gateway to Memory

On 1 August 2025, as I approached Yasukuni Shrine on the path toward the Yūshūkan Museum, the First Torii (Ōtorii) stood as the first and most commanding monument before me. Rising nearly 25 meters high and 34 meters wide, its sheer size arrested my attention even before stepping through. Unlike the familiar wooden torii of other shrines, this one is forged entirely of steel, a decision made in 1921, when Japan projected itself as a modern power at the height of its imperial era.

The torii was more than just a gate; it was a statement of permanence. Passing beneath it, I felt that I was crossing from the ordinary streets of Tokyo into a carefully constructed realm of memory, where every step is designed to remind visitors of sacrifice, loyalty, and the collective spirit of the nation. The fact that this steel gate survived the bombings of Tokyo in 1945 gives it an almost indestructible aura — a monument that has outlasted empires, governments, and even the lives of those it was meant to honor.

It struck me that the First Torii is not neutral. Built during an era when the state bound Shinto to nationalism, it carries with it the weight of contested history. For some, it represents reverence for the war dead; for others, it symbolizes the darker legacy of militarism. Yet for every visitor walking toward Yūshūkan, it is inescapably the first marker of remembrance, framing the shrine’s narrative long before one encounters its halls, exhibits, or memorial stones.

As I paused beneath its shadow, I realized that the First Torii does not only frame an entrance — it frames interpretation. It sets the tone for everything that follows inside Yasukuni. Whether one walks with reverence, curiosity, or unease, the experience begins here, under the steel crossbeam that has stood for more than a century.

Thus, on that day in August 2025, the First Torii was not only the first structure I encountered but also the first lesson: that Yasukuni Shrine is as much about how Japan remembers as it is about what Japan remembers.

place_info.title: Indian Restaurant Mumbai Kudan
place_info.address: 松岡九段ビル B1F 2 Chome-2-8 Kudanminami, Chiyoda City, Tokyo 102-0074, Japan

reviews.snippet:
After our visit to Yūshūkan Shrine, we wandered a little further and eventually found ourselves at Indian Restaurant Mumbai Kudan.

It felt like the perfect stop — a cozy retreat after the solemnity and historical depth of the shrine. From the moment we stepped inside, the atmosphere set a welcoming tone.

The interior is warm and inviting, with soft lighting and décor that blends subtle touches of Indian culture with a clean, modern Japanese sense of order.

The seating is comfortable and spaced well, creating an intimate environment that works whether you’re dining as a couple, with friends, or even alone.

There’s also a faint but comforting aroma of spices in the air that instantly stirs your appetite, reminding you that this is not just another international restaurant in Tokyo but a place that takes its cuisine seriously.

The staff played a big role in making the meal memorable. They greeted us warmly, spoke with genuine friendliness, and never once gave the impression of being rushed. Even small gestures — a smile while serving, or checking in discreetly to make sure everything was fine — showed their attention to detail. They struck a rare balance between professionalism and personal warmth, which made the experience feel less like being a customer and more like being a welcomed guest.

As for the food, it truly delivered. The lamb biryani came in the right portion size — hearty enough to satisfy without being overwhelming. Each spoonful carried the depth of carefully balanced spices, the rice cooked to perfection, and the lamb tender and flavorful. The accompanying raita was cool and refreshing, cutting through the richness of the biryani just as it should. The chicken soup, while simpler, was comforting and light, almost like a gentle prelude before the main act. And the mango lassi was the perfect finishing touch: creamy, chilled, and naturally sweet, refreshing both the palate and the spirit.

Yes, the prices are a little on the higher side compared to a quick casual eatery, but given the quality of the food, the care in presentation, the friendliness of the staff, and the overall pleasant interior, it felt justified.

It’s not just a place to fill your stomach; it’s a place to sit down, enjoy, and unwind after a long day of exploring. For us, it became more than just dinner — it felt like part of the journey itself, blending seamlessly into the memory of that day in Kudan.

place_info.title: HOTEL S, Hachijo
place_info.address: 5 Chome-435-1 Hachijo, Nara, 630-8145, Japan

reviews.snippet:
We didn’t plan for it, but that’s what makes travel interesting. After a scenic trip to Shirakawago, we found ourselves in the middle of Japan’s Mountain Day long weekend with nowhere to stay in Kansai. Hotels were either sold out or ridiculously priced.

Then we spotted Hotel S online—good rate, great location, nice facilities. Click. Booked. Done. It wasn’t until later that we realised… we’d just booked a love hotel.

For a bunch of travellers from Malaysia, this was going to be something new.

Love hotels in Japan have an interesting past. They popped up after World War II when many couples lived with extended family and had no real privacy. Back then, they were called kashi-houra - cheap rooms rented by the hour, usually near train stations.

By the 1960s, the idea had evolved into themed hotels, and in 1968 Osaka’s “Hotel Love” gave the entire industry its name. Fast forward to the bubble era of the 1980s and they were full-on extravagant - think jacuzzis, karaoke, even space-themed rooms.

Laws in the mid-80s forced them to tone down the flashy exteriors, and today many have reinvented themselves into stylish, spa-like hideaways.

Hotel S is one of those modernised ones. It’s in Nara’s Hachijō district and had just been refurbished in July 2025. The look is sleek Japanese-modern, but it keeps the love hotel perks: private covered parking for every room, discreet entrances, and automated check-in and check-out.

We arrived just before midnight on 9 August for a four-night stay in two spacious Deluxe Double Rooms—40 m² each, king beds, booked for four adults. Coffee, tea, bottled water, breakfast, and Wi-Fi were all included.

After a 30 minute briefing by a local Japanese manager with very broken English, we were assigned rooms but not given keys. Even no information from our passports were requested, which is very strange.

The rooms were much bigger than we expected. Our bed sat on a raised platform against a bold red floral wall, with a cosy sofa and coffee table in front of a huge flat-screen TV. There was so much space that our hiking gear barely made a dent in it.

The entryway had a long counter with a kettle and neatly arranged slippers—a quiet nod to Japanese hospitality.

The bathroom was a highlight: deep soaking tub, plus shelves crammed with free personal care products you’d never get in a business hotel—hair water, styling milk, cleansers, bath gel, shaving foam, and more.

On the ground floor, our parking space even came with a multilingual sign with a board to cover guests' car's plate number for privacy.

In the room, a clear info sheet explained the hotel’s systems: automated payment machines, optional auto-lock deactivation, late check-out fees of JPY 1,340 per 30 minutes, and the rules for online bookings.

Breakfast was brought to the room every morning—my favourite was the colourful bento of rice with mentaiko, tamagoyaki, pickles, tempura, and juice.

For travellers who’ve never stayed in a love hotel, here’s what to know. Don’t expect much staff interaction - check-in is usually automated, and English may be limited, so a translation app helps.

Many switches and remotes are labelled only in Japanese, so spend a few minutes figuring them out. There’s no concierge, no tourist brochures, no communal lounge—these places are built for privacy, not for planning your sightseeing. Breakfast is usually set-menu in-room service, so if you want variety, locate the nearest convenience store.

If you’re on foot, know that the entrances and parking bays are designed for discretion, which can be a little confusing the first time.

But if you go in with an open mind, you’ll find a love hotel often gives you more space, a bigger bed, and a better bathtub than most mid-range hotels in Japan.

Our accidental booking turned out to be a win - comfortable, spotless, private, and just different enough to make the story worth telling. For anyone exploring Nara and curious about this slice of Japanese culture, Hotel S might surprise you—in the best way.

place_info.title: MUJI - MyTOWN Shopping Centre
place_info.address: Level 1, MyTown Shopping Centre Lot L-001, 90, Jalan Cochrane, Cheras, 55100 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I dropped by MUJI at IOI City Mall on Sunday, 17 August 2025 with my daughter. At first, it was just to pick up some stationery for her since I didn’t manage to buy anything for her during my recent trip to Japan. But as always with MUJI, the visit turned into more than just a quick shop.

The store has that familiar calming vibe—wide aisles, wooden shelves, soft lighting, and everything neatly arranged. We started with the stationery section, which is always a highlight. My daughter had fun choosing a few things and we ended up with a file partition, an aluminium ruler, a gel pen, and a pencil cap set. Small, simple items, but MUJI makes even these everyday things feel a bit special.

As we walked through, I noticed how well-organized the layout was. The clothing section looked very inviting with stacks of neatly folded basics in neutral tones, while the travel area showed off sturdy luggage and practical bags. I liked the home and storage section the most—rows of polypropylene boxes, organizers, and wooden shelves that make you want to go home and reorganize your whole space. They also had an interior consultation corner, which is a nice touch for people looking to redesign their rooms.

What really stood out was the kids’ play area tucked inside the store. There were mats, beanbags, and blocks where children could sit and play while their parents shopped. It’s not something you usually see in lifestyle stores, and it gave the place a friendlier, family-focused atmosphere.

The food corner was another highlight. Baskets of Japanese snacks, curry packs, and teas gave a nice cultural feel to the store. There was even a clearly marked non-halal section, which is good for Muslim shoppers like me to navigate without worry. On top of that, the skincare and aroma section looked well curated, with diffusers, oils, and simple skincare lines adding to the overall lifestyle experience.

By the time we left, I realized it wasn’t just about buying four small stationery items. It was about sharing the time with my daughter, browsing calmly through a store that makes you slow down, and appreciating how MUJI turns everyday essentials into something thoughtful. This outlet at IOI City Mall really captures that balance of Japanese simplicity with Malaysian practicality, and for me it turned an ordinary Sunday outing into a meaningful memory.

place_info.title: HALAL SAKURA
place_info.address: ルート根岸第２ビル 1F・2F 2 Chome-18-11 Negishi, Taito City, Tokyo 110-0003, Japan

reviews.snippet:
We stumbled upon Halal Sakura after finishing our visit to the Tokyo National Museum on the afternoon of 31 July 2025. A quick check on Google Maps showed it was within walking distance, so my friend and I made our way there, arriving at about 5.30 pm for an early dinner. The streets around Uguisudani were quiet at that hour, and when we stepped inside the restaurant, it was almost empty, giving us the feeling of having the whole place to ourselves.

The owners, originally from Samarkand in Uzbekistan, welcomed us warmly. Their friendliness immediately made the place feel homely rather than just another restaurant in central Tokyo. The décor had touches of Central Asia, with patterned fabrics on the booths and a low table with cushions by the window, but what really mattered was the food—and it turned out to be the best part of the evening.

We decided to start with a hearty spread, and the first dish that came to our table was the kebab set. It was an impressive sight: eight skewers lined neatly on a wooden board, with each stick offering something different. There were lamb kebabs, beef, chicken, and minced meat, all charred just enough to lock in the juices, with alternating pieces of tomato, onion, and green pepper. The smoky aroma rose as soon as the platter landed on the table, and each bite lived up to that promise—tender, flavorful, and satisfying. The kebabs were served with a side of fries, a simple coleslaw salad, and a tangy tomato sauce that gave a nice kick. It was generous enough that two people could comfortably share, though we happily tried every skewer.

Next came the plov, or osh as it’s also called—the national dish of Uzbekistan. This was pure comfort food. A large plate of rice, fragrant and slightly oily in the best way, was topped with chunks of tender lamb, soft chickpeas, and strips of sweet carrot. The addition of boiled quail eggs made it even more traditional. The flavor was rich but not heavy, the kind of dish that feels like it could easily be a full meal on its own. Eating it in Tokyo, just a short walk away from the museum and the city buzz, felt like we had been transported to another part of the world.

We also had a bowl of lamb soup, which was light but warming. The broth was golden and clear, with pieces of lamb, carrots, and red peppers floating in it. It was seasoned gently, not overpowering, which made it a perfect balance to the stronger flavors of the kebabs and plov. It reminded me of the kind of soup that would be served at the beginning of a family meal—comforting and simple, something that prepared the stomach for the bigger dishes.

To wash it all down, we each had a cup of ayran, the salted yogurt drink that’s so common across Central Asia. Cold and slightly tangy, it was exactly what we needed with the grilled meats, cutting through the richness and refreshing the palate. By the end of the meal, we both agreed that without ayran, the kebabs wouldn’t have felt quite as complete.

When the bill arrived, it came to ¥7,200 for two people. Slightly on the higher side for a casual dinner, but given the quality of the food, the portion sizes, and the fact that we were in central Tokyo eating authentic Uzbek halal cuisine, it felt fair.

Halal Sakura isn’t just about eating—it’s about experiencing something different in the heart of Tokyo. The food was excellent, each dish prepared with care, and the owners’ warmth made the evening even better. Walking back, full and content, I thought about how unexpected it was to find a little slice of Uzbekistan hidden away in a Tokyo neighborhood. For us, it was a perfect dinner after a long day of sightseeing, and it’s a place I’d happily return to.

response.snippet:
Dear Azmi Mahamad 
Thank you so much for your thoughtful review! We are delighted you enjoyed the kebabs, plov, soup, and ayran, and that our hospitality made you feel at home. Your kind words mean a lot to us, and we look forward to welcoming you again whenever you are in Tokyo.

Warm regards,
Halal Sakura Team

place_info.title: Randor Residence Tokyo Annex
place_info.address: Japan, 〒116-0001 Tokyo, Arakawa City, Machiya, 1 Chome−6−9

reviews.snippet:
We stayed at Randor Residence Tokyo Annex for three nights starting 30 July 2025, booking two apartments before heading to Kawaguchiko for our Mt. Fuji hike. The place turned out to be a great base for us, combining comfort, space, and convenience in a quiet neighborhood. The rate was very reasonable.

The location is really practical, less than a ten-minute walk from Machiya Station, with small streets lined by local shops, bicycles, and vending machines selling drinks for just JPY180. Even at night the area feels safe, with warm lights from the apartments and shopfronts creating a cozy neighborhood atmosphere. It’s not a touristy spot, and that’s what makes it appealing—you get a sense of ordinary Tokyo life, while still being close to public transport and halal restaurants within walking distance.

The apartments themselves are surprisingly spacious by Tokyo standards. Our unit had two comfortable beds with fresh linens and plenty of natural light streaming in from the balcony. The living space included a sofa and a TV, and the kitchen came fully equipped with a refrigerator, microwave, stovetop, and utensils. Having a dining table and a proper kitchen meant we could prepare simple halal meals, which was a real advantage for us.

The bathroom setup follows the Japanese style, with the toilet and bath separated. The bath area had a deep soaking tub and a shower with good water pressure, along with refillable bottles of shampoo and body soap. The toilet was modern and spotless, set apart with a wooden floor finish. One of the most useful features was the washing machine and drying rack inside the apartment—perfect for travelers preparing for outdoor activities like our upcoming hike.

From the higher floors, the views were a nice surprise. In the daytime you could see a mix of modern high-rise buildings and older blocks with rooftop gardens, while at night the neighborhood glowed softly with streetlights and signboards. It gave us a sense of both the old and new Tokyo coexisting side by side.

Overall, Randor Residence Tokyo Annex felt more like a home than a hotel. The check-in process was smooth with clear English instructions, the apartments were kept very clean, and the atmosphere was peaceful. It was ideal for a group like ours, with the extra space and facilities making our short stay much more comfortable than a standard hotel room. If I had to sum it up, I’d say it’s the kind of place where you can settle in easily, rest well, and feel ready for the next stage of your journey.

details.hotel_highlights: Great view, Quiet, Kid-friendly, Great value

place_info.title: Dal Bhat Eatery & Halal Foods
place_info.address: 3 Chome-2-1 Machiya, Arakawa City, Tokyo 116-0001, Japan

reviews.snippet:
Dal Bhat Eatery & Halal Foods – Machiya, Tokyo

We were a group of six Malaysians staying nearby in Machiya before our trip to Fuji. After searching on Google Maps for halal food options, we found Dal Bhat Eatery & Halal Foods, located in the Lions Plaza Machiya complex.

It’s not immediately easy to find—especially if you enter from the side lane like we did—but once you head downstairs to the concourse (B1) level, the restaurant greets you with a modest entrance, bright food posters, and a warm “Welcome” sign.

Inside, the restaurant felt lively and authentic. Part eatery, part Asian food bazaar, the shelves were stacked with rice bags, spices, and snacks from Nepal and South Asia. It reminded us of small eateries back home, which immediately made us feel comfortable. Seating is compact but cozy, and the friendly atmosphere added to the charm.

What We Ate

We ordered a mix of curries and side dishes to share. The tandoori chicken was one of the highlights—juicy, well-marinated, and served sizzling hot on onions. The seasoning had the right balance of spice and smokiness, and the meat was tender inside.

The biryani was another winner, beautifully spiced with long-grain basmati rice, garnished with onions, and accompanied by cool yogurt raita. It was fragrant and flavorful without being too heavy, perfect for sharing.

We also enjoyed freshly baked naan—garlic naan with its crisp edges and sesame toppings, and cheese naan, soft, gooey, and indulgent. Both paired perfectly with the curries.

For something different, we tried momos (Nepali dumplings) in curry sauce. This dish stood out as a unique blend of Nepali and South Asian flavors, with dumplings sitting in a rich, spiced gravy that we happily dipped our naan into.

Experience

The food was very tasty and suited our Malaysian palate. Portions were reasonable, neither too small nor too overwhelming, and sharing made it feel like a family-style dinner. The bill for all of us came to JPY4,450, which we found very reasonable for Tokyo, especially considering the quality and variety of dishes we enjoyed.

The fact that the restaurant is halal-friendly gave us peace of mind, which is always important when traveling. The staff were polite and attentive, and even though it was past 8 pm, they served us with a smile.

Final Thoughts

Our visit to Dal Bhat Eatery was a pleasant surprise—affordable, halal, authentic, and hearty. It felt like a hidden gem in Machiya, offering Muslim travelers in Tokyo a taste of home with a Nepali twist. We left satisfied and happy, ready for our journey to Fuji the next day.

We would definitely recommend this place to anyone in the area, and we’d gladly come back on our next trip to Tokyo.

place_info.title: Naritasan Shinsho-ji
place_info.address: 1 Narita, Chiba 286-0023, Japan

reviews.snippet:
Walking through Naritasan Shinshoji Temple feels like stepping into a living timeline of Japan’s spiritual and cultural heritage.

Founded in 940 CE, the temple has grown over centuries into a sprawling complex where history, faith, and artistry coexist seamlessly. What struck me most is how each structure tells its own story, yet together they create a rhythm—an unbroken flow of tradition and renewal.

We, a group of six Malaysians coming for our Mt Fuji expedition, visited this temple on 30 July 2025 to kill some time upon arriving at Narita Airport before checking in to our accommodation in Tokyo. What began as a simple detour quickly turned into one of the most memorable highlights of the trip.

The journey begins with the grand Niomon Gate, its massive guardian statues standing as if frozen in eternal vigilance. Passing through, you enter a world where ancient pagodas and modern reconstructions blend without losing their sacred character. The Three-Story Pagoda, with its delicate carvings and vivid colors, feels like a jewel box of Edo-period craftsmanship—ornate but harmonious, reminding you that architecture here was always more than function; it was an offering in itself.

The Main Hall, by contrast, overwhelms with scale rather than ornament. Its golden altar, soaring roof beams, and tatami-lined expanse give it an atmosphere of solemn energy. Watching monks in colorful robes perform their ritual processions inside made me realize how this isn’t just a preserved monument—it’s a temple still alive, still breathing with daily devotion. The deep resonance of chants and drums carried through the hall in a way that gave the space both gravitas and warmth.

What ties everything together is Naritasan’s cultural role as a place of pilgrimage. Since the Edo period, commoners flocked here not only for religious purposes but also for a sense of shared belonging. Walking its paths today, you sense that continuity—the same incense smoke curling skyward, the same wooden halls echoing with prayers, the same pagodas standing firm against centuries of change.

For us, Naritasan Shinshoji was less about single highlights and more about layers. Each gate, hall, and pagoda is a fragment of Japan’s past—political stability, artistic ambition, spiritual resilience—woven into one living temple. It’s the kind of place where history isn’t trapped behind glass; it lingers in the air, beneath the roof tiles, in the footsteps of monks and pilgrims alike.

place_info.title: Three-story Pagoda
place_info.address: 1 Narita, Chiba 286-0023, Japan

reviews.snippet:
The Three-Story Pagoda at Naritasan Shinshoji

Standing before the Three-Story Pagoda, I felt as if I was looking not only at a religious monument but also at a jewel box of Japanese architectural mastery from the Edo period. Originally built in 1712, the pagoda has survived more than three centuries, carrying with it the devotion, artistry, and symbolism of a time when Buddhist architecture was at its most vibrant. It is officially designated as an Important Cultural Property of Japan, and it is easy to see why.

Architecturally, the pagoda embodies the perfection of Edo craftsmanship. Each of its three stories narrows elegantly as they ascend, a rhythm of proportion and balance that makes the tall structure feel both monumental and graceful. The rooflines are built in the irimoya style (hip-and-gable), their sweeping curves accentuated by meticulously arranged tiles. Rising from the very top is the sōrin, the bronze spire that symbolizes the axis of the universe in Buddhist cosmology. Its segmented rings represent the stages of enlightenment, a constant reminder of the spiritual purpose behind the architectural grandeur.

What makes this pagoda especially captivating is its ornamentation. Unlike some plainer Zen structures, this pagoda bursts with color and detail, reflecting the ornate taste of the Tokugawa era. The brackets and eaves are decorated with intricate carvings of mythical beasts—dragons, lions, phoenixes—guardians of sacred space. Painted clouds and wave patterns swirl under the eaves, giving the sense that the building itself floats between heaven and earth. Gilded accents catch the sunlight, making the structure shimmer like a treasure chest.

Historically, pagodas in Japan were built as reliquaries, symbolic towers that enshrined sacred texts or relics of the Buddha. While this particular pagoda is more symbolic than functional, it stands as a representation of the Buddhist universe—each tier reflecting elements of earth, water, fire, wind, and space. Its presence within the Naritasan complex emphasizes the temple’s long-standing role as a spiritual center since its founding in 940 CE.

In its position beside the Great Main Hall, the Three-Story Pagoda feels like a counterpoint—while the Main Hall is solemn and massive, the pagoda is vibrant and expressive. Walking around it, I was struck by how it harmonized with the larger temple grounds while still drawing attention as a masterpiece on its own. It is not just a building; it is a sermon in wood, lacquer, and gold.

On a personal level, I found myself imagining the artisans who built and repainted it across centuries. Their brushstrokes, chisels, and gold leaf applications remain alive in this structure, whispering across time. To stand before it is to witness the endurance of faith and beauty, a fusion of architecture and spirituality that has survived wars, earthquakes, and countless generations of change.

place_info.title: Niomon Gate
place_info.address: 1 Narita, Chiba 286-0023, Japan

reviews.snippet:
When I reached the Niōmon Gate of Naritasan Shinshō-ji, I immediately felt that I was no longer just a visitor but a participant in a centuries-old tradition. Unlike the bright, relatively modern Sōmon Gate that welcomes you from the town side, the Niōmon carries an older, more solemn character. Its weathered wood and massive presence reveal its Edo-period origins, standing here since the early 19th century as both protector and passageway.

The first thing that caught my eyes were the two towering Niō guardians flanking the gate. One bares his teeth with a fierce open mouth, the other silent with lips pressed together. Together they embody the eternal cycle of “A” and “Un,” the beginning and the end of all things. Looking at them, I understood why pilgrims across the generations would feel both fear and reassurance here—the reminder that faith requires both courage and surrender.

Passing under the huge lantern, I couldn’t help but look up at the intricate carvings, dragons curling along beams and protective motifs etched into the wood. They are more than decorations; they are silent prayers locked in timber, enduring the rains and winds of nearly two centuries. I thought of the countless hands that built and restored it, and the generations of devotees who paused at this threshold to bow, to pray, or simply to breathe before stepping deeper into the sacred grounds.

What makes this gate so special is its atmosphere. The Sōmon tells you that you have arrived at Naritasan, but the Niōmon tells you that you are now entering holy space. Crossing it felt like leaving behind noise and distractions, as if the guardians were demanding me to check my heart before walking further. For me, this was not just architecture; it was an encounter with history, belief, and discipline, concentrated in a single passage.

place_info.title: Benzaitendō Hall
place_info.address: 355 Honcho, Narita, Chiba 286-0023, Japan

reviews.snippet:
After wandering through the larger, more imposing halls of Naritasan Shinsho-ji, I found myself drawn to a quieter corner of the grounds, where the atmosphere softened and the sound of trickling water took over. This was Benzaitendō Hall, a small vermillion shrine that seemed to whisper rather than proclaim its presence.

The approach itself set the tone. A stone wall lined with carved names and crests stretched along the path, each inscription a legacy of devotion from families, merchants, and pilgrims of the past. These stones reminded me that the temple is not only built by monks and carpenters but by the faith and offerings of countless ordinary people whose names still echo here.

Crossing into the hall’s precinct, I was met with a pond at the center, its still waters cradling the shrine like an island. The structure, with its hōgyō-zukuri roof, stood gracefully on stone posts, its red walls reflected in the water. This placement felt deeply symbolic—Benzaiten, the goddess of eloquence, music, fortune, and water, enshrined above her natural element. The reflection shimmered like a reminder that blessings, like water, are meant to flow freely.

As I leaned over the railing, I noticed the pond was alive with turtles, gliding slowly beneath the shrine. Their presence was striking. In Japanese tradition, turtles symbolize longevity and wisdom, and here they seemed like silent guardians, lending weight and patience to Benzaiten’s flowing energy of fortune. Together, the goddess above and the turtles below created a balance between the fleeting charm of prosperity and the enduring grace of time.

The modest sign by the hall confirmed its importance: erected in the Edo period, Benzaitendō is one of the oldest surviving structures within Naritasan. Its size may be humble compared to the grand Main Hall or towering pagoda, but its role is profound. While Fudō Myō-ō embodies immovable strength and protection, Benzaiten embodies gentle creativity, eloquence, and fortune. Standing there, I understood why pilgrims stop here after offering at the larger halls: to complement fire’s fierce purification with water’s soothing blessing.

I rang the small bell, bowed lightly, and offered a quiet thought—an unspoken wish for harmony in words, wisdom in choices, and a flow of blessings that would not overwhelm but gently sustain. As the sound of the bell faded into the ripples of the pond, I felt a sense of peace—like a song without lyrics, carried on water and time.

place_info.title: Somon Gate (Main Gate)
place_info.address: 347 Honcho, Narita, Chiba 286-0023, Japan

reviews.snippet:
A Journey Through the Sōmon Gate

As I walked the final stretch of Omotesandō Street, the rhythm of the city began to soften. The cheerful calls of shopkeepers, the smoky aroma of grilled unagi, and the lively chatter of visitors accompanied me, yet my eyes were already fixed on what stood ahead—the Sōmon Gate, broad and majestic, waiting like a sentinel at the entrance to Naritasan Shinsho-ji.

At first glance, the gate radiates antiquity. Its massive wooden pillars, the sweeping hip-and-gable roof, and the golden plaque inscribed with 成田山 give it the aura of a structure rooted in centuries. Yet in truth, the Sōmon is a modern creation, completed in 2008 to commemorate the temple’s 1,070th anniversary. That paradox fascinated me: how something so new could feel so timeless, as if it had always stood here, welcoming pilgrims.

Passing closer, I noticed the details that give it life—the elegant joinery, the subtle carvings, the protective ornaments along the roof ridge. Each element speaks of Japan’s reverence for craftsmanship, ensuring that even a modern addition resonates with tradition. I paused beneath its eaves, and for a moment, the bustle of Omotesandō fell away.

Stepping through the wide opening of the gate, I felt a shift inside me. In Buddhist tradition, the first gate is never just an entrance; it is a threshold between worlds. Behind me stretched the ordinary world of trade, food, and daily rhythm. Ahead of me unfolded a realm of incense, chanting, and sacred stillness. It was as though the Sōmon itself whispered: “Leave your burdens here; walk forward with a quieter heart.”

I turned briefly to look back. Framed within the wooden outline of the gate, the modern buildings and street seemed distant, almost foreign, as if I had stepped into a different dimension. That view confirmed what I felt—the Sōmon is not simply architecture. It is a bridge, a living reminder that entering Naritasan is not just a physical act but a spiritual journey.

For me, the Sōmon Gate set the tone of the entire visit. Its presence combined strength and welcome, tradition and renewal. Crossing its threshold was more than walking through wood and stone—it was the first step of a pilgrimage, a gentle yet powerful reminder that every sacred journey begins with the act of leaving one world behind to enter another.

place_info.title: Narita International Airport
place_info.address: 1-1 Furugome, Narita, Chiba 282-0004, Japan

reviews.snippet:
We, a group of six Malaysians, touched down at NRT from KUL at 8 am on 30 July 2025, after a short transit in HCMC. For me, this visit carried a certain sense of nostalgia. My first encounter with Narita was back in 2005, when I arrived on a business trip with all arrangements meticulously taken care of by my Japanese host, Ebara. This time, we had to make every arrangement on our own, from immigration procedures to finding our way into the city. In many ways, this made the experience feel more personal and rewarding.

Immigration clearance could not have gone more smoothly. Having pre-registered online beforehand, all we needed to do was present our QR codes at the counter. The entire process was efficient, straightforward, and done in minutes. It was one of those moments that reminded me how much Japan values preparation and how technology is applied thoughtfully to reduce unnecessary waiting.

At Customs, however, I faced a small challenge. The machine could not read my QR code, forcing me to return to the line and complete the procedure manually. The officer who assisted me was unfailingly polite, patient, and reassuring. Once he realised I was from Malaysia, he took extra care to explain the process and ensure everything was in order. That moment captured something essential about Japan: efficiency combined with genuine courtesy.

No sooner had we completed our clearance than news arrived of a tsunami alert following a massive earthquake in Russia. For us Malaysians, who rarely face such natural events, this was both unusual and slightly unsettling. Yet the atmosphere in the airport remained calm, and because we had no plans to go near the sea, the alert hardly disrupted our journey. Still, it was a reminder of Japan’s unique geographical realities and the way its people live with a constant awareness of natural forces larger than themselves.

Another moment that left an impression on me was spotting a patrol robot quietly moving through the terminal alongside security personnel. It was my first time encountering such a thing in person. This simple sight felt symbolic of Japan itself—an effortless blending of tradition and modernity, where human warmth coexists with cutting-edge innovation.

Our accommodation in Machiya, Tokyo, was only available for check-in after three o’clock in the afternoon. As one of our friends had warned us, Japanese hosts are known to be very strict with check-in and check-out times, and there was no possibility of negotiating an earlier entry. With several hours to spare, we decided to treat Narita not just as an airport but as the first chapter of our journey.

We placed our luggage in coin lockers, which were both convenient and secure, leaving us free to explore without being burdened by our bags. Lunch was taken at a halal udon restaurant inside the airport, a comforting and practical choice that reminded me how accommodating Narita has become for Muslim travellers. Afterwards, we bought Suica cards directly from the airport machines. With our cards ready, we boarded the train for a short excursion to Narita town, taking in the quiet charm of the place before returning to the airport once again. Later, we made our way to Tokyo by express bus.

Reflecting on the experience, I realised how much Narita Airport embodies the values that make Japan unique. The airport is immaculately clean, every facility carefully maintained. The signage is clear, the systems are well thought out, and the staff treat travellers not merely as numbers to be processed but as guests to be welcomed. Even in moments of uncertainty, such as a failed QR scan or a sudden tsunami alert, there is no sense of panic or indifference. Instead, there is order, calm, and an underlying courtesy that reassures you that you are being looked after.

Narita is often described simply as a gateway into Japan, but for me, it felt like more than that. It was the stage where our journey began, where first impressions were made, and where Japan’s unique blend of precision, discipline, and warmth became immediately visible.

place_info.title: Kineya Mugimaru (Halal) NRT 1T
place_info.address: Japan, 〒282-0004 Chiba, Narita, Sanrizuka, 第一旅客ターミナルビル中央棟 内 Narita International Airport, 5F

reviews.snippet:
Kineya Mugimaru, Narita International Airport T1 — A Memorable First Meal in Japan

We had just touched down at Narita on the morning of 30 July 2025, arriving from Kuala Lumpur for our long-awaited Fuji hiking expedition.

The airport was bustling with summer holiday travellers, and the atmosphere felt even livelier as Japan was in the midst of Ryo Taisai, a grand traditional festival.

Amidst the excitement, our group of six made our way to Kineya Mugimaru, a halal-certified udon restaurant located on the 5th floor of Terminal 1.

For me, this was more than just brunch—it was my first-ever dining experience in Japan, and I was eager to see how authentic Japanese flavours would translate in a halal setting.

The moment we spotted the bold sign “All Our Food is Halal”, it instantly put us at ease. Stepping inside, we were greeted by a warm, wood-themed interior, softly lit with Japanese-style lamps, creating a balance between casual dining and a traditional touch.

The service style here is straightforward and efficient, perfectly suited for travellers. You queue at the counter, choose your udon from the overhead menu, and then move along to select optional tempura or side dishes before paying.

Watching the chefs at work behind the open counter was part of the charm—fresh noodles boiling, broth steaming, and toppings carefully prepared right before our eyes.

I went for the Gyū Tororo Udon (牛とろろうどん), priced at JPY1,060. Self prepared steaming hot, with tender slices of beef laid neatly atop thick, springy udon noodles, all bathed in a light yet umami-rich broth.

The beef was delicate in flavour but beautifully complemented by the savoury depth of the soup. The tororo (grated yam) added a unique, creamy, and slightly sticky texture that clung to the noodles, creating a comforting mouthfeel.

Each bite was satisfying without being heavy, and the broth was so balanced that I found myself sipping it down to the last drop.

Given its airport location, the quality and price felt like exceptional value. It wasn’t just the food—it was the experience of starting my Japan journey with something so warm, authentic, and travel-friendly.

The restaurant’s spacious seating, calming atmosphere, and the reassurance of halal certification made it a perfect first stop after a long flight.

As I finished my meal, I felt a quiet sense of gratitude. This wasn’t just a bowl of udon—it was the first chapter of our Japan adventure, shared over good food, good company, and the anticipation of the journey ahead.

response.snippet: Thank you for your detailed and heartwarming review of your experience at our restaurant. We are truly honored that Kineya Mugimaru was your first dining experience in Japan. It brings us great joy to know that our halal-certified udon provided you with a comforting and authentic start to your Japanese adventure. We strive to create a welcoming atmosphere for all travelers, and we're delighted that you found our service efficient and our food satisfying. Your kind words about the Gyū Tororo Udon are particularly appreciated. We hope the rest of your Fuji hiking expedition was equally memorable, and we look forward to welcoming you again on your future visits to Japan.

place_info.title: Naritasan Omotesando
place_info.address: 350-3 Honcho, Narita, Chiba 286-0026, Japan

reviews.snippet:
Stepping Back in Time on Naritasan Omotesando

We decided to explore Narita town upon arrival at Narita Airport on 30 July 2025, before heading to our rented apartments in Machiya, Central Tokyo. It turned out to be a perfect choice — a gentle immersion into Japan’s history and culture before the buzz of the capital.

We took this street unintentionally when walking towards Naritasan Shinshoji from the station, and it felt like stumbling into a living postcard from another era.

Naritasan Omotesando stretched out ahead — an 800-meter slope lined with Edo- and Meiji-era wooden shopfronts, each with its own story. Here, time seemed to slow.

Shop signs were hand-painted, noren curtains swayed in the breeze, and the air carried a faint scent of soy glaze and grilled eel.

Narita’s fame for unagi dates back centuries, and we saw it in action — chefs deftly cleaning live eels right at the storefront, just as they have done for pilgrims visiting Naritasan Shinshoji Temple since the Edo period. Watching it felt like witnessing a craft handed down unchanged through generations.

The street itself was once the main pilgrimage route to the temple, and the sense of purpose lingers. Inns, teahouses, and sweet shops once catered to travelers on foot; today, they welcome visitors from around the world while preserving the same warmth and rhythm. The architecture tells its own story — dark timber, tiled roofs, and sliding windows that have looked out on hundreds of years of footsteps.

Every few steps offered a glimpse into another era: a traditional sweets shop selling monaka wafers filled with sweet bean paste, a lantern-lit alley leading to a hidden garden, an old merchant’s house repurposed as a crafts store. It was history you could touch, smell, and taste.

By the time we reached the temple gates, the modern world felt far away. Naritasan Omotesando wasn’t just a walk — it was a journey through Japan’s cultural memory, one that made our first hours in the country unforgettable.

place_info.title: Nasi Lemak Ikan Sembilang, Lenggeng
place_info.address: Lot2000, Jalan Besar Pekan, 71750 Lenggeng, Negeri Sembilan, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Nasi Lemak Ikan Sembilang, Lenggeng

We stopped at Nasi Lemak Ikan Sembilang, Lenggeng for breakfast as part of our USM Roadtrip 2.0, after camping at a nearby campsite. The warung was already quite crowded, with a steady flow of locals and travellers filling up the seating area.

The setup is simple and practical, with self-service trays of lauk and a menu that focuses on traditional Negeri Sembilan–style dishes.

The nasi lemak here is their signature, accompanied by ikan sembilang (catfish) and various gulai or rendang options. Prices are affordable, starting from RM1 for plain nasi lemak, with add-ons depending on the type of fish or lauk chosen.

In terms of taste, the nasi lemak was good but not particularly outstanding compared to other popular nasi lemak spots we’ve tried. The sambal was moderate in flavour and spice, and while the gulai lauk had the familiar Negeri Sembilan character, it did not stand out as something unique.

What made the visit memorable was more the atmosphere—a busy morning crowd, friendly staff, and the rustic kampung backdrop with a small river running nearby—rather than the food itself.

Overall, it was a satisfying breakfast stop, convenient for travellers in the Lenggeng area, but not necessarily a must-visit destination unless you are already nearby.

place_info.title: D'RAM SALAM THAI
place_info.address: 71750 Lenggeng, Negeri Sembilan, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
During our camping trip at a nearby campsite in Lenggeng, we drove around this small town in search of dinner and stumbled upon D’Ram Salam Thai. It turned out to be a cozy local Thai eatery with a casual, family-friendly atmosphere.

The restaurant has a simple village-style setup, with open-air seating, bright décor, and a homely vibe. Plastic chairs and wooden tables fill the space, while the walls are decorated with colorful food posters and Malaysian flags—adding to its cheerful charm.

We decided to try one of their set meals for four, which included all the typical Thai favorites: tom yum, ikan siakap, kaila ikan masin, kerabu, and more. The portions were generous, and the taste reminded us of authentic Thai street-style cooking—flavorful, hearty, and well-prepared.

Service was straightforward and quick, and the prices were very reasonable for a group meal. After a day outdoors, the hot soups and spicy dishes were exactly what we needed.

Overall, we were satisfied with the experience. It’s not a fancy restaurant, but it offers good food, decent variety, and a local feel that makes it worth a stop if you’re passing through Lenggeng.

place_info.title: Masjid Kuala Dulang
place_info.address: Jln Kampung Peninjau, 71600 Kuala Klawang, Negeri Sembilan, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
A Visit to Masjid Kuala Dulang – Between History, Mystery, and Friendship

During our USM Roadtrip 2.0, three of us — former engineering mates from Universiti Sains Malaysia — decided to take a small detour in Jelebu. What brought us here was not just the nostalgia of our student days on the road, but also the curiosity to see for ourselves the legendary Masjid Kuala Dulang, the oldest mosque in the district, standing quietly in Kampung Kuala Dulang, just two kilometers from Kuala Klawang.

At first glance, the mosque looks like many other kampung mosques — simple, functional, and warmly welcoming. But as soon as we stepped inside, we were reminded that this was no ordinary masjid. This was a place steeped in over 400 years of history, built in the early 1500s by two Minangkabau preachers, Dato’ Nika and Mudim Khatib Raja. Local lore has it that the two mysteriously disappeared not long after the mosque was completed — a story that added a sense of quiet wonder to our visit.

What makes Masjid Kuala Dulang unforgettable is the mystery of the dulang (tray). Imagine this: during the mosque’s construction, every day after Zuhur, the workers would find a dulang full of rice, fish, and vegetables outside the mosque. Enough to feed everyone — even musafir who happened to pass by. Nobody ever knew who prepared the food. And one day, just as suddenly as it appeared, the dulang stopped showing up. This miracle, or mystery, gave the mosque and the kampung their enduring name.

As we walked around, the imam shared that even today, every Thursday night, people still bring offerings of food like pulut kuning and bananas. Some do it as sedekah, others as part of a nazar. The practice, passed down for centuries, continues to tie the community together. Standing there, I felt that this wasn’t just a place of worship — it was a living thread of faith, culture, and tradition.

Self-Reflection

For us three old friends, this stop wasn’t just about heritage tourism. It made us think about continuity. Just like this mosque has been preserved through centuries, our own friendship — forged in the lecture halls and labs of USM — has endured the tests of time. The story of the dulang reminded me of rezeki — that provision will always come, often in ways we least expect. And it also reminded us that the real barakah in life often comes quietly, humbly, and just enough to sustain us and those around us.

Leaving the mosque, we weren’t just ticking off another stop on our roadtrip. We carried with us a piece of Jelebu’s soul — one that spoke of faith, mystery, and the timeless blessing of gathering as friends on a journey.

place_info.title: Teratak Za'ba
place_info.address: Kampung Bukit Kerdas, 72100 Batu Kikir, Negeri Sembilan, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
A Visit to Rumah Za’ba – Rediscovering a Forgotten Giant

Our USM road trip 2.0 through Negeri Sembilan led us, three former college-mates, to a quiet yet historically significant site — Rumah Za’ba in Batu Kikir, Jempol. At first glance, the traditional wooden house stood humbly amidst its village setting, raised on stilts with carved details that spoke of Negeri Sembilan’s heritage. It was not a grand palace or monument, but within its walls lived the legacy of a man who shaped the intellectual foundation of the Malays — Tan Sri Zainal Abidin Ahmad, better known as Za’ba.

Like most Malaysians, we had learned about Za’ba during our school years. His name appeared in history books, his writings briefly quoted, his title of “linguist and reformer” mentioned. Back then, it felt like distant information, something memorized for exams rather than truly understood. But standing in his birthplace, walking on the very floors where he grew up, our perspective shifted.

Inside the house-turned-gallery, we found displays of his writings, manuscripts, and quotes. One of them struck us deeply:

“Bahawasanya jika tiada pelajaran, nescaya tiadalah jalan bagi mereka itu hendak terlepas keluar daripada kepapaan perangai dan kepapaan alat-alat otak.”

(Without education, there is no way for people to escape the poverty of character and the poverty of the mind.)

It was here that Za’ba’s true importance dawned on us. He was not merely a figure in textbooks — he was a reformist who fought ignorance with education, a nationalist who uplifted the Malay spirit, and an intellectual whose grammar reforms laid the foundation for modern Malay language. His struggle was not on the battlefield but in the classroom, in the press, and in the minds of his people.

As we reflected, we realized that men like Za’ba and other nationalists prepared the soil for independence. They gave Malays the intellectual tools, the confidence, and the vision to rise as a nation. Visiting this house made us respect not only Za’ba, but also the countless others who fought — in their own ways — for the freedom we enjoy today.

Leaving Rumah Za’ba, the three of us agreed that this road trip had given us more than sightseeing memories. It gave us a renewed sense of respect for our forefathers, a reminder that education is liberation, and an appreciation for the quiet strength of those who built our nation not with weapons, but with words and wisdom.

place_info.title: WARUNG SIMPLE - Bandar Tun Hussein Onn
place_info.address: Taman Sutera Residences, 1, Jln Sutera 4, Tun Hussein Onn, 43200 Cheras, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Breakfast at Warung Simple, Bandar Tun Hussein Onn

On Saturday, 16 August 2025, I came to Warung Simple in Bandar Tun Hussein Onn with a friend for breakfast — and it turned out to be a morning well spent.

Ambience & First Impressions

From the outside, the bold signage reads “Warung Simple – Simple Tapi Power”. It immediately sets the tone: no frills, no fuss, just good food. The shoplot frontage is neat with banners showcasing tempting menu highlights — from nasi kerabu and nasi simple sets to Thai kitchen specials like tom yam and kerabu kampung.

Inside, the space is open and welcoming. Rows of tables fill the room, making it easy to accommodate families, groups, or even solo diners. The interior is modern-warung style: clean tiles, exposed brick counter, black walls with menu boards glowing above. It feels functional yet cosy — a place where you can sit down, chat, and enjoy your meal without rush.

Ordering & Menu Variety

Ordering here is self-service at the counter. Above, the digital menu boards are bright and clear, showcasing everything from Nasi Kerabu Tumis to Nasi Simple with ayam cincang, ikan keli, kambing grill, or ikan tilapia. Prices are straightforward: most sets between RM8–12, with “special” upgrades just a few ringgit more.

A small side menu lists extras like ayam bakar, daging bakar, or lemak bakar add-ons at RM6 each. Another section highlights Mee Celup and Nasi Air, priced RM8–9, alongside a wide range of drinks — teh, kopi, milo, sirap, bandung, and fresh juices. There’s even a sign proudly announcing “Free Ulam” for nasi kerabu orders, which adds that authentic kampung touch.

What I Ordered

For breakfast, I went with their signature Nasi Kerabu Ayam Bakar (RM10). The portion was big and generous — fragrant bunga telang rice paired with smoky grilled chicken, sambal with fiery heat, crunchy keropok, and fresh ulam. It was colourful, hearty, and very satisfying.

To drink, I had the Teh Ais Mangkuk (RM3.50) — served in a playful pink bucket, cold and refreshing — and a strong Kopi O (RM1.50) that gave just the right caffeine kick.

The bill came to RM15 in total, which is excellent value for the amount and quality of food.

Taste & Experience

Every bite of the nasi kerabu worked beautifully. The ayam bakar had a proper grilled char, smoky and savoury, while the sambal lifted the dish with spice. The rice itself was soft and fragrant, and the ulam kept everything balanced. It felt authentic yet modern, the kind of meal that leaves you satisfied long after.

The drinks also made the experience memorable — the quirky bucket teh ais is not just fun but also Instagram-worthy, while the kopi O stayed true to its traditional boldness.

The whole experience was easy and pleasant: quick service, friendly staff, and a relaxed atmosphere.

Looking Ahead

What impressed me most was the variety on offer. Beyond the nasi kerabu, the Thai kitchen menu looked especially tempting with tom yam udang galah, kerabu kampung crispy, and lala masak pedas. I also want to come back for the Nasi Kerabu Tumis Set, the comforting Mee Celup, and the homely Nasi Air.

Final Thoughts

Warung Simple in Bandar Tun Hussein Onn really delivers on its promise: “Simple Tapi Power.” It may look straightforward, but the flavours, portion sizes, and prices make it a gem for anyone craving hearty Malay food with a twist.

For just RM15, I enjoyed a filling breakfast of nasi kerabu ayam bakar, teh ais mangkuk, and kopi O — tasty, satisfying, and memorable. Next visit, I’ll definitely be exploring more of their Thai kitchen and specialty dishes.

If you’re around Cheras or Bandar Tun Hussein Onn, this spot is worth stopping by. It’s simple, yes — but truly power.

place_info.title: ABM Sate Tulang Jelebu ( Jelebu, Negeri Sembilan )
place_info.address: No.19 Arked MDJ, Jalan Dato Menteri, 71600 Kuala Klawang, Negeri Sembilan, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Sate Pit Stop on Our Pekan–KL Road Trip

Our drive from Pekan back to KL, during our USM Roadtrip 2.0, stretched into the evening, and by the time the clock hit 7 PM, hunger had us scanning for a good dinner stop. That’s when we spotted this sate restaurant—simple, inviting, and perfect for a quick break from the road. To our surprise, it wasn’t too crowded for a Sunday evening. Instead of the usual noisy bustle you’d expect from a popular sate joint, the atmosphere was calm, giving us the chance to unwind after hours of driving.

The first thing on our minds was their signature sate tulang, which we’d heard so much about. Unfortunately, luck wasn’t on our side—it was already sold out. A little disappointing, but not enough to kill the mood. We quickly moved to Plan B: fifteen sticks of chicken sate served with nasi impit, paired with three glasses of hot, frothy kopi tarik. It was simple, straightforward, and exactly the kind of road trip comfort food we needed. The total came to just RM30, which felt fair enough.

When the food arrived, the smoky aroma of grilled chicken filled the air, and one bite was enough to tell us it was a notch above the usual KL sate. The chicken was juicy, slightly charred on the outside, and seasoned well—flavorful without being overpowering. Each stick paired nicely with the peanut sauce, and the nasi impit added that familiar touch of tradition. The kopi tarik, meanwhile, balanced everything out with its strong, slightly sweet kick—an old-school companion for a meal like this.

Price-wise, it wasn’t any cheaper than what you’d pay at most sate outlets in KL, but considering the taste and the cozy stopover vibe, it didn’t feel like a stretch either.

All in all, it was a satisfying pit stop, even though missing out on the famed sate tulang left us a little curious. In a way, it gives us the perfect excuse to come back again—because no road trip is complete without discovering something new to look forward to on the next journey.
