place_info.title: Öz Urfa dinlenme tesisleri
place_info.address: Tuzla mevki, Küçükköy, Bilentur Cd, 10410 Ayvalık/Balıkesir, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
During my drive from Assos to Izmir on 26 June 2025, I had the opportunity to enjoy a memorable late lunch at this restaurant, conveniently situated within a TotalEnergies gas station. While parking directly in front of the restaurant can be a bit limited, I found that parking at the gas station or nearby is easy and only requires a brief walk—quite manageable for travelers on a long journey. We chose to sit in the open-air section, which provided a refreshing and pleasant dining environment.

As someone genuinely interested in discovering the diverse world of Urfa cuisine, I was excited to sample the authentic dishes featured on the menu. My curiosity about regional Turkish food led me to order two of their signature offerings: Kelle Paça Soup and Çöp Şiş Kebab.

I was also hoping to try Ciğer Şiş (Liver Skewers), a celebrated delicacy from Urfa that I have often heard about. While it was not available during my visit, this only increases my anticipation to return and experience it next time.

Kelle Paça Soup (180 TL):
This dish truly stood out as an exceptional introduction to traditional Turkish soups. Made from slow-cooked lamb head and feet, the Kelle Paça Soup arrived steaming hot, with a rich, inviting orange broth topped with aromatic oils and spices. The soup was beautifully balanced—hearty yet not overpowering, with tender morsels of meat adding a satisfying substance. A wedge of lemon was thoughtfully included, allowing me to add a touch of brightness and cut through the richness. Every spoonful reflected the time-honored flavors of Turkish home cooking, and I thoroughly enjoyed its robust, comforting taste.

Çöp Şiş Kebab (400 TL):
Equally impressive was the Çöp Şiş Kebab, which consisted of juicy, perfectly marinated cubes of lamb, expertly grilled and served atop soft flatbread. Accompaniments included a grilled tomato, roasted green pepper, and a crisp onion salad enhanced with sumac and fresh herbs. Although the portion size for both the kebab and the salad was on the smaller side, the flavors were outstanding. The meat was succulent, the flatbread soaked up all the delicious juices, and the freshness of the salad complemented the smokiness of the kebab. It’s clear that great care goes into preparing this dish, and it beautifully showcased the bold, vibrant tastes of Urfa cuisine.

Overall Experience:
The prices were reasonable, especially given the quality, authenticity, and the convenience of the location for travelers. While the cleanliness of the facilities could be further improved, the restaurant was perfectly acceptable for a roadside stop, and the welcoming, relaxed atmosphere added to the experience. Communication was made easy with the help of Google Translate, and I found the staff to be extremely friendly, attentive, and helpful—they made sure all our needs were met and made us feel genuinely welcome.

Summary:
This restaurant is a fantastic choice for anyone eager to explore the flavors of Urfa cuisine while traveling through the region. Both the Kelle Paça Soup and the Çöp Şiş Kebab offered an authentic and satisfying taste of traditional Turkish cooking. Although I was unable to try the famous Ciğer Şiş on this occasion, I look forward to returning and broadening my culinary adventure. With reasonable prices, delicious food, and warm, attentive service, this stop turned out to be a highlight of my journey. I highly recommend it to fellow travelers seeking genuine Turkish hospitality and regional flavors.

place_info.title: Kısmet Balık Evi
place_info.address: Cevat Paşa, İnönü Cd. No:54/A, 17000 Çanakkale Merkez/Çanakkale, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
Our lunch at Kısmet Balık Evi—which charmingly translates to “Fortune Fish House”—was a highlight of our visit to Çanakkale. We came here on Tuesday, 24 June 2025, after receiving a heartfelt recommendation from our hotel staff. There’s an endearing story behind the restaurant’s name: “Kısmet” is not just a nod to good fortune, but also the name of the owner’s fishing boat, hinting at a business built on pride, tradition, and a personal touch.

Atmosphere & Interior

From the moment you step inside, Kısmet Balık Evi surrounds you with a wave of nostalgia and Turkish cultural charm. The walls are filled with large, colorful posters featuring legendary Turkish movie stars and scenes from classic films. Inspirational quotes from Turkish cinema add character, making the place feel like a vibrant tribute to the country’s pop culture.

Every corner and surface is thoughtfully decorated with vintage collectibles—old radios, typewriters, sewing machines, vinyl records, and even a retro turntable. There are hand-painted bottles, dried flowers, and quirky figurines sprinkled throughout, creating a cozy, lived-in atmosphere. The red glass tabletops, plush chair cushions, and wooden furniture contribute to the warmth, while big windows fill the room with natural light and offer a lively view of the street outside. Books and personal memorabilia line the shelves, giving the entire place the inviting feel of a friend’s living room.

Menu & Food

Kısmet Balık Evi’s menu is a feast for seafood lovers, offering everything from the essential Turkish classics to inventive house specialties. A dedicated display showcases the day’s fresh catch, so you know exactly what’s available and how fresh it is.

Menu Highlights:
•   Seafood Classics: You’ll find all the essentials—grilled sea bass (levrek), gilt-head bream (çipura), sardines, anchovies, calamari, shrimp, and crispy fried mussels—each prepared in the traditional Turkish style.
•   Signature Dishes: The restaurant stands out for its creative options like kaşarlı levrek (grilled sea bass with cheese), levrek kavurma (sautéed sea bass), and levrek buğlama (sea bass steamed with vegetables)—distinctive house specials you won’t find everywhere.

Our Selected Meals

Kaşarlı Levrek (Grilled Sea Bass with Cheese):
This dish was a real showstopper. The sea bass was impeccably fresh, expertly grilled to keep the flesh moist and flavorful, then generously topped with melted Turkish cheese. The cheese added a rich, slightly tangy note that paired beautifully with the delicate flavor of the fish—an inventive twist that exceeded our expectations.

Izgara Kılçıksız Sardalya (Grilled Boneless Sardines):
Sardines are a staple along the Aegean coast, and these were among the best we’ve tried. The sardines were meticulously deboned, then grilled to achieve the perfect balance of crisp skin and juicy, tender flesh. Their clean, briny flavor really captured the essence of local seafood, and the presentation made them easy to enjoy, even for those new to sardines.

Mevsim Salata (Seasonal Salad):
The salad was bright, fresh, and full of crisp seasonal vegetables. It provided a refreshing contrast to the savory seafood and rounded out the meal nicely.

Service & Value

We were likely the first customers of the day, and the service was impressively fast and attentive. The staff were welcoming and eager to share their recommendations. While the portions were a bit on the small side, the freshness and quality of the seafood more than made up for it. A few flies were present (as is often the case in fish restaurants) but did not detract from the overall experience.

Total Paid: 1,010 TL—excellent value for such a high-quality, authentic meal in a central location.

place_info.title: Hacı İbrahim Ağa Çeşmesi
place_info.address: Fevzipaşa, 17010 Çanakkale Merkez/Çanakkale, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
A Hidden Gem Discovered by Chance!

I was delighted to stumble upon the Hacı İbrahim Ağa Çeşmesi as I exited the Navy Museum on Tuesday, 24 June 2025, in the afternoon. What a wonderful surprise to find this beautifully restored Ottoman-era fountain right in front of the museum’s administrative building! Even though there isn’t an English sign, its presence is impossible to ignore—a perfect blend of local heritage and elegant architecture.

Rich in Meaning and History

The fountain’s Ottoman Turkish inscription is deeply touching. Its message speaks of overflowing generosity, likening Hacı İbrahim Ağa’s charitable works to the endless sea. It wishes that those who drink from this fountain remember the benefactor in their prayers and expresses gratitude to God for such kindness. I was struck by the poetic spirit and the heartfelt hope that travelers, too, would be blessed by this simple yet profound act of charity.

Who Was Hacı İbrahim Ağa?

Learning more, I discovered that Hacı İbrahim Ağa was a significant figure in Ottoman Çanakkale. He served as the steward to the celebrated admiral Cezayirli Gazi Hasan Pasha and held an important court position. His philanthropy is legendary—he commissioned not just this fountain, but several others throughout the city, many established as charitable endowments. His legacy lives on through these gifts of water and generosity.

Historical and Architectural Beauty

The fountain itself is a marvel: fully constructed from marble, with a rectangular form and a gently arched, shallow niche. Every detail speaks of Ottoman craftsmanship, from the pronounced keystone to the subtle relief decorations—grape clusters, curling branches, tulips, and floral motifs—all elegantly carved. The inscription is artfully set within eight decorative cartouches, and the combination of brass faucet and marble basin adds to the authenticity. This artistry is all the more impressive considering the fountain’s age and the care taken to restore it.

A Testament to Culture and Community

Public fountains like this were once central to daily life, serving both locals and travelers in the pre-modern city. In Islamic tradition, providing water is considered one of the most enduring forms of charity, bringing spiritual rewards long after the benefactor’s lifetime. Today, the Hacı İbrahim Ağa Fountain stands as a protected piece of cultural heritage—admired not only for its design, but for the spirit of giving it represents.

In summary:

The Hacı İbrahim Ağa Çeşmesi is a true historical treasure—small in size but immense in meaning. It’s a powerful symbol of both the generosity and artistic sensibility of the Ottoman era. For anyone interested in Çanakkale’s history, culture, or architecture, I can’t recommend a visit highly enough. Don’t miss this hidden gem!

place_info.title: Yalı Balık & Kumpir Evi
place_info.address: Kemalpaşa, Çarşı Cd. No:2, 17000 Çanakkale Merkez/Çanakkale, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
After visiting the Navy Museum on Tuesday, 24 June 2025, we decided to have an early dinner at Yalı Balık & Kumpir Evi (Waterfront Fish & Baked Potato House), arriving around 4:30 pm. The restaurant is ideally situated right on the waterfront, offering pleasant views and convenient access from many of Çanakkale’s main attractions.

When we arrived, the restaurant was relatively quiet with only a few other diners present. However, despite not being busy, the service was notably slow. We were disappointed to learn that both the cream fish soup and lemonade—two items we had wanted to try—were unavailable that day.

For our meal, we ordered the following:

1. Fried Mussels (Midye Tava) – 380 TL
We ordered the portion (not the sandwich version) of this popular Turkish street food. Mussels are battered and deep-fried, typically served with a tangy garlic sauce on the side. Unfortunately, this dish didn’t live up to our expectations. The mussels were overcooked, resulting in a tough texture and a lackluster flavor that was a letdown compared to similar dishes we’ve enjoyed elsewhere.

2. Sea Bass (Levrek) – 450 TL
Levrek is a classic in Turkish seafood cuisine, generally served whole and grilled, accompanied by a side of fresh salad, greens, and lemon. The sea bass here was outstanding—tender, juicy, and full of fresh flavor. It was definitely the highlight of our meal and showcased the quality of the local seafood.

3. Drinks
We also ordered a cola (60 TL) and a bottle of water (20 TL) to round out our meal.

Total Cost: 700 TL
The overall price was what we expected for a central seafood spot in Çanakkale, especially given the waterfront location.

In summary, our experience included two classic seafood dishes: fried mussels to start, followed by a perfectly grilled sea bass as the main course. While the sea bass exceeded our expectations and made the meal worthwhile, the fried mussels were a disappointment, and the slow service detracted from the overall experience. At one point, we even had to remind the waiter to bring our drinks, which further slowed things down.

That said, if you’re looking for a relaxing meal with waterfront views and you prioritize a delicious main course over appetizers or speedy service, Yalı Balık & Kumpir Evi is worth considering. However, if quick service and flawless starters are important to you, you might want to explore other options.

place_info.title: Cumhuriyet Meydanı - Çanakkale
place_info.address: Kemalpaşa, Cumhuriyet Blv. No:59, 17100 Çanakkale Merkez/Çanakkale, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
We visited Cumhuriyet Meydanı (Republic Square) on Tuesday, 24 June 2025, at around 6 pm, after a short walk from Aynalı Çarşı.

One of the highlights here is seeing one of the rare Atatürk statues created during his lifetime (1933). It’s a powerful symbol of Turkish history and identity. The statue bears two famous inscriptions from Atatürk:
•   “We established the Republic. It is you who will raise and sustain it.”
•   “Peace at home, peace in the world.”

These words are deeply meaningful, reflecting Atatürk’s vision for modern Turkey.

The square also displays impressive Ottoman-era Krupp cannons, a direct link to Çanakkale’s military heritage and its key role in the Gallipoli campaign.

Located right in the heart of downtown, Cumhuriyet Meydanı is an ideal starting point for exploring Çanakkale. It’s just steps away from the ferry terminal, the waterfront, plenty of cafés, and shops.

I also appreciated the recent renovations—modern paving, well-kept green spaces, and new seating make the square much more comfortable and inviting.

From the square, it’s easy to walk to other main attractions, including the waterfront promenade, Aynalı Çarşı, museums, and several other landmarks. Overall, it’s a spot that truly captures the spirit and history of Çanakkale.

images.title: Cumhuriyet Meydanı - Çanakkale
images.snippet:

— K. Atatürk

place_info.title: Mega Beach Çanakkale Kafe
place_info.address: Barbaros, Deniz Sk. No:7, 17020 Çanakkale Merkez/Çanakkale, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
I visited Mega Beach Halk Plajı with my wife around 7 PM on Tuesday, 24 June 2025. The beach is conveniently located just 1.2 km from the city center, though finding a parking spot was difficult—even though parking is free.

Entrance to the beach is also free, and it’s a true public space. However, bringing outside food and drinks isn’t allowed; there’s someone at the entrance checking for this. I spent my time at the busy on-site restaurant, which was full of people, while my wife enjoyed a swim for about an hour.

The beach is Blue Flag certified, meaning the water quality and safety are recognized at an international standard. Sunbeds and umbrellas are available to rent for a fee. The sandy beach itself is about 175 meters long and 25 meters wide, and there are full public amenities—including showers, changing rooms, toilets, a children’s playground, and picnic tables.

The atmosphere was lively and energetic, and the beach was quite crowded during our visit, mostly with children and teenagers. My wife found the sea calm, pleasantly cool, and especially suitable for kids thanks to the shallow shoreline. The children on the beach seemed to enjoy the water the most.

We stayed until sunset and really enjoyed the beautiful views over the Dardanelles Strait. On the downside, some patches of algae were noticeable, and the general cleanliness—while adequate—could be improved. Also, there are lots of sunbeds, which makes open space a bit limited for those not renting one.

Overall, Mega Beach Halk Plajı is a convenient and family-friendly spot, especially if you want a lively local experience close to the city. Just be prepared for crowds, and don’t expect perfect cleanliness.

images.title: Mega Beach Çanakkale Kafe
images.snippet: What I bought in order to stay at the restaurant

response.snippet: Thank you for good thinking. You are always welcome to mega beach.

place_info.title: Lalezar Restaurant
place_info.address: Karaağaç, Lozan Cd. No:6, 22030 Edirne Merkez/Edirne, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
I visited Lalezar Restaurant with my wife on Saturday evening, 21 June 2025. We sat at the covered outdoor dining area, right by the Meriç River, enjoying the beautiful view and relaxing atmosphere. The setting is truly special, especially as the sun begins to set over the water.

We chose this restaurant because of the banners near the entrance, which advertised their specialties. So, we decided to try their most famous dishes. First, we ordered the Edirne Tava Ciğeri (fried liver), which cost 380 TL. The portion was big and perfect for sharing. It was very tasty—crispy on the outside and well-cooked, definitely one of the best versions of this local dish I’ve tried.

Next, we had the Meşhur Edirne Köftesi (famous meatballs) for 360 TL. The meatballs were juicy and flavorful, cooked just right. However, I think there are other restaurants in Edirne that serve even better köfte, but these were still good and enjoyable.

For drinks, I ordered the Özel Lalezar Ayranı, their special thick ayran, for 100 TL. It was rich, creamy, and quite different from the usual watery ayran. It paired nicely with the liver dish and was very refreshing. We also had a mineral water (soda) for 100 TL, which was just what we needed with our meal.

The total cost for our meal was 940 TL, and I paid by credit card. The service was friendly and quite fast, considering how busy the place was. I really liked the riverside setting, which made the whole dining experience more memorable.

Lalezar Restaurant is well-known in Edirne for its riverside location, great views, and classic Turkish food. The restaurant can get quite crowded during weekends or festivals, so coming early or making a reservation might be a good idea. I noticed that some dishes here are a bit more expensive than other places, probably because of the nice view and location. But if you’re looking for a relaxing meal with beautiful scenery, Lalezar is definitely worth a visit.

place_info.title: The largest frying pan of the world
place_info.address: Karaağaç, 22100 Edirne Merkez/Edirne, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
I visited the World’s Largest Frying Pan in Edirne on Saturday afternoon, 21 June 2025, right after exploring Edirne City Forest. I climbed the stairs and walked around the giant pan, which is really impressive up close. There was a display sign explaining that this pan set a Guinness World Record on May 12, 2018, during the International Brass Festival organised by the Edirne Municipality. On that day, they cooked 600 kilograms of fried liver on the pan to break the record. The pan itself weighs 2 tons, stands 80 centimetres high, and has a diameter of 704 centimetres. For the record-breaking event, they used 2,520 litres of sunflower oil, 250 kilograms of flour, 12 tons of wood, and 3 tons of coal.

This pan is not just a display—sometimes it is actually used for special events, especially during the famous Kırkpınar Oil Wrestling Festival, to serve thousands of people. It was first introduced back in 1987 to celebrate Edirne’s food culture, especially the local specialty of fried liver (ciğer tava). The size is really impressive, and seeing it in person made me appreciate how proud the people of Edirne are of their food traditions.

On the positive side, it’s a unique and fun landmark, perfect for photos and a great way to learn about the city’s love for food. However, I noticed there isn’t much information in English about the history or why the pan is important, so it would be better if more details were available for visitors. Still, it’s a memorable and quirky stop in Edirne and worth seeing if you’re interested in local culture or just want a fun photo.

place_info.title: Hacı Adil Bey Çeşmesi
place_info.address: Karaağaç, 22100 Edirne Merkez/Edirne, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
I visited Hacı Adil Bey Çeşmesi with my wife on Saturday afternoon, 21 June 2025, shortly after crossing the Meriç River via the historic stone bridge. This fountain immediately stands out with its authentic late Ottoman design, elegant stonework, and quiet presence amid the daily bustle of Edirne. When we arrived, several horse carts were waiting nearby for customers, giving the scene a lively and traditional local feel.

Learning about the history of the fountain made the visit even more meaningful. Hacı Adil Bey, who served as governor of Edirne during two of its most challenging eras, commissioned this fountain in 1911 in memory of his own son. His son was tragically martyred at a young age by Bulgarian insurgents in the Istranca Mountains while accompanying his father on an official visit to Demirköy. The fountain was built both as a charitable act for the people of Edirne and as a heartfelt tribute to his son’s memory—a true example of enduring sadaqah jariyah.

What makes this fountain especially remarkable are the Qur’anic verses inscribed on each side, reflecting both spiritual depth and artistic heritage. On the eastern face, the verse “We made from water every living thing” is from Surah Al-Anbiya (21:30), emphasizing the foundational role of water in all creation. The southern face features the verse “And their Lord will give them a pure drink” from Surah Al-Insan (76:21), symbolizing the promise of pure reward and blessing. The northern face displays the basmalah, “In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful” (بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم), a phrase that marks the beginning of every significant act in Islam. On the western face, the inscription reads “The best form of charity is to give water”—a teaching from the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) found in various hadith, and the date of construction is given as 1322 AH (1904-1905 CE).

These inscriptions, beautifully carved in Ottoman script, add a spiritual and contemplative dimension, reminding visitors of the importance of charity, remembrance, and community service in Islamic tradition.

On the positive side, the fountain is well preserved, centrally located, and serves as a unique historical and architectural highlight in Edirne. Its presence as a charitable fountain and a place for locals to gather makes it both culturally and spiritually meaningful. However, during my visit, there was no running water at the fountain, and the area was sometimes crowded and noisy due to nearby traffic and horse carts. I also felt that additional information in English would help international visitors appreciate its background and significance.

Overall, Hacı Adil Bey Çeşmesi is a small but moving monument that blends history, faith, and public service. It is a worthwhile stop for anyone who wants to experience not only the architectural heritage of Edirne, but also its enduring spirit of charity and remembrance, all reinforced by the wisdom and guidance of the Qur’an.

place_info.title: Meriç Bridge
place_info.address: Karaağaç, 22100 Edirne Merkez/Edirne, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
I visited the Meriç Bridge with my wife on a Saturday afternoon, 21 June 2025. We parked our rental car for free at Polis Bahçesi Otopark, which was both convenient and close to the bridge itself. From there, we enjoyed a leisurely walk across the bridge, although it was quite busy with constant traffic in both directions. The walkway is very narrow, so we had to be extra cautious whenever vehicles passed by. Despite the crowds, we paused at the central pavilion in the middle of the bridge to appreciate its unique architecture and the tranquil atmosphere it offers.
The Meriç Bridge, also known as Yeni Köprü or the “New Bridge,” stands as one of Edirne’s most iconic Ottoman-era stone bridges. It was completed between 1842 and 1847 during the reign of Sultan Abdülmecid I and features twelve elegant stone arches stretching 263 meters across the Meriç River—a major waterway that forms part of the border between Turkey and Greece. The bridge’s prominent central pavilion was historically used as a rest stop and lookout for travelers. Constructed from ashlar stone, the central arch is notably higher than the others, an architectural solution that helped the bridge withstand floods and allow river navigation, reflecting the advanced engineering of the Ottoman era.
From the middle of the bridge, we enjoyed beautiful panoramic views of the Meriç River, including the marked rowing lanes, and observed several anglers fishing at both ends. The area is particularly popular for photography, especially around sunset when the river and the city are bathed in golden light. Meriç Bridge serves as both a cultural and architectural landmark, connecting the city center to the historic Karaağaç district, which is home to the old train station and Lausanne Monument. Its riverside location makes it a favorite setting for local festivals and public gatherings, and it is often featured in postcards and paintings of Edirne. Locals even refer to the bridge as a “gateway to Europe” because of its strategic position on the route to Greece. During the Ottoman period, the bridge and its surroundings were popular picnic and leisure spots for both citizens and dignitaries, a tradition that continues today.
Another unique aspect of the Meriç Bridge is the natural environment that surrounds it. The riverbanks are habitats for various bird species and turtles, making it an unexpectedly good spot for casual birdwatching in addition to sightseeing.
Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed our walk across this historic bridge and found the experience memorable. The setting is undeniably beautiful and photogenic, the atmosphere vibrant with both locals and tourists, and the structure itself an impressive example of Ottoman civil engineering. I especially recommend visiting in the late afternoon for the best light and fewer crowds. However, future visitors should be aware that the bridge can get crowded, and the walkway is very narrow, so it may not feel entirely safe or peaceful during busy times. Additional signage about the bridge’s history would enhance the visitor experience, and some areas could benefit from more regular maintenance. Despite these minor issues, Meriç Bridge remains one of Edirne’s must-see attractions—rich in history, beauty, and local culture.

place_info.title: Edirne City Forest
place_info.address: 22050, Karaağaç, Lozan Cd., 22100 Edirne Merkez/Edirne, Türkiye

reviews.snippet:
I visited Edirne City Forest (Söğütlük Millet Bahçesi) with my wife on a Saturday afternoon, 21 June 2025, after a leisurely stroll across the historic Meriç Bridge. We entered the park from Lozan Caddesi and quickly found a peaceful picnic spot under the shade. The picnic areas are well maintained and ideal for relaxing with family or friends.
We spent time exploring the walking trails in the southern section forest, surrounded by dense forest—mostly old oaks and pines. The fresh air, cool shade, and natural sounds made it feel worlds away from the busy city. The tranquility here is remarkable, and the forest truly acts as a “green lung” for Edirne, improving air quality and providing much-needed respite during the hot season.
Our visit ended near the prayer building, which was under construction at the time. Afterwards, we continued our walk along the riverside path, heading to Lalezar Restaurant to complete our afternoon.
What stands out about this place:
The park is family-friendly, with playgrounds, picnic zones, barbecue areas, cycling paths, and even a riverside tea garden.

It’s free to enter and well suited for families, couples, or solo visitors seeking nature and peace.

The riverside promenade is particularly scenic, with beautiful views, especially at sunset.

There’s a strong sense of cleanliness and respect here, making it a great place to unwind.

Practical notes:
“Land snorkeling” or wandering off the marked trails is not allowed—visitors must remain on official walking paths to protect the forest ecosystem.

Weekends can get busy, especially at the picnic areas, so arriving earlier is best if you want a good spot.

Interesting facts and local insights:
The forest covers about 30 hectares and is home to native oaks, pines, elms, and diverse wildlife—including birds, turtles, and small mammals.

Historically, this area has been a popular leisure retreat since Ottoman times, used by locals and the royal court alike for picnics and festivities.

The forest is frequently used for family gatherings, especially on weekends and holidays, and is valued for both its ecological and economic importance (estimated at 100 TL recreational value per visitor).

It’s a hub for outdoor activities—walking, cycling, fishing, birdwatching, and group exercises are all common here.

Local schools sometimes use the park for nature education and community events.

The area is also featured in folk stories, with some Edirne residents recalling tales of hunts and celebrations held here in the past.

Overall, Edirne City Forest offers a clean, well-kept, and tranquil setting—perfect for anyone looking to escape city life for a few hours and enjoy the beauty of nature by the river.

place_info.title: Faculty of Dentistry, UKM
place_info.address: Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, Jalan Raja Muda Abdul Aziz, 50300 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I recently received dental care at the Faculty of Dentistry, UKM, and my overall experience was exceptionally positive. As part of a leading public university, this faculty offers one of the most comprehensive, professional, and affordable dental services available in the Klang Valley. It is a highly recommended destination for individuals seeking quality oral healthcare without the high costs associated with private clinics.

Comprehensive & Professional Dental Services

The facility offers a complete range of dental treatments, covering general dentistry, orthodontics (braces), periodontics (gum treatment), endodontics (root canal), oral surgery, prosthodontics (dentures, crowns, bridges), pediatric dentistry, and more — all under one roof. The treatments are handled either by qualified dentists or postgraduate dental specialists, often supported by final-year dental students under close supervision. This academic-clinical structure ensures thorough attention to detail and the use of current dental techniques and technology.

Affordable & Transparent Pricing

One of the most attractive aspects of the UKM Dental Faculty is its highly affordable pricing structure. As a teaching hospital, the fees are significantly lower than private dental clinics, often by as much as 50%–70%, depending on the procedure. Despite the reduced costs, the quality of service remains uncompromised, making it an ideal option for individuals and families, particularly those managing long-term or complex dental issues.

Quality of Care & Expertise

The level of professionalism demonstrated by the faculty's team — including academic staff, specialists, and students — is commendable. Each consultation is carried out meticulously, with a strong emphasis on patient education, accurate diagnosis, and tailored treatment plans. The environment is clean, well-equipped, and adheres to high clinical standards. Patients are made to feel comfortable, informed, and cared for at each stage of their treatment journey.

Waiting Time: The Only Drawback

The only notable drawback in my experience was the lengthy waiting time between the initial assessment and specialist consultation. After the first appointment with a general practitioner, I had to wait over four months — despite follow-ups — before I could see the relevant dental specialist. This is perhaps understandable, given the high demand, limited specialist slots, and the institution’s dual role as both a healthcare provider and a teaching facility.

For non-urgent or long-term treatment plans, the wait is still worth enduring, considering the significant savings and high-quality care provided. However, for urgent dental conditions, patients may need to consider alternative interim solutions while waiting for their specialist appointment.

Final Verdict

In summary, the Faculty of Dentistry, UKM is a top-tier public dental care provider offering exceptional value, comprehensive treatment options, and a high standard of care. While patience is required due to the extended waiting periods, especially for specialist referrals, the benefits in terms of cost savings and clinical excellence make it an outstanding choice for both routine and specialized dental care. I would highly recommend this facility to anyone seeking reliable, affordable, and professional dental services in Malaysia.

place_info.title: Restoran Yasmine Corner
place_info.address: AG-01, Desa, Jalan 16b, Taman Permai Jaya, 68000 Ampang Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Dropped by this restaurant on a Friday night around 8:30 pm after finding out that Joe Seafood was closed. There’s a shawarma place right next door, which is pretty convenient if you want other options. This spot is your standard mamak setup—nothing fancy, just the usual tables and menu.

I ordered the tandoori chicken with cheese naan. Honestly, the taste was just okay, and the portion of chicken was really small—definitely not what I expected. I also got an iced lemon tea, but surprisingly, they couldn’t serve it in a regular cup, only in a big glass.

Service was quite disappointing—not very attentive or helpful. With all that, I don’t think I’ll be coming back. Plenty of other better mamak spots around.

place_info.title: Studio 5
place_info.address: No. 5, 6 & 7, Gerai Statik Jalan Kolam Air Lama, Ampang Jaya, 68000 Ampang, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Dropped by here for a quick solo iftar on Friday evening, which happened to be Arafah Day, before my usual badminton game at Kelab Darul Ehsan (KDE). I noticed about half of the stalls were closed, so choices were quite limited. I randomly picked this stall, hoping for something decent to break my fast.

I went with the char kuey teow for RM9. Honestly, it turned out a bit too salty for my taste, and overall, the flavour was below my expectations—maybe I was hoping for more, but it just didn’t quite deliver. I also had a teh O ais limau for RM3, which was refreshing and pretty standard. Price-wise, it’s about what you’d expect for this area, so nothing out of the ordinary.

After iftar, I managed to perform my Maghrib prayers at the small surau nearby, which was a convenient touch for those looking for a place to pray. All in all, the experience was just okay—not the best char kuey teow I’ve had, but I might come back to try the nasi lemak next time since I’ve heard some good things about it. Maybe I’ll have better luck on my next visit!

place_info.title: Sahara tent Restaurant ( jalan ampang)
place_info.address: B243, Lorong Nibong, Taman U Thant, 50450 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet: A very good Middle Eastern restaurant with mandy and grill speciality. Very spacious and comfortable. Reasonable price. Ample car parking.

details.recommended_dishes: Mandy Chicken, Sahara Roasted Lamb, Beef Chicken and Lamb Kebab, Fattoush Salad, Mix Grill, Kabsa Chicken, Chicken and Lamb Mandy

place_info.title: WARUNG ACAN
place_info.address: NO 1 SEKOLAHA AGAMA LAMA, Jalan Jati, Kampung Melayu Subang, 68000 Ampang, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Visited on a Wednesday evening around 8.30 PM with a group of six colleagues after a badminton session at KDE.

The eatery is situated in a residential area, relatively easy to locate thanks to its proximity to the nearby mosque. The entrance is marked by a large plastic canvas awning, making it visible even from a distance.

Upon arrival, the place gave off a slightly disorganised impression, mainly due to the abundance of items and equipment scattered around. However, this casual setup is typical of many local warungs and adds to its kampung-style charm.

There are two main stalls operating within the same lot:
•   Right-hand stall: Run by a lady offering a selection of dishes including bubur ayam, sup tulang, mee rebus, cucur udang, enoki goreng, pisang goreng, and laksa.
•   Left-hand stall: Serves staple items such as kuey teow goreng, nasi goreng, nasi lemak, and similar dishes.

What I ordered:
•   Kuey Teow Goreng Special – Included shrimps and egg. Taste was average, nothing exceptional but decent for a casual dinner.
•   Sup Tulang – Fairly good, flavourful broth with tender meat.
•   Teh O Ais Limau (served in a bowl) – Unique presentation but the taste was standard.

Pricing was reasonable and comparable to other typical Malay roadside eateries. Service was casual, with orders served fairly promptly despite the crowd.

Overall, it’s a decent spot for a relaxed, post-activity meal with friends. While the food isn’t particularly outstanding, the variety and affordability make it worth considering for future casual outings. I may return to try other menu items.

images.title: WARUNG ACAN
images.snippet: Keow teow sup, order by my friend

place_info.title: Hameed's Nasi Kandar @ Signature 2 Food Court
place_info.address: Kuala Lumpur City Centre, 50088 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I’ve  been coming to Hameed’s Nasi Kandar at the Signature Food Court in KLCC for about 15 years now, and honestly, it’s still one of my regular haunts when I want a quick fix of authentic Malaysian Indian-Muslim food. The place is halal-certified and super convenient if you’re already at KLCC—just head up to Level 2 and you’ll spot their stall among the food court buzz.

I dropped by for brunch with a friend this Tuesday around 10:30 am. Even at that hour, there’s already a steady stream of locals and tourists. The menu sticks close to the classics: nasi kandar, a variety of curries, fried chicken, beef rendang, and some good old Malaysian breakfast staples.

This round, I ordered a cold kopi tarik (RM3.50) and my friend had a hot teh tarik (RM3.50). Both drinks were spot on—kopi tarik was strong, creamy, and really hit the spot, while the teh tarik had that signature frothy top and was just the right balance of tea and sweetness. For food, I went for roti sardin (RM5.50)—crispy on the outside, with a spicy, savoury sardine filling that’s always satisfying, especially if you’re after a quick breakfast bite. We also shared a plate of nasi goreng (RM8.00), which was fragrant, not too oily, and just hearty enough for a late breakfast. Added a side of ayam goreng (RM6.00) which, as always, came out crispy on the outside and juicy inside—proper Malaysian-style fried chicken.

I appreciate that Hameed’s has kept their flavours authentic over the years. The curries and side dishes are usually rich and tasty, and you really get a blend of Indian and Malay influences with every bite. It’s not a fine-dining place by any means—it’s a busy food court with a lot of noise and people coming and going. But for a KLCC location, the environment is decent for a casual meal, and it’s convenient if you’re out shopping or catching up with friends.

That said, the prices are a bit on the high side, especially if you get adventurous and pick seafood—prawns can go up to RM45, so do check the price before you order or you’ll get a shock at the counter. Also, not all items are clearly priced on display, so I always recommend asking first, especially if you’re not familiar with how nasi kandar is charged.

Service is okay but can be a bit rushed during busy times, and the food quality can vary slightly depending on the day. Some days, everything tastes spot on, other days the curries or sides can be a little bland. Still, after so many visits over the years, it’s generally reliable.

If you want the best value, stick to classics like fried chicken or beef rendang and avoid the pricey seafood. Try to come during off-peak hours for a less hectic experience—late morning or mid-afternoon usually works for me.

All in all, Hameed’s at KLCC is a solid spot for a quick, authentic meal in the city centre. The food hits the spot, the drinks are always satisfying, and after 15 years of coming here, I can say it’s stood the test of time. Definitely recommended if you’re in KLCC and craving a real taste of local fare—just watch your wallet if you’re eyeing those prawns! Mamak cut throat.

place_info.title: Restoran Ros Sari @ BTHO
place_info.address: 15, Jalan Suadamai 1/2, Tun Hussein Onn, 43200 Cheras, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Dropped by Ros Sari Restaurant with a friend on a Saturday around noon. Parking wasn’t easy — not many spots nearby, so you might need to park a bit further if it gets busy. When we arrived, it was still quiet, but by 1.00 pm the place was almost full, so timing makes a difference if you want to avoid the crowd.

They’ve got a wide variety of dishes — from ikan bakar to traditional Malay desserts. Quite a good spread if you enjoy local food. There’s also an uncovered outdoor seating area, but we chose to sit inside. The indoor space is clean, shaded, and nicely decorated with a cozy Malay vibe.

One interesting thing to note — the Prime Minister (PMX) actually visited this restaurant on June 23, 2023. It’s clearly a well-known spot.

I had ikan patin masak tempoyak, pucuk paku masak lemak, and gulai kawah daging with white rice. The portion size was reasonable. Taste-wise, I found it average overall. I was told that gulai kawah is one of their signature dishes, but honestly, it wasn’t really to my liking. If you ask me, the gulai kawah at Restoran Gulai Panas Mak Tok is much better in terms of flavour and depth.

The total came to RM20 — a little pricey for a typical nasi campur experience, but to be fair, the price range is clearly displayed. So no surprises when it comes to billing.

Service was okay and the variety is definitely a plus. Cleanliness could be better, especially during the lunch rush — tables and floor could use more frequent touch-ups.

All in all, Ros Sari is a decent spot to explore traditional Malay dishes in a comfortable setting. I’ll probably come back again sometime to try the ikan bakar, which looked really tempting. Worth a visit, especially if you’re curious about places that attract even the country’s top leaders.

details.parking: Corner lot. Near MOH medical center and PETRONAS petrol station

place_info.title: Cili Kampung - Suria KLCC
place_info.address: Lot 432 - 433 & OS401, Kuala Lumpur, 50088 Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
So, a group of five of us showed up around noon on Thursday without a reservation. The place was pretty packed, so we got seated in the outdoor dining area, which turned out to be a nice spot. We ordered a few signature dishes to share.

First up, we had the Masak Lemak Daging Salai (RM45), which is smoky beef in a rich coconut milk gravy with turmeric, lemongrass, and chili. It was good, but the beef could’ve been a little more tender. The flavors, though, were on point, and I loved how creamy and spicy it was. Next, we tried the Asam Pedas Ikan Tenggiri (RM40), which was mackerel in a tangy and spicy tamarind broth with herbs. This one was great! The fish was cooked well, and the balance of sour and spicy was perfect. Definitely one of the highlights of the meal.

We also ordered the Udang Petai Sambal (RM65), which had tiger prawns stir-fried with sambal and petai (stink beans). This one was really spicy—maybe a bit too much for some, but the prawns were cooked just right. The sambal and petai combo was so authentic and packed with bold flavors. Then, there was the Ayam Goreng Cili Kampung (RM40), crispy fried chicken with curry leaves, onions, and chili. It was good—crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside. I just wish the spices had soaked into the chicken a little more, but still, it was a solid fried chicken dish. Lastly, we had the Gulai Nangka Muda dan Pucuk Manis (RM35), which was tender jackfruit and leafy greens in a light coconut curry. This was good, but the jackfruit wasn’t as tender as I expected, so the texture was a little off. The curry itself was delicious, though, and the greens added a nice touch.

Now, a couple of things to keep in mind. If you’re not into spicy food, you might struggle here. Almost everything has a bit of heat, and I guess that’s why they named the place “Cili”! If you like spicy, you’re gonna love it, but if not, maybe let them know to tone it down a bit. The price is also on the expensive side, especially when you consider the portion sizes. The food is good, but I think the prices could be a little more reasonable for what you get. Also, the restaurant was pretty crowded when we went, and they require a deposit for group reservations, which is a bit annoying. It’s not a deal-breaker, but it’s something to think about if you’re planning a big group meal.

Overall, we had a pretty solid experience. The food was delicious with just a few small things that could be improved, like the jackfruit and beef. The vibe is great, and even though it was busy, the staff were friendly and attentive. I’d totally recommend it if you’re craving authentic Malay flavors, just be prepared for the spice and the prices!

place_info.title: Kenny Hills Bistro, Four Seasons KL
place_info.address: G-07 (B), Ground Floor, Shoppes at Four Seasons Place, 145, Jln Ampang, Kuala Lumpur, 50450 Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Visited Kenny Hills Bistro at Four Seasons KL on a Friday at around 11:00 AM with two others. The restaurant was only about half full at the time, offering a calm and unhurried setting. However, due to special reservations for the indoor main dining area, we were seated at the outdoor section. While the outdoor seating was semi-alfresco with tasteful decor, natural light, and potted greenery that created a relaxing atmosphere, it didn’t quite offer the full ambiance or cool comfort of the main indoor dining space.

I ordered the Angus Beef MB3 Ribeye (200g), priced at RM138, cooked medium and paired it with a premium foie gras slice as an add-on. According to the menu, this ribeye is prepared with burnt onion purée, roasted vegetables, and brown beef jus. The portion size was reasonable, and the steak was well-executed with a good sear and balanced seasoning. The foie gras added a rich, indulgent texture and depth of flavour, enhancing the overall experience. To accompany the meal, I had an iced chocolate, which was smooth, not overly sweet, and very refreshing—especially fitting for outdoor dining on a warm day.

Service was polite and attentive without being overbearing. Staff were accommodating even though part of the restaurant was reserved. Overall, the visit was a pleasant one—solid food, calm atmosphere, and professional service. I would consider returning, possibly with a reservation in advance to enjoy the full indoor dining ambiance.

Kenny Hills Bistro offers a refined all-day dining experience that blends European bistro classics with Asian-inspired dishes. Their breakfast menu (available from 8 AM to 6 PM) includes hearty options like the Bistro Big Breakfast, French toast, and gourmet egg dishes such as the Smoked Salmon Eggs Royale and the unique Smoked Haddock Omelette “Arnold Bennett.” For lighter fare, guests can enjoy artisanal sandwiches like the Croque Monsieur, Prawn & Avocado Sandwich, and 4 Cheese Toastie, as well as savoury crêpes and waffles. Vegetarian-friendly options such as Wild Mushrooms & Burrata and Spinach & Mushroom Crêpe are also available.

For lunch and dinner, the bistro features an eclectic mix of Western and Asian mains. Appetizers include sharing plates like Burrata with Kale Pesto and Crab & Prawn Bisque. The menu boasts a diverse range of salads, pastas, risottos, and meats, including premium Wagyu dishes and seafood such as Seared Salmon and Pan-Roasted Sea Bass. Asian selections feature local favourites like Ayam Masak Hitam, Ikan Siakap Bakar, and Tamarind Fish En Papillote. Freshly baked quiches and shepherd’s pie round off the offerings, with vegetarian and gluten-friendly options well-represented throughout. The overall menu highlights quality ingredients, elegant presentation, and a pork-free commitment suitable for a wide audience.

We are deeply honoured and delighted to learn that our offerings and ambience have resonated with you so profoundly. Your refined feedback serves as a testament to our ongoing pursuit of excellence and serves as a source of motivation for our entire team. We eagerly look forward to welcoming you back again soon!

place_info.title: Choizen Capital Advisory Sdn. Bhd.
place_info.address: Oasis Square, E-5-7, No. 2, Jalan PJU 1A/7A, Oasis Ara Damansara, 47301 Petaling Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I visited Choizen Capital Advisory Sdn. Bhd. for a business discussion. The office setup is modest and functional, suitable for a small to mid-sized advisory firm. It features a straightforward layout consisting of a conference room and a visitor meeting room, both enclosed with glass walls that create a transparent and open atmosphere. The remainder of the office consists of cubicles, reflecting a practical working environment.

While not luxurious, the office provides a professional and focused setting, which serves its purpose for meetings and business discussions.

place_info.title: Dapur DD @ Oasis Square Ara Damansara
place_info.address: 2, Jalan PJU 1A/7, Ara Damansara, 47301 Petaling Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Visited on a quiet Wednesday around 4:30 PM. The place was not crowded, offering a calm and relaxed atmosphere for a late afternoon meal.

Dapur DD mainly serves nasi campur and traditional Malaysian dishes. While the peak lunch hours had passed, there were still some decent food options available. For tea, we ordered mee kari, mee sup, iced lemon tea, and kopi O ais.

The mee kari and mee sup were average in flavour but came in large, satisfying portions. The iced lemon tea was the standout — refreshing and well-prepared. The kopi O ais was acceptable, though not exceptional.

By the time we finished eating around 5:45 PM, the staff were already beginning to prepare for closing (around 6:00 PM), so this is something to keep in mind for late visitors.

The dining environment is clean and casual, and service was polite and efficient. Note that it’s cash-only at the time of writing, so plan accordingly.

Overall, a decent spot for homestyle Malaysian food if you’re in the area — simple, filling, and reasonably priced.

place_info.title: Mee Hiris China Muslim @ Datum Jelatek
place_info.address: Jln Jelatek, Taman Keramat, 54200 Kuala Lumpur, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Dropped by Mee Hiris China Muslim @ Datum Jelatek for lunch today (Tuesday), and it turned out to be more than just a meal — it was a quiet, meaningful experience filled with nostalgia.

The two of us ordered Set B (CS06), which came with cumin stir-fried mutton, stir-fried cabbage with mushrooms, seaweed & egg soup, mee tarik soups (two bowls), Babao tea, and a Pepsi — all for RM89.70, with a total of RM104.05 all inclusive. For the generous portions and authentic taste, it felt like great value.

The food didn’t disappoint. The cumin mutton was full of aroma and flavour — soft and well-marinated. The cabbage and mushroom were nicely balanced, not oily, and comforting. The seaweed & egg soup was warm and light. We chose mee tarik soup — fresh, chewy, hand-cut. What made it even more impressive was being able to see the noodle-making process through the glass kitchen window — from kneading the dough to slicing it directly into boiling water. Real craftsmanship.

We also appreciated the calm environment. There are outdoor dining tables, but we chose to sit inside where it was cooler and more comfortable. The place wasn’t busy — not many customers, so the whole lunch felt peaceful and unhurried. The staff were polite and friendly, and service was efficient and pleasant throughout.

But beyond the food, this visit meant something personal. This area used to be DBKL low-cost flats back in the day. The two of us first met in late 1992 during my internship at Texas Instruments, just nearby. Now, over 30 years later, we’re here sharing lunch, and my former colleague will retire in two weeks at age 60. That made the moment even more special — seeing how much the place has changed while reflecting on how far we’ve come.

All in all, Mee Hiris offers more than just a meal. It’s a place that connects heritage, culture, and memory — through warm food and quiet comfort.

place_info.title: Datum Jelatek Shopping Centre
place_info.address: P1, Datum Jelatek, Jln Jelatek, Taman Keramat, 54200 Wilayah Persekutuan, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Feels like a quiet start to something bigger — with a touch of nostalgia.
This was my first time visiting Datum Jelatek, and I have to say—it brought back some memories. I remember when this area used to be low-cost flats. Seeing how much it’s changed feels a bit surreal. There’s something nostalgic about walking through a place you once knew, now completely transformed.

The mall itself is modern and clean. It’s connected directly to the Jelatek LRT station, which makes it really easy to get to. I drove, and parking was okay—not too bad, though I can imagine it getting tight during busy times.

Inside, it’s quite spacious and calm. I liked how quiet it was, but I also noticed that many of the shoplots are still empty. A few big names are already open—KFC, Burger King, Mr. DIY, Guardian, and some nice coffee spots like Gigi Coffee and Richiamo. So if you’re here for a quick bite, a relaxing coffee, or a simple errand, it works.

But it does feel like it’s still finding its identity. It doesn’t have that energetic mall vibe yet. Astrum is under construction nearby, so it looks like the whole area is in the middle of growing into something new.

Overall, I’m glad I came. It’s not a place I’d go out of my way for just yet, but it’s peaceful, accessible, and has potential. For me, the mix of the new and old made the visit a bit more meaningful.

place_info.title: Baker's Cottage Bandar Tun Hussein Onn
place_info.address: 9, Jalan Suadamai 1/3, Tun Hussein Onn, 43200 Cheras, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I come here pretty often, mainly for their whole roasted chicken. It’s only RM16.99, which is a real bargain these days. You can choose between BBQ (my go-to – really tasty and smoky) and Black Pepper (a bit spicier). The chicken is always juicy, full of flavour, and totally worth it.

I’ve also tried their potato roll – not bad, just average. And the jumbo chicken frankfurter is pretty decent if you’re in the mood for something quick and filling.

The place is clean and neatly arranged, and though it’s mostly for takeaway, there’s a small area where you can sit and eat if you want. The staff are friendly and helpful, which makes the whole experience pleasant.

They’ve got lots of choices too – cakes, tarts, buns, even some good combo deals that mix chicken with desserts. Great if you’re picking up something for a small gathering or just want variety.

Only downside? Parking can be a bit of a pain, especially during peak times. But if you manage to find a spot, it’s a smooth and quick stop.

place_info.title: House of Patin Lipis di KL
place_info.address: No 5 , Jalan Liew Weng Chee, Off, Jalan Yap Kwan Seng, 50450 Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
A hidden bungalow converted to an authentic Pahang dishes restaurant particularly for the tempoyak patin.

From the menu, the three of us have a few sets that you can easily choose with a pre-determined price. We ordered Set Family Patin for 4-6 pax (RM127.50), consists of:
Patin Gulai Tempoyak, 1 whole big fish
Fried ayam kampung, 4 pieces
Omelette, 4 pieces
Mixed vegetables, 2 sets
Ulam sambal tempoyak, 1 set
Steamed rice, 1 big bowl
Then we added masak lemak daging salai (RM15). For drinks, we ordered air masak, which is available free flow.

The whole food that we ordered was tasty and superb, particularly for the fresh tempoyak patin. Not smelly for freshwater fish. The portion size is big, the meat is tender and the gravy was not too spicy. The ayam kampung was tender and crispy. We reckoned that the food we ordered was for at least five people. Really big portions.

This restaurant has three private dining rooms and ample tables. There is an outdoor section available. There is an area to wash your hands and washrooms.

Their services are efficient and fast. The checkout and payment were super smooth.

The only setback is the parking. especially during peak lunch hours. The restaurant only has very limited parking spaces within the compound. Alternatively, park your car along the narrow roadside.

details.recommended_dishes: Patin Masak Tempoyak with White Rice, Ayam Goreng Kampung, Daging Salai Masak Lemak Cili API

place_info.title: AQUA Restaurant & Grill Bar
place_info.address: Kuala Lumpur City Centre, 50088 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Dropped by AQUA with a friend on a quiet Tuesday evening around 6 PM. The place was super chill — not crowded at all, which made it a nice escape from the city noise. It’s an open-air restaurant on the 3rd floor, right by the pool at Mandarin Oriental KL, with a view of KLCC Park. You get this cool breeze and a peaceful vibe — felt like we were on a mini retreat in the middle of KL.

We shared the Assorted Mixed Satay — it came with a mix of lamb, beef, and chicken skewers. Everything was well-marinated and grilled just right. It was served with a peanut sauce, nasi impit (compressed rice), cucumber, and onions. A solid pick if you’re craving local flavours done well.

For dessert, we went for the Malaysian Style Pisang Goreng. It’s not your usual street version — this one had golden, crispy banana fritters with a scoop of housemade ice cream. We chose the Gula Melaka flavour, which paired perfectly with the warm fritters. A nice mix of crunchy and creamy, with that sweet local touch.

Service was friendly and on point. The staff gave us space but were attentive when we needed anything. Price-wise, it’s on the premium end (as expected for a 5-star hotel in KLCC), but the quality, service, and setting made it worth it for us.

If you’re looking for a laid-back spot with a bit of class — whether for a light dinner, snacks, or just to enjoy the KL skyline from a quieter angle — AQUA is a pretty solid pick.

response.snippet:
Dear Azmi Mahamad

Thank you for sharing this generous review with us.  We are glad that you enjoyed the overall dining experience at AQUA Restaurant & Bar.  It is very rewarding to know how much our guests enjoyed themselves.

Our team will be thrilled to know that you were impressed with the food, the legendary service we strive to provide and the relaxing ambience.

We truly appreciate your kind words and recommendation of AQUA.  We look forward to welcoming you back for another relaxing evening soon.

Kind regards
Jaime Wolynski
Director of Food & Beverage

place_info.title: ORCHID Restaurant
place_info.address: 4, Lorong Yap Kwan Seng, Kampung Baru, 50450 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Came across ORCHID Restaurant while walking along Lorong Yap Kwan Seng and both of us decided to give it a try for lunch on a quiet Thursday. Not many people around, which made it a calm and relaxing place to sit and eat.

Parking wasn’t ideal — we had to park at the hotel across the road. But once inside, the experience improved. The restaurant has both a covered open-air section and a comfortable air-conditioned dining area. We chose to sit in the air conditioned area — cool, clean, and cosy.

ORCHID is a well-known spot for Middle Eastern food, serving a mix of Arabic, Turkish, and Yemeni dishes. The menu is huge and offers something for everyone. Some highlights include Grilled meats like Shish Tawook, Lamb Kebab, and Mixed Grills; Rice dishes such as Mandi, Kabsa, and Biryani (with chicken or lamb); Starters like Hummus, Baba Ghanoush, Falafel, and grape leaves; Yemeni comfort food like Fahsa, Salona, and Molokhia; Turkish-style Pide — especially the cheesy lamb one; Desserts like Kunafa and Baklava; Drinks including fresh juices, smoothies, and mocktails

What we ordered:
a. Hummus with Lamb (RM25) – Absolutely delicious. The lamb was tender and flavorful, and the hummus was smooth and rich. Served with warm, super-soft bread. Easily the highlight of our meal.
b. Tabboulah (RM20) – Fresh, light, and zesty. Not the best we’ve had, but a refreshing side.
c. Mandy Lamb (RM39) – Big portion of fragrant rice and tender, well-spiced lamb. Really satisfying and great value.
d. Tea in a pot – Served hot in a traditional teapot. A simple but perfect finish to the meal.

Generous portions, fair prices, and fast, friendly service. Definitely planning to come again!

place_info.title: The Mollys Kitchen @ Plaza Pekeliling
place_info.address: 2, Jln Tun Razak, Sentul, 50400 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I stopped by The Mollys Kitchen while waiting for my scooter to be serviced nearby. It’s located in Plaza Pekeliling, Sentul Selatan, inside an open yet covered section of the building complex.

The dining area is simple and functional—nothing fancy—but it’s fairly comfortable to sit and eat. That said, the complex itself is quite rundown and could really use some maintenance and a bit of a facelift. Still, the atmosphere was relaxed and not too crowded when I was there.

What really caught my attention was how early the food was ready. I arrived around 9:00 a.m. on a Wednesday morning, and many of the lunch dishes were already prepped and available. That’s definitely a plus for early risers or those in a rush.

I ordered the Nasi Kerabu set, which came with both crispy fried chicken and a piece of fried fish, along with a glass of iced tea. At RM14, I felt the price was reasonable given the portion and variety. The taste? Better than average. The standout was the fried chicken—crispy on the outside, juicy inside, and well-seasoned. The fish was okay too, just not as memorable. The nasi kerabu itself had the essential herbs and sides, although it could’ve used a bit more punch in flavour for my liking.

I paid using my e-wallet with no issues, so payment was smooth and quick.

All in all, The Mollys Kitchen isn’t a fancy or modern place, but for a casual local meal—especially early in the day—it delivers pretty good value. I’d come back if I’m in the area again, especially when I need a quick, no-fuss bite.

place_info.title: Pokok KLCC Lot 91
place_info.address: LOT C-08, LEVEL CONCOURSE, PERMATA SAPURA, Kuala Lumpur, 50088 Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Had an appointment at Menara UOA and decided to call up three friends for a spontaneous lunch catch-up—two of them working nearby at different companies in Permata Sapura.

We walked over to Pokok KLCC, which turned out to be a perfect choice given its location and setting. We arrived around 12:30 pm on a Tuesday, and there were still plenty of tables available.

The ambiance was calm with a clean, minimalist interior and well-spaced seating that gave us a comfortable and relaxing dining experience.

We ordered a mix of their café favourites, and everything was delicious. The Beef Burger (two portions) came juicy and cooked medium just as requested, stacked with cheese, caramelised onions, and salad in a soft brioche bun—really satisfying and flavour-packed.

The Seafood Basket with calamari, prawns, and perch fish was crispy outside and tender inside, great for sharing.

We also had two servings of the Fish & Chips, which had generous portions of flaky white fish in crunchy batter, served with fries and tartar sauce.

The Pineapple Juice was a refreshing tropical touch, and drinking water helped keep the flavours balanced.

What really stood out was the service—the staff were friendly and even checked in during the meal, which reminded me of overseas dining standards.

For a café situated in the KLCC area, prices were quite reasonable and the overall experience exceeded expectations. Pokok KLCC is one of several branches under the Pokok brand, known for combining Malaysian flavours with Western café classics in nature-inspired spaces. This KLCC outlet maintains that same charm, making it a great lunch spot whether you’re working nearby or just visiting the city. Will definitely return.

response.snippet: Thank you so much for your review Azmi! We hope to serve you again soon.

place_info.title: MUSA NASI KANDAR ALAM DAMAI
place_info.address: NO.19 (GROUND FLOOR, Jalan Damai Niaga 1, Alam Damai, 56000 CHERAS, Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Dropped by Musa Nasi Kandar around 9.30pm on a chill Monday night with my neighbour for a bit of supper. First time trying this place — not bad at all!

This place quite well-known in KL nowadays. They’ve got a few branches, and we went to the Alam Damai, Cheras outlet. Heard their Taman Shamelin Perkasa branch also quite famous — maybe will check that out next time.

For this visit, I ordered sup mamak, roti canai banjir, and a glass of teh tarik. The soup was seriously kaw — thick and flavourful, just how I like it. Had it with plain white bread, syok gila.

The roti canai also sedap, crispy outside, lembut inside, and the kari ayam pekat really kena. Not watery like some other places.

And the teh tarik? Fuhhh, creamy and not too sweet — can tell they really take pride in that one. Probably one of the better teh tariks I’ve had in a while.

Parking senang, banyak space. Staff all friendly and fast service. The place is super clean, lighting pun nice — really tak rasa macam typical mamak. More organized, got style.

InsyaAllah, next round I plan to try their actual nasi kandar — especially the fish head curry and their ayam bawang, which I heard are their specialty. That one must come with extra kuah campur!

Definitely will come again. Chill place, good food, and not your average nasi kandar spot. Worth the visit!

place_info.title: Nasi Kandar Haji Sultan @ Ampang Point
place_info.address: Lot 1243, Unit B, Jln Ulu Klang, Kampung Berembang, 55000 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Dropped by Nasi Kandar Haji Sultan Ulu Klang for lunch on a Monday around 12.30 pm. Came in a group of three — one of us sent the car to the wash next door (super convenient), and we decided to makan here while waiting.

Not too crowded at that time, so we had a smooth experience. Classic Nasi Kandar setup — line up, pick your rice and lauk, then drinks and payment at the end.

We ordered:
1) Nasi briyani with ayam bawang and perut kambing – ayam bawang is juicy, garlic-rich, full of flavour; perut kambing was tender and not overly strong.
2) Nasi briyani with ayam goreng and perut kambing – ayam goreng was crispy outside, well-marinated inside.
3) Nasi goreng kampung mamak – spicy, smoky, with sambal, anchovies, and egg. Comfort food at its best.

Drinks: mango juice, teh O ais limau, teh ais – just the usual, all okay.

What impressed us:
1) Flavour – curries are bold and rich, really capture that northern Alor Setar-style taste.
2) Cleanliness – super tidy place with a comfy air-conditioned section.
3) Service – staff were fast and friendly, well above average Nasi Kandar standards.
4) Price – very reasonable for portion and quality.

For those curious about the menu, there’s a wide range:
•   Rice: nasi briyani, nasi kuning
•   Proteins: ayam bawang, ayam goreng, kambing seketul, perut kambing, lamb shank, ikan, sotong, udang
•   Sides: telur, papadam, sayur goreng, kentang, peria
•   Prices range depending on your choices.

This chain is known for its Alor Setar-style nasi kandar and has outlets in Subang, Shah Alam, Kajang, and here in Ulu Klang. First time trying, and honestly — would come back. Tasty food, clean place, good service.

Tip: Wash your car next door and enjoy a good plate while waiting!

place_info.title: Surau Ar-Raudah, Desa Damai
place_info.address: TAMAN DESA DAMAI PERSIARAN ALAM DAMAI Cheras, Alam Damai, 56000 Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I stopped by Surau Ar-Raudah one Sunday evening for a quick Maghrib prayer, while on my way to another appointment nearby. Tucked within the peaceful residential enclave of Taman Desa Damai, this surau sits quietly within a gated community. Thankfully, there was no guard at the entrance when I arrived, and it was already getting dark — but the environment felt safe and serene.

The surau itself is relatively small, but I would say it is perfectly sized for the surrounding community. It’s so convenient to have a surau within walking distance from the houses — truly a blessing for residents who want to perform their prayers in jamaah without having to travel far. This convenience naturally fosters a close-knit Muslim community, and I could sense that this surau plays a strong role in maintaining that spiritual bond.

Facilities-wise, the surau is clean and well-kept. The prayer hall was tidy, with working fans to keep the space cool. The wuduk area on the north side was clean, with good water pressure. Even more interesting — there’s a small set of weightlifting equipment available, showing how the surau cares for the physical well-being of its regulars too. Outside, a lovely marble sitting area invites quiet chats and moments of reflection after prayer — a thoughtful addition for community bonding or casual tazkirah sessions.

The Maghrib prayer was led by a young imam, whose Qur’an recitation was calm, clear, and beautifully paced. It’s truly refreshing to see the surau led by the younger generation, full of energy and good akhlaq. The wirid after the prayer was brief and to the point — simple and effective. About 10 makmum were present that evening, creating an atmosphere that was both intimate and peaceful.

I also noticed signs of active volunteerism — from the way the surau is maintained to the subtle touches that show care and planning. It reflects a strong commitment from the committee and residents to keep this space meaningful and alive.

Of course, no place is perfect. A few minor things to note: the surau may face space constraints during larger events like Ramadan or community gatherings — a common challenge for smaller facilities. And parking may be tricky, especially for non-residents or during peak hours, as the layout within the gated neighborhood is quite limited and not clearly marked for visitors.

But those are small matters in the bigger picture. Surau Ar-Raudah stands as a serene, well-loved, and purpose-driven place of worship — inclusive for both young and old, spiritually nurturing, and well-integrated into the heartbeat of the neighborhood.

Syabas and jazakumullahu khayran to the surau committee and all volunteers for their dedication. May this surau continue to flourish as a beacon of light and unity in Taman Desa Damai.

place_info.title: Surau Jumaat As-Sobirin, Damai Rasa, Alam Damai
place_info.address: 4, Jalan Damai Rasa 18, Alam Damai, 56000 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
A new small surau in Damai Rasa, Alam Damai.

A compact multilevelled designed surau utilising a slope at the end Alam Damai Park.

Top floor is an open car park mainly for the penceramah, imam and other surau officials.

Then the main prayer hall floor.

The lower floor is for galley and other utilities including ablution area.

The surau is equipped with advanced audiovisual facilities.

The surau is organised and clean. Kudos to the management.
