place_info.title: Restoran Salam Tiara (Alam Damai)
place_info.address: 106, Jln Damai Raya 2, Alam Damai, 56000 Cheras, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
We dropped by Restoran Salam Tiara just after 2.00 pm on a quiet Sunday afternoon. Surprisingly, we were the only customers there at the time — a little odd given the quality of food we were about to experience. Located in the Damai Raya commercial area, it’s just around the corner from the always-busy Nasi Kandar Husein.

But if you’re in the mood for something a little more traditional and uniquely Nusantara, this spot is worth the detour.

The menu carries a strong identity: Masakan Tradisional Indonesia & Malaysia — and it truly delivers. Think bold spices, authentic presentations, hearty portions, and comforting textures. It’s the kind of food that brings back memories of kampung kitchens and family gatherings.

We tried three main dishes:
•   Set Talapia Goreng: Crispy, nicely seasoned, and paired with fragrant rice, ulam, and sambal belacan. The portion was just right, though not overly large.
Verdict: Slightly above average — honest and homey.
•   Set Bawal Bakar: This was our favourite. The grilled pomfret was deliciously smoky and tender, but we did wish the fish was a bit bigger.
Verdict: Very delicious — just give us a larger fish and we’re sold!
•   Sate Ayam Maranggi: Impressive. Big, juicy chicken skewers (10 sticks!) marinated in a savoury-sweet Javanese-style blend. Served sizzling hot.
Verdict: Tasty, satisfying, and worth a try — though RM22 feels slightly premium.

For drinks:
•   Happy Soda: Creamy, fizzy, nostalgic — a sweet treat that cools down the spice beautifully.
Verdict: Superb.
•   Orange Juice: Fresh and pulpy, a refreshing companion to balance the richness of the meal.
Verdict: Above average.

The total came to RM68 for two — pretty reasonable for full meals and drinks. Just a heads-up: cash only, so plan ahead.

Service was friendly and efficient, and the ambiance was simple but clean — ideal for a casual lunch. Parking is hassle-free, which is always a plus in KL.

Salam Tiara is a hidden gem for lovers of authentic Indonesian-Malay cuisine. The flavours are spot on, the food is honest, and the satay alone is enough to bring us back. With just a few small improvements (like fish size and digital payment), this place has the potential to become a local favourite.

Recommended for fans of grilled fish, satay lovers, and anyone chasing nostalgic flavours in a quiet, no-fuss setting.

place_info.title: MR.DIY
place_info.address: NO.39 (GROUND, FIRST & SECOND FLOOR, Jalan Angsana 1, Taman Bukit Angsana, 43200 Cheras, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I dropped by this MR.DIY store around 8:00 PM on a Saturday night. There are actually more than five MR.DIY outlets within 5 km of my house, so it’s pretty easy to find one nearby. This particular branch is quite new — it’s the 1,211th store and was opened less than a year ago.

The store is located at a corner lot and spans three floors, which gives it a spacious feel. There’s a sign at the entrance showing their opening hours: 10:00 AM to 10:00 PM every day, including weekends.

First Impressions

The store looked clean, well-organized, and tidy. I appreciated how the items were neatly arranged, making it easy to browse. The staff were friendly and helpful, which made the visit more pleasant.

What I Liked:

Affordable Prices: As expected from MR.DIY’s “Always Low Prices” motto, the prices here are very budget-friendly. It’s great for families or anyone looking to save a bit while shopping for daily essentials.

Plenty of Choices: There are over 17,000 items to choose from — everything from household tools and appliances to toys, toiletries, and seasonal decorations. It’s convenient when you want to grab multiple things in one stop.

Nice Shopping Experience: The store is spacious and comfortable to walk around in. It didn’t feel crowded or messy, which is always a plus.

Some Things to Keep in Mind

Product Quality: The low prices are great, but some items — especially electronics and tools — might not last very long. They’re fine for light or occasional use, but I wouldn’t expect them to handle heavy-duty tasks.

Customer Service Varies: I had a good experience with the staff at this branch, but I’ve heard that the level of service can differ at other locations.

Returns and Exchanges: From what I know, their return and exchange policy can be quite strict, especially if there’s an issue with a faulty product.

Cleanliness in Other Stores: While this outlet was clean and organized, I’ve seen or heard about other MR.DIY branches being a bit messy or cluttered.

What I Bought

I went for MR.DIY’s own-brand products because they were cheaper. I wasn’t expecting top-tier quality, but they work fine for simple DIY tasks and everyday use. For the price, I think they’re worth it.

All in all, this MR.DIY branch is just what you’d expect — affordable, well-stocked, and convenient. While there are some areas that could be improved, like product durability and consistency in service, I’d still recommend it for anyone looking to pick up basic household items without breaking the bank.

place_info.title: Just Sear @ M Suites
place_info.address: G03-R3 M Suites, 283, Jln Ampang, 50450 Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Located in M suites, between Great Eastern mall and Menara PERKESO on Jalan Ampang. From the main entrance, walk to left side and follow the concrete road until you find the restaurant facing the new Setiawangsa-Pantai highway.

The restaurant is double storey, with added mezzanine floor. You can take seat either on the ground floor (same level) as the counter or take the stairs to the mezzanine floor with bigger sitting area. A surau is located on the mezzanine floor.

Tips: If you order Tomahawk, you have to wait for approximately one hour so that they could defrost the meat. So, better call first to make the order. The rest of the items in the menu will take 10-15 minutes to be prepared.

We ordered Wagyu MB9 Tomahawk. While waiting the tomahawk to be ready, we order wagyu satay and pizza.

The price is reasonable for Central Business District.

The staff are friendly and helpful.

Apparently the owner used the facilities as central kitchen successfully.

My first time here.

images.title: Just Sear @ M Suites
images.snippet: Steaks and wagyu from the menu

place_info.title: RESTORAN JOE SEAFOOD @ Taman Ampang
place_info.address: 18, jalan 13b, Taman ampang, 68000 Ampang Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
I first discovered this restaurant through a good friend who lives in Kampung Melayu Ampang. Since then, it has become a regular dinner destination—especially after our weekday badminton games at KDE. It offers a truly local, no-frills dining experience that’s increasingly rare to find in the Klang Valley.

The restaurant occupies two shop lots and provides a surprisingly large seating area, with additional tables set up under canopies in the front parking space. However, it can get busy, and waiting times may vary depending on the day. Parking can be difficult, and on some evenings, we’ve had to park quite far and walk in. Still, the food always justifies the effort.

The setup is unique. At the entrance, there are two open cooking stations: one for grilled items (including their soft, fluffy steamed bread), and the other for boiled and steamed dishes like mee celup. The main kitchen inside handles the rest of the menu.

The staff here are consistently friendly and helpful, and they speak Malay with a distinctive Pattani accent—a pleasant and welcoming touch that adds to the charm of the place.

Their menu is wide-ranging. You’ll find:
•   Kerabu: Thai-style spicy salads (mango, beef tripe, anchovies, cockles, and more)
•   Vegetables: Stir-fried greens, broccolini, tofu, bean sprouts, and “Sayur Joe”
•   Noodles: Fried, soup-based, Ladna, Bandung, Wantan, and Kungfu-style
•   Sup: Including Sup Tulang and Sup Ekor
•   Nasi Goreng: Plain, USA-style, Paprik, Pattaya, Kampung
•   Tripe dishes: Served padprik, curry-style, fried, or as kerabu perut
•   Celup dishes: Like mini steamboats (chicken, beef, intestines, lungs, young tripe)
•   Fresh fruit juices and a good range of classic drinks

Out of the many dishes I’ve tried, these four remain my favourites:
1.	Daging Salai Harimau Menangis – Beautifully grilled and smoky with a soft, tender texture. The cut used is brisket or tenderloin, said to be so desirable that even a tiger (harimau) would weep. Served with a tangy Thai-style nam jim jaew sauce—truly satisfying.
2.	Sup Perut Muda – Comforting and rich in flavour. A great pick after physical activity; it warms the body and fills the soul.
3.	Kerang Rebus – Fresh, firm cockles boiled to perfection and served with a zesty dipping sauce. A classic done right.
4.	Otak Otak – A delightful East Coast treat, served hot at the table. These grilled fish parcels wrapped in banana leaves are aromatic and flavourful—a rare find around here.

Portion sizes are generous, and prices are reasonable for the quality and freshness. The only downside for me was the Thai Teh Ais, which at RM5 felt a little expensive for what is essentially iced tea—although the taste was still enjoyable, especially if you’re a fan of Thai tea.

All in all, this place is a gem. Whether you’re local or just passing through Ampang Jaya, it’s well worth the visit. The food is excellent, the service warm, and the overall experience consistently enjoyable—even if you have to walk a bit from where you park. I’ll definitely be back.

images.title: RESTORAN JOE SEAFOOD @ Taman Ampang
images.snippet: Sup Perut Muda is one of their specialties

place_info.title: Makan Kitchen @ DoubleTree
place_info.address: 348, Jln Tun Razak, Kampung Datuk Keramat, 50400 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
After attending a half-day industry forum on Level 10 of the Intermark building, I made my way upstairs — just one floor up — to Makan Kitchen at DoubleTree by Hilton Kuala Lumpur. The lunch buffet was included as part of the forum package, and I arrived around 1:00 PM, right in the middle of the lunch hour. Despite the bustling time, the entire experience remained pleasant, well-organised, and satisfying.

Makan Kitchen is DoubleTree’s signature restaurant, formerly known as Crown Princess, and it’s well-known for serving authentic Malaysian flavours through its interactive live kitchens. The space is beautifully arranged, with show stations representing local cuisines including Malay, Chinese and Indian — each offering their own distinctive aroma, preparation style, and taste. It’s a great place to not just eat, but also to observe culinary craftsmanship in action.

Before diving in, I planned my buffet approach strategically so I could enjoy the variety without feeling stuffed too early:
•   I started light with soups and fresh salads.
•   Then moved on to sample small portions from each kitchen — tandoori chicken and naan from the Indian station, herb roast duck from the Chinese counter, and a variety of Malay kerabu salads, which were especially refreshing.
•   I made sure to leave space for desserts — their durian tarts and assortment of traditional kuih lived up to the hype.

I also requested to be seated near the Chinese kitchen, just to enjoy the view of the live wok station. Watching the chefs cook fresh dishes added a nice touch of energy and authenticity to the whole experience.

What I Really Liked:

1. The Variety Was Excellent
The spread was diverse — from grilled meats and aromatic curries to delicate Chinese dim sum and hearty Malay dishes. The representation of Malaysian heritage was not only comprehensive but also executed with great attention to flavour and presentation.

2. Comfortable Seating & Calm Ambience
Despite being mid-service, there was ample seating and good spacing between tables. Whether you’re a solo diner or part of a group, it’s easy to find a spot. The soft background music and attentive service staff added to the overall relaxing vibe.

3. Smooth Flow & Cleanliness
I found the layout intuitive and easy to navigate, with clear signage and a logical station arrangement. Used plates were cleared quickly, and staff were available to offer guidance or take drink orders. Everything felt efficient and professional.

4. Friendly Service
I appreciated how the staff remained warm and responsive throughout. One of them even suggested pairing a certain curry with a type of naan — a small gesture that really stood out.

What Could Be Improved:

The only downside I noticed was the long queue at the satay station. By the time I reached it, the crowd had built up and the wait was noticeably longer than the other stations. The smell of freshly grilled satay was definitely worth the delay, but it did slow the experience down a bit. Perhaps adding a second grill or station could help manage this better during peak periods.

All in all, Makan Kitchen’s weekday lunch buffet was a well-rounded, halal-friendly culinary experience. It’s a great option whether you’re attending a nearby event, meeting clients, or simply want to treat yourself to a rich variety of Malaysian flavours in a comfortable setting. Just be ready to queue a little for the satay!

Would I return? Absolutely.
And next time, I’ll probably head to the satay counter first.

response.snippet:

It's wonderful to know you enjoyed the variety and authenticity of our Malaysian offerings, and that the atmosphere, layout, and service contributed to a pleasant and seamless dining experience. We’re especially pleased to hear that our team’s attentiveness and warm hospitality stood out to you — moments like the naan and curry pairing suggestion are exactly the kind of personalised touches we aim for.

Your feedback on the satay station queue is duly noted. The popularity of that station is something we're proud of, but we also understand the importance of managing guest flow, especially during peak hours. It was our pleasure to have you with us, and we’re thrilled to know that you plan to return.

place_info.title: Nasi Kukus KLS @ TBS
place_info.address: Second floor, Terminal Bersepadu Selatan, Jln Lingkaran Tengah 2, Bandar Tasik Selatan, 57100 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
A Pleasant Nasi Kukus Stop After a Long Journey

After a four-hour bus ride from Ipoh, I arrived at Terminal Bersepadu Selatan (TBS) on Monday, May 12, 2025—a public holiday (Wesak Day) during a long weekend. It was around 8:00 PM when I stumbled upon Nasi Kukus KLS, a modest eatery tucked away on Level 4.

The restaurant occupies a small, half-sized space with tightly arranged seating and a self-service, cafeteria-style setup. Orders are placed and paid for at the counter, where food is also freshly prepared next to the payment area. Once ready, customers collect their meals when their order number appears on the digital screen. Despite the holiday crowd, the dining area was only about half full when I arrived. The environment felt casual and unpretentious, with a touch of character added by beautiful wall murals.

According to Malaysian Foodie, Nasi Kukus KLS spent over a year perfecting their recipes, focusing on achieving the ideal balance of herbs and spices in both the rice and the ayam goreng berempah (spiced fried chicken). Their curry is slow-cooked for hours to intensify its richness and aroma, and their sambal is crafted to deliver a bold, spicy kick—complementing the overall flavour of the dish.

The menu offers an impressive variety of Nasi Kukus (steamed rice) dishes. These include:
•   Ayam Goreng Berempah (Spiced Fried Chicken) – RM13.90
•   Sotong Goreng Berempah (Spiced Fried Squid) – RM15.90
•   Ikan Bawal / Lele Goreng Berempah – RM13.90–15.90
Other proteins include turmeric chicken, pandan chicken, rendang, and curry mutton. Side add-ons and drinks are also available, including a set meal upgrade for RM2.30.

My Order:
•   Ayam Goreng Berempah – RM13.11
•   Coke – RM2.17
Subtotal: RM15.28
6% SST: RM0.92
Total Paid: RM16.20

After a 10-minute wait, my number appeared and I collected my set meal, which included:
•   Steamed white rice
•   Spiced fried chicken thigh with crispy herb crumbs
•   Curry gravy
•   Sambal belacan
•   Cucumber-onion salad
•   A glass of Coke

The portion was reasonable. The rice was warm and fluffy, though not the most aromatic I’ve tasted. The chicken was decent—crispy and mildly spiced, perhaps slightly on the average side compared to standout local alternatives. Nonetheless, the combination of curry and sambal did lift the overall flavour experience.

In summary, Nasi Kukus KLS offers a practical and flavorful local meal experience, especially convenient for travelers passing through TBS. The food preparation is fresh, the menu is diverse, and service is efficient. While it may not be the best nasi kukus in the Klang Valley, it’s a solid option—and I’d consider returning again.

place_info.title: Amanjaya Bus Terminal
place_info.address: 1, Persiaran Meru Raya 5, 31200 Ipoh, Perak, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
A Decent Long-Distance Terminal, With Room for Improvement

I recently used Terminal Meru Raya (Terminal Amanjaya) for both arrival and departure during the long Vesak weekend in May 2025, and here’s my balanced take for those planning a visit:

Overall Experience
•   Arrival (Friday, May 9 @ 8:00 PM): Surprisingly calm and quiet despite being a long weekend. The terminal was not crowded, and it was easy to navigate.
•   Departure (Monday, May 12 @ 3:00 PM – Vesak Day): Significantly busier with long queues and crowded departure areas, as expected during a public holiday. Plan extra time if traveling on festive dates.

Location & Accessibility
•   Located about 15 km from Ipoh city center, the terminal is easily accessible via myBas T30a and T30b, taxis, or e-hailing services like Grab.
•   Personally, I preferred parking at nearby Mydin Mall and walking across. It’s more convenient, especially during busy hours, and gives you access to better facilities before your trip.

Facilities & Amenities
•   The terminal is a three-level structure, generally modern and spacious, with air-conditioned waiting lounges. However, air conditioning was weak in the afternoon, especially when the terminal was crowded.
•   There’s a KK Mart convenience store, Di Naina Mamak restaurant, and RotiBoy—good for quick meals or refreshments.
•   Surau (upper floor): Sadly, not up to par. It’s small, not very clean, and lacked proper organization. The nearby men’s toilet was also in poor condition and needed maintenance.
•   Most shops and food outlets on the upper floor were closed or unoccupied, giving the space a rather deserted feel.

Ticketing & Digital Services
•   Online booking is available through bus operators or platforms like busonlineticket.com. However, converting your e-ticket to a boarding pass costs RM2, and only cash is accepted at certain counters—this is inconvenient. It would be better if the fee were included in the ticket price, as practiced at TBS (Terminal Bersepadu Selatan).
•   The Terminal Meru Raya app exists, but feedback from users is mostly negative. I didn’t use it due to the poor reviews.

Bus Services & Departures
•   The terminal serves major destinations like KL, Penang, Cameron Highlands, and Johor Bahru, with operators such as Perak Transit, Yoyo Express, Super Nice, and KKKL.
•   The digital departure board is too small and only located at one spot. For such a large terminal, more and larger displays would help passengers monitor schedules more easily.
•   Staff were present but less helpful during peak hours. Best to confirm your gate and timing early.

Tips for Fellow Travelers
1.	Arrive early, especially on weekends and holidays.
2.	Bring RM2 cash if you booked online and need to print your boarding pass.
3.	Use Mydin Mall for better parking and facilities before/after your trip.
4.	Pray early elsewhere, such as ay Mydin, if possible, especially if cleanliness is a concern.

Terminal Meru Raya is functional and offers the essential services needed for intercity travel. It’s a strategic hub for northern Malaysia, and while it has potential, improvements are definitely needed—especially in facility maintenance, digital services, and passenger convenience.

If these areas are improved, it could easily rival larger terminals like TBS. Until then, come prepared with a bit of patience and flexibility. Safe travels!

place_info.title: Toilet Plaza Tol Bukit Beruntung
place_info.address: CHF3+WJ, Bukit Beruntung, 48300 Rawang, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Date & Time of Visit: Monday, May 12, 2025 (Vesak Day Long Weekend), 6:30 PM

As a frequent highway user and someone who values cleanliness and comfort during travel, I wish to share my personal experience using the public toilet facilities at Bukit Beruntung Toll Plaza on the evening of a public holiday. Despite it being the Vesak Day long weekend, when traffic and rest stop usage were noticeably high, I was pleasantly surprised by the excellent condition of the facilities.

1. Cleanliness Despite High Traffic

Upon arrival at 6:30 PM, I expected the facilities to be worn out from a day of heavy use. However, the toilets were still clean, dry, and well-stocked. There was no unpleasant smell, no water pooling on the floor, and toilet paper was available. This reflects a well-managed cleaning schedule and efficient oversight by the janitorial team. For a peak holiday period, this level of cleanliness is impressive and reassuring.

2. Convenient and Accessible Layout

The location of the toilets was clearly signposted and within short walking distance from the main toll and rest area. Entry was smooth, and I noticed there were spacious cubicles, suitable for travelers with bags or small children. The OKU-accessible stalls were visibly marked and appeared user-friendly.

3. Muslim-Friendly Design

As a Muslim traveler, I appreciated how easy it was to perform wudhu (ablution). The ablution area was clean, separate from the main toilet, and designed to prevent water spillage, helping keep the rest of the facility dry. The nearby surau was also open and in use by other travelers at the time, indicating good coordination of religious facilities.

4. Modern Facilities and Comfort

The facility was equipped with sensor-operated taps, automatic flush systems, and LED lighting, all of which made the experience feel modern, hygienic, and safe. Despite the evening hour, the area was well-lit and ventilated, which enhanced comfort.

5. Safe and Family-Friendly Environment

There was a visible security presence, which gave me peace of mind, especially as I was traveling with my family. The area around the toilet was brightly lit, and there were baby-changing facilities available, which would be very convenient for families with young children.

6. Public Feedback and Atmosphere

I observed that other users were also satisfied, and the overall mood was calm and positive, despite the holiday crowd. I overheard a fellow traveler commenting to his companion, “Tak sangka bersih lagi walaupun ramai orang hari ni” (Didn’t expect it to still be clean even though it’s crowded today).

Overall, my visit to the public toilets at Bukit Beruntung Toll Plaza during the Vesak Day long weekend at 6:30 PM was highly satisfactory. PLUS Malaysia Berhad deserves full credit for maintaining excellent service standards even during peak periods. The combination of cleanliness, accessibility, safety, and Islamic-friendly facilities truly reflects a commitment to traveler well-being. I hope these standards are maintained and adopted across all rest stops nationwide.

place_info.title: D'Festivo Residence
place_info.address: 31, Jalan Medan Ipoh 1H, Bandar Baru Medan Ipoh, 31400 Ipoh, Perak, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
D’Festivo Residences – Unit A-9-12A
Stay Dates: 9–12 May 2025 (Vesak Long Weekend)

“A thoughtfully designed, peaceful sanctuary in the heart of Ipoh.”

I stayed at Unit A-9-12A in D’Festivo Residences over the Vesak weekend, and it turned out to be a restful, high-quality homestay experience. Located in Bandar Baru Medan, Ipoh, this north-facing unit offered a blend of comfort, practicality, and modern design that made for a truly enjoyable getaway.

About D’Festivo Residences

Completed in 2016 by Emerald Capital Sdn. Bhd., D’Festivo is a modern, well-maintained leasehold condominium with 240 units. Despite its age, the building remains clean and well-kept, offering a resort-style living environment with facilities like:
•   Swimming pool, fitness centre, and children’s playground
•   Landscaped garden, sauna, and 24-hour security

Its strategic location places it next to Festival Walk Ipoh, and within minutes of AEON Mall Kinta City, schools, hospitals, and eateries—perfect for families, couples, or professionals.

The Unit – A-9-12A

This tastefully renovated, minimalist unit was one of the highlights of my stay. Naturally bright and spacious, it features:
•   Master bedroom with en-suite bathroom
•   Second bedroom with a king-size bed
•   Third bedroom with a double-decker bunk bed
•   Shared bathroom, glass-partitioned kitchen, and a cozy living area with high-speed Wi-Fi and streaming-capable smart TV

The glass kitchen design is a standout, keeping cooking smells out of the living space—an excellent detail for longer stays.

Cleanliness, Comfort & Connectivity

The unit was immaculately clean, with fresh towels, well-arranged furniture, and calming decor. Wi-Fi connectivity was fast and reliable, and the entertainment setup made it easy to relax indoors.

Parking & Access

The dedicated car park on Level 1 was convenient, though the internal layout could use better signage for easier navigation. Still, access was smooth, and the host’s instructions were clear.

Minor Drawback

The only drawback was some audible traffic noise from the North-South Expressway, especially at night. It was not disruptive to me, but light sleepers might prefer a unit facing away from the highway.

Overall, my stay at D’Festivo Residences, Unit A-9-12A, was highly satisfying. The unit offered everything needed for a restful urban retreat—cleanliness, design, comfort, and convenience. I would confidently recommend this homestay to anyone visiting Ipoh, whether for a short holiday or an extended stay.

place_info.title: Family Bundle @ Taman Jubilee
place_info.address: 28, Jalan Raja Ekram, Taman Jubilee, 30450 Ipoh, Perak, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
May 12, 2025 (Vesak Day)

Today, my wife and I visited Family Bundle at No. 28, Jalan Raja Ekram, Taman Jubilee, Ipoh — one of Malaysia’s better-known thrift stores. Since it was Vesak Day, a public holiday, we took the opportunity to explore the area and spend a relaxed afternoon thrifting.

Arrival and First Impressions

We arrived around noon and were fortunate to find a street parking spot not far from the store, near Jubilee Park. As I stood there, I couldn’t help but feel nostalgic. Jubilee Park, though quieter now, reminded me of its vibrant days — I first visited it in late 1987, when it still had the charm of a full-fledged amusement park. That memory added a personal touch to our visit.

The Family Bundle store itself is a two-storey building, strategically located near a busy intersection in downtown Ipoh. Its presence is easy to spot, though the area can be quite congested, especially on weekends or public holidays.

Store Layout and Offerings

Inside, the store houses a significantly large collection of second-hand clothing. The ground floor is dedicated to men’s clothing, while the upper floor caters to women’s apparel. I appreciated that each floor was equipped with fitting rooms, which made trying out items convenient.

The selection is undeniably broad. Whether you’re looking for casual wear, smart attire, or outerwear, there’s something for most tastes and age groups. My wife managed to find some trousers and shirts that suited her style and needs — and we both agreed that the pricing was reasonable. While not dirt-cheap, the prices were fair for the quality offered, especially for those willing to take time to browse.

Store Ambience and Observations

That said, I found the store less organized compared to my previous experience at Mr Musashi. Certain sections were quite densely packed, and items weren’t always sorted as systematically as they could be. This made the browsing experience a bit less efficient, particularly for shoppers who prefer to find things quickly.

The ambience was modest, with functional lighting and a utilitarian setup. There wasn’t much in terms of aesthetic presentation, but for a thrift store, the focus is clearly on volume and affordability rather than decor.

Customer Service and Experience

Our interaction with the staff was minimal. While no one was unfriendly, there wasn’t much initiative taken either in offering assistance or engaging with customers. The service was adequate, but not especially warm or memorable. That said, the check-out process was smooth and efficient.

I also noticed that some items, especially those marked as “Premium,” were priced higher than typical bundle shops. While these pieces might be of better quality, I think clearer price labelling and explanation would help customers better understand the pricing structure and justify the premium.

Reflections and Final Thoughts

In conclusion, Family Bundle at Taman Jubilee provides a practical and accessible shopping experience, particularly for those on a budget or who enjoy treasure-hunting through racks of preloved clothing. While I appreciated the broad selection and reasonable pricing, the overall experience would benefit from better organization and more attentive customer service.

The nostalgic charm of the surrounding area, combined with the potential to discover hidden fashion gems, made it a worthwhile stop for us — though improvements in store layout and presentation would go a long way in elevating the experience.

I would consider returning, perhaps during a quieter days, to take more time browsing through the stock and see if the layout improves. It remains a useful destination for second-hand shopping in Ipoh.

place_info.title: Restoran Mat Rock | Ayam Goreng Kunyit | Gerbang Malam Ipoh
place_info.address: 166, Jalan Sultan Idris Shah, Kampung Jawa, 30300 Ipoh, Perak, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
May 12, 2025 (Vesak Day):

After a short shopping trip at a nearby second-hand (bundle) store, my wife and I decided to have lunch at Restoran Mat Rock Ayam Goreng Kunyit, located conveniently near the main entrance of Gerbang Malam, Ipoh. It was around 1:00 PM on a long weekend public holiday (Vesak Day, May 12, 2025). Surprisingly, the restaurant was almost empty, which made for a quiet and relaxed dining experience.

Dining Experience & Service:

The restaurant follows a cafeteria-style concept where diners choose from the menu and make full payment at the counter before seating themselves. Payment was quick and convenient — I used MAE QR code without any hassle.

Our food was ready within seconds after payment. A very efficient system. There is also self-service complimentary plain water and soup, which adds extra value to the meal.

What We Ordered:

We tried the following two sets:
•   Set A: Nasi, Ayam Goreng Kunyit, Teh O Ais – RM10.00
Very tasty. Chicken was crispy and well-marinated, with balanced spices.
•   Set 2: Nasi, Ayam & Daging Goreng Kunyit, Teh O Ais – RM16.00
Also delicious, though the beef was slightly tough. Everything else was satisfying and flavorful.

Overall, the dishes lived up to the restaurant’s reputation for turmeric-based fried meals. Despite the beef’s texture, I consider the meal very enjoyable.

Why I Recommend It:

•   Location: Prime spot near Gerbang Malam’s main entrance.
•   Food Quality: Tasty, flavorful, and satisfying.
•   Service: Fast, efficient, and well-organized.
•   Price: Very affordable for the portion and taste offered.
•   Added Value: Free soup and water, self-serve.

Summary:

My dining experience at Mat Rock Ayam Goreng Kunyit in Ipoh was overwhelmingly positive. From the smooth ordering process and prompt service to the satisfying taste and value for money, everything met (and exceeded) expectations. I especially appreciated the added touch of complimentary soup and water, as well as the convenient digital payment option.

I genuinely have no complaints about this restaurant and will gladly return in the future.

place_info.title: BHPetrol Ladang Bikam (Northbound)
place_info.address: Kaw. Hentian Ladang Bikam Arah U/S, 35600 Sungkai, Perak, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
BHPetrol Ladang Bikam (Northbound)

I recently traveled from TBS, KL to Ipoh during a long weekend by bus, and my bus made a stop at BHPetrol Ladang Bikam (Northbound) for a quick toilet break. I took the opportunity to use the restroom, and I was really impressed by how clean and well-maintained it was, especially considering it’s a busy rest stop. It’s no wonder the place won the “Toilet of the Year” award in 2024, highlighting its exceptional cleanliness.

Afterward, I performed my Asar prayer at the surau, which was also well-kept and offered a peaceful environment. It’s always a great feeling when you can pray in comfort while traveling.

I then visited the convenience store, BHPetromart, which was well-organized and stocked with a variety of snacks, drinks, and travel essentials. Whether you need to grab a quick bite or pick up toiletries, this store has it all. I was particularly impressed by how neatly everything was arranged, making it easy to find what I was looking for.

The Dunkin’ Donuts outlet is a great option for a quick coffee or snack to keep you refreshed. The staff at both the convenience store and the food outlet were friendly, welcoming, and ready to assist, which really added to the positive experience.

For those traveling with electric vehicles, BHPetrol Ladang Bikam (Northbound) is also planning to install a 200kW DC fast-charging station soon, in collaboration with TNB Electron. This will make it even more convenient for EV drivers on their long journeys.

Whether you’re traveling by car, bus, or even EV, this rest stop provides a great mix of essential services and comfort. It’s a fantastic place to rest, refuel, and recharge both your body and your vehicle. I would definitely recommend this stop to other travelers making their way up or down the North-South Expressway.

place_info.title: Kelab Darul Ehsan
place_info.address: 10, Jalan 15, Taman Tun Abdul Razak, 68000 Ampang Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Having been a member of Kelab Darul Ehsan for over a decade, my connection to this club runs deep. Initially, my primary reason for joining was the golf course—a beautifully designed 9-hole layout by the Ronald Fream Group. Tucked into a hilly, natural landscape with strategic water hazards and tight fairways, it presented a rewarding challenge for any golfer. The fourth hole, in particular, remains memorable with its lotus pond and narrow approach—requiring both precision and calm under pressure.

In more recent years, my engagement with the club has shifted. Alongside colleagues, I now frequent KDE for its badminton facilities. While some areas—like the changing rooms and general upkeep of certain amenities—show signs of aging and less-than-optimal maintenance, the overall environment remains usable and pleasant. The sense of nostalgia often outweighs these minor inconveniences.

Beyond golf and badminton, KDE has long offered a broad array of recreational amenities, from its unique driving range with floater balls into a scenic lake, to its family-friendly swimming pool, gym, tennis and squash courts, and halal dining options. Its setting in Taman Tun Abdul Razak, Ampang Jaya, makes it accessible yet peacefully removed from the city’s bustle.

However, like many long-standing institutions, this club is not immune to change. I recently heard from other members that Kelab Darul Ehsan may be earmarked for property development in the near future. If true, it marks the closing of a chapter not just for me, but for many who have found community and recreation within its grounds.

KDE is more than a recreational facility; it is a place filled with personal milestones, quiet mornings on the fairway, and team spirit on the badminton court. As I reflect on the possibility of its transformation, I carry both gratitude for the memories and a quiet sadness that its familiar spaces may not be here for future generations to enjoy.

Customer Experience

Ambience & Service

Food Ordered

•   Spicy YY Boneless Chicken (6 pcs): Good portion, balanced spiciness
3.	Drinks
•   Coke and Sprite: Standard servings
4.	Dessert
•   Peach Bingsoo: Refreshing and light, good way to end the meal

⸻

Overall Experience
•   Food Quality: Consistently good across appetiser, main, and dessert
•   Service: Friendly and timely
•   Ambience: Pleasant and not crowded during lunch hour
•   Halal Status: K Fry is known to be pork-free and alcohol-free, but not JAKIM-certified — suitable for many Muslims but worth confirming for strict requirements

⸻

Rating (Out of 5)
•   Food: 4.5
•   Service: 4.5
•   Ambience: 4.0
•   Value: 4.0

place_info.title: The Chicken Rice Shop @Avenue K KLCC
place_info.address: L1-19 & SAC-L1-1, Level 1, Avenue K, 156, Jln Ampang, Kampung Baru, 50450 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
TCRS Avenue K

This was my first visit to The Chicken Rice Shop (TCRS) outlet at Avenue K, although I’ve been to several other branches before. As expected, the quality of food and the overall experience are consistent with TCRS’s well-known standards – hearty portions, family-friendly menus, and reliable service.

We ordered the 308 Family Fiesta Set, designed for 5–6 persons, and it was truly impressive both in variety and taste. The set included a generous spread: Hainanese Steamed Chicken, Roast Chicken, Prime Honey BBQ Chicken, and assorted portions like wings and breast, which were all perfectly cooked – tender, juicy, and well-marinated. The accompanying sides such as Tofu with Oyster Sauce, Nyonya Pai Tee, Stuffed Fish Balls, and Ipoh Bean Sprouts brought a rich balance of flavours and textures to the meal.

The inclusion of six portions of rice and soup, along with refreshing drinks like Mirinda Strawberry, Mineral Water, and the indulgent Famous Kuching 3 Layer Tea, completed the meal splendidly. The Rainbow Delights and Kerabu Mango added a vibrant, appetising touch that pleased everyone at the table.

Despite the lunchtime crowd, the service was prompt, friendly, and efficient. The ordering process was smooth – either through scanning a QR code or opting for manual ordering, which provides good flexibility depending on your preference.

The Avenue K outlet gets busy quite quickly, especially around noon, so I recommend arriving slightly earlier to secure a seat without waiting.

Overall, I am very satisfied with this visit. TCRS Avenue K upholds the reliable quality that TCRS fans have come to expect. Highly recommended for families and groups looking for a fulfilling, value-for-money meal with efficient service in a clean and comfortable environment.

details.recommended_dishes: Hainanese Chicken Rice, Roast, Bean Sprouts with Rolls, Sai to Fish Ball, Pak Choy with Oyster Sauce, Prime Honey BBQ Chicken

place_info.title: D'Pantai Homestay
place_info.address: Jalan Pantai Rantau Panjang, Kampung Rantau Panjang, 26800 Kuala Rompin, Pahang, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
A Coastal Delight Beyond Expectations: D'Pantai Homestay Campsite, Kuala Rompin: Where a spontaneous detour turned into an unforgettable beachfront camping experience

During a recent road trip across the East Coast, we—a close-knit group of three—found ourselves driving through the peaceful town of Kuala Rompin in search of a quiet place to set up camp for the night. Our original destination was the Z&S Campsite, located a little further south. Unfortunately, we were greeted by disappointment as the site was closed upon arrival. But as travellers know, some of the best experiences come from the unexpected—and that’s exactly what happened next.

Refusing to let the closed gates end our day, we drove north and came across D'Pantai Homestay, a charming beachside property that looked promising. Though the homestay itself was fully booked, we were pleasantly surprised by the kindness and resourcefulness of the staff. Rather than turning us away, they welcomed us warmly and suggested we camp at the adjacent public beachfront area, which is unofficially part of the homestay’s surroundings.

To make things even better, they provided us with contact details for the operator of the nearby public toilet facilities, ensuring that we had access to clean toilets and showers—a huge relief for any camper. It's rare to find such a level of helpfulness, and it immediately made us feel comfortable and safe.

Setting up our tents on the open beachfront, we were amazed by the natural beauty that surrounded us. The sand was soft, the air was fresh with a salty breeze, and the view of the South China Sea stretched endlessly before us. Within 100 metres, we found a few small local restaurants offering delicious and affordable halal meals, perfect for dinner and breakfast. The convenience of having food nearby added a layer of ease to our spontaneous stopover.

As dusk approached, we were treated to one of the most breathtaking sunsets we had seen on our journey. The sky transformed into a canvas of gold, orange, and soft purple hues, reflecting off the gentle waves. The sunrise the next morning was equally captivating—a serene and spiritual moment, as the first light shimmered over the horizon, accompanied by the distant call of seabirds and the soothing sound of waves.
Despite it being the weekend, the beach remained surprisingly uncrowded. There was a sense of privacy and serenity that allowed us to unplug from the world and fully absorb the moment. As night fell, we laid back to watch the stars come out above the rhythmic crashing of waves—a simple pleasure that reminded us why we love the outdoors.

What stood out most about this experience wasn’t just the location, but the genuine hospitality extended by the team at D’Pantai Homestay. Even though we weren’t official guests in their rooms, they treated us with care, respect, and generosity—values that are becoming increasingly rare in commercial tourism today.

Conclusion:
If you're a traveller seeking more than just a place to sleep—if you value authentic encounters, stunning scenery, and a peaceful environment—then the beachfront near D'Pantai Homestay in Kuala Rompin should absolutely be on your list. Whether you’re camping or just stopping by, this place is a hidden gem waiting to be discovered.

We arrived by chance, but we left with a heart full of gratitude and a memory that will stay with us for a long time. This was not just a stop—it was a highlight of our road trip.
Highly recommended for backpackers, road trippers, casual campers, and anyone in search of coastal serenity with a touch of heartfelt Malaysian hospitality.

response.snippet: Alhamdulillah dan terima kasih atas perkongsian tuan.
response.translated_snippet: Alhamdulillah and thank you for sharing sir.

place_info.title: Mohammed Bin Saud Grand Mosque
place_info.address: 6363, 4388, Al Jummayzah, Makkah 24237, Saudi Arabia

reviews.snippet:
A Spiritual Sanctuary in Makkah: Mohammed Bin Saud Grand Mosque (مسجد محمد بن سعود الكبير)
An essential masjid for peace, prayer, and spiritual connection beyond the Haram

In the sacred city of Makkah al-Mukarramah, where the atmosphere is filled with the blessings of worship and submission, the Mohammed Bin Saud Grand Mosque (مسجد محمد بن سعود الكبير) offers a beautiful and serene alternative to Masjid al-Haram for daily prayers. Nestled just slightly away from the central Haram area, this mosque provides an ideal space for those who seek a quieter yet equally spiritual environment to perform their ibadah.

During Ramadan 2025, this mosque became my primary place of worship when I was not in Al-Haram. Located only 25 meters from my accommodation, it offered both spiritual refuge and remarkable convenience. Its proximity allowed me to attend almost every prayer in congregation. However, I had to arrive early, especially for Maghrib, Isha, and Fajr, as the main prayer hall often fills quickly. When arriving late, I found myself praying on the road under the scorching sun—a humbling reminder of the devotion shared by worshippers from all walks of life.

Architecturally, the mosque is elegant and welcoming. The interior is air-conditioned, well-lit, and adorned with subtle Islamic motifs, creating a calm atmosphere for reflection and prayer. The carpeted floors are relatively clean and comfortable, and the overall maintenance of the mosque is excellent. Staff members are present and attentive, ensuring cleanliness and order, especially during the busy Ramadan period. It is important to note that the mosque is usually closed about 30 minutes after each main prayer, so planning ahead is essential.

One of the most spiritually enriching experiences I had was breaking fast (iftar) here with fellow congregants. The sense of brotherhood, sharing, and humility was palpable. Though it is not as large as Al-Haram, this mosque is deeply alive with ikhlas (sincerity) and community spirit, especially during the holy month.

Conclusion:
Masjid Mohammed Bin Saud Al-Kabir is far more than just a nearby place of prayer—it is a spiritual anchor. Whether you're a resident, visitor, or pilgrim, this masjid offers a unique environment of peace, discipline, and devotion. The combination of proximity, spiritual atmosphere, and community experience made it a treasured part of my Ramadan in Makkah.

It is now, undoubtedly, a must-visit mosque for anyone staying near the area. Every prayer here brought me closer to Allah ﷻ in a setting that is quiet yet spiritually vibrant.

place_info.title: Kurban Fish Market
place_info.address: 2364 Abdul Muhsin Ibn Abdul Aziz, Qurban, Madinah 42316, Saudi Arabia

reviews.snippet:
A Hidden Gem in Medina: Kurban Fish Market – A Must-Visit Dining Experience

Every visit to Medina is incomplete without dining at Kurban Fish Market**, especially for those who enjoy fresh, flavourful seafood. Located within walking distance on the long route from Masjid an-Nabawi to Masjid Quba, this place is a delightful detour and an ideal spot for a nourishing and satisfying meal.

We discovered this gem during one of our long evening walks from Nabawi to Quba. Though there are several seafood restaurants within the market area, we decided to enter the first one we came across—and we were not disappointed.

From the moment we stepped in, we were warmly welcomed by a team of friendly Pakistani staff. The dining experience begins with selecting your fish from an impressive display of fresh catches. Once chosen, the fish is weighed, and the price is clearly communicated before proceeding. We found this transparency very professional and reassuring.

After confirming the order, we were asked to choose the cooking style: deep fried or grilled. We opted for grilled, as we wanted to truly enjoy the natural flavour of the fish. Alongside the fish, we were also given a choice between white or brown rice, and then we placed our drink orders.

The waiting time was very reasonable—around 10 to 15 minutes—and when the food arrived, it was fresh, aromatic, and perfectly cooked. The grilled fish was tender, juicy, and packed with subtle spices that did not overpower the natural taste. The rice was fluffy and complemented the fish well.

Amazingly, the entire meal for our group cost only SAR 100, which we found to be excellent value for money considering the freshness and quality of the food.

One of the most thoughtful features of the location is the two-level musolla (surau) right next to the restaurant. It provides a peaceful and convenient place to perform prayers before or after the meal—something that is especially appreciated in the holy city of Medina.

Conclusion:
Kurban Fish Market is more than just a seafood restaurant—it's an experience of hospitality, tradition, and taste that perfectly complements the spiritual atmosphere of Medina. Whether you're a seafood lover or just looking to try something different and wholesome, this place is highly recommended. It has now become a must-visit stop every time we return to this blessed city.

place_info.title: Al Safwah Royale Orchid
place_info.address: 4289, Al Hajlah, Makkah 24231, Saudi Arabia

reviews.snippet:
Musolla Facilities at Al Safwah Royale Orchid – An Excellent Spiritual Convenience

I had the honour of visiting the musolla at Al Safwah Royale Orchid Hotel during the blessed last 10 days of Ramadan, specifically to perform the Jumu‘ah prayer. My visit was upon the kind invitation of a friend who was staying at the hotel. From the moment I arrived, I was impressed with the organisation, accessibility, and spiritual ambiance of the facility.

To enter the hotel as a guest, I was required to be accompanied by my friend, who presented his room card to gain access to the mezzanine floor where the musolla is located. This system ensures security and privacy for the guests while maintaining a tranquil environment suitable for worship.

The musolla itself is remarkably spacious, clean, and well-maintained. Despite its size, I noticed that it became quite crowded an hour before Jumu‘ah, which reflects its popularity and the high demand, especially during Ramadan. It is advisable to arrive early to secure a comfortable spot.

One of the most convenient features is that the musolla is connected to the Masjid Al-Haram’s live audio system. This allows worshippers to fully follow the Jumu‘ah sermon and prayer in real-time without having to physically enter the Haram complex. During the crowded days of Ramadan, this is an incredible advantage—offering ease, safety, and focus in worship without the need for very early arrival at the mosque.

The musolla’s environment is spiritually uplifting and well-managed. The hotel clearly understands the needs of Muslim guests, particularly during this sacred time, and has made commendable efforts to accommodate them with dignity and comfort.

In conclusion, I highly commend the musolla facilities at Al Safwah Royale Orchid. It is an excellent alternative for those who wish to perform their prayers in close proximity to the Haram while avoiding congestion. For hotel guests, especially during Ramadan, it provides an added spiritual benefit that enhances the entire pilgrimage experience.

place_info.title: Masjid Al-Jumuah
place_info.address: CJW8+54V، طريق السلام، Al Jumuah, Madinah 42315, Saudi Arabia

reviews.snippet:
During Higera, the Prophet left Quba on a Friday to head into Madinah. About a kilometer from Quba he passed the village of Banu Salim bin Auf.

The people of Banu Salim implored: “O Prophet of Allah, you stayed at the homes of our cousins for a number of days, reward us too with something, for they will pride themselves over us till the Day of Judgement that you stayed with them”. The Prophet dismounted and offered his first Jummah in their locality.

Approximately one hundred Muslims participated in this first Jummah salah. Amongst them were the Prophet’s relatives from Bani an-Najjar who had come to meet him and some from Bani Amr who had escorted him from Quba.
After performing the Friday prayer, the Prophet mounted Qaswa (his camel) and set off for the city of Madinah.
Masjid Jumma is also known as Masjid Bani Salim, Masjid al wadi, Masjid Ghubaib and Masjid Aatikah.

According to ibn Jarir, the Prophet delivered this khutbah (sermon):
“Praise belongs to Allah. I praise Him, ask for His help and seek His Forgiveness and beseech Him for Guidance. I believe in Him and do not reject Him. I despise those who disbelieve Him. And I bear witness that there is no God but Allah, the One, Who has no partner, and that Muhammad is His slave and His Messenger who is sent with guidance and true religion, light and admonition, when there has not been a Messenger for a long time, when knowledge is but little, men are misguided, and end of time is near, death being at hand. He who obeys Allah and His Messenger is indeed guided and he who disobeys them is lost on the wrong path, is fallen down to a terrible misguidance.
And I urge you to fear Allah – the best advice a Muslim may give to another Muslim, urging him to prepare for the Hereafter and to fear Allah. O People; keep away from that which Allah has asked to shun. And there is no counsel greater than that and no remembrance greater than that. Know! For him who fears Allah in his pursuits, the best course is taqwa (righteousness) in affairs of the Hereafter. He who keeps his relationship with Allah, both secret and open, correct – being sincere – will be an asset for him after death more than zikr in this world. But if anyone fails in that then he would wish that his deeds were kept away from him. As for him who believes and fulfills his promise then;

“The word is not changed with Me, nor do I wrong (My) servants.” [50:29]
Muslims! Fear Allah in what concerns you now and what will follow, in what is hidden and what is open, for,
“And he who fears Allah, He will acquit him of his evil deeds and He will magnify the reward for him.” [65:5] And those who fear Allah will gain a mighty success. It is fear of Allah that keeps away His disapproval, punishment and wrath. It is taqwa (fear of Allah) that brightens the countenance, pleases the Lord and raises ranks.

O Muslims! Pursue good fortune but do not lag behind in the rights of Allah. He taught you His Book and guided you on the path that the righteous and the false may be distinguished. O People! Allah has been good to you and you should be like that to others. Keep away from His enemies and strive in His cause with determination. He has chosen you and named you Muslims so that he who perishes, does so for a worthy cause and he who lives, follows a worthy cause. And every piety is done with His help.

O People! Remember Allah. Strive for the Hereafter. As for him, who corrects his relationship with Allah then Allah corrects his relationship with other people.

Know! Allah judges over people but is not judged by anyone. He is their Master but they have no power over Him. Allah is the Greatest. And there is no power (to do good) except with Allah the Mighty.”

place_info.title: HHR Station
place_info.address: CQ8Q+GVW, Unnamed Road, Ar Rusayfah, Makkah 24232, Saudi Arabia

reviews.snippet:
During our recent journey in Ramadan, our group of four had the privilege of experiencing the Haramain High-Speed Railway (HHR) from Makkah to Madinah. The experience was nothing short of exceptional, combining modern infrastructure with efficiency and comfort.

Mecca HHR Station: A Testament to Modern Islamic Architecture

Located in the Rusaiyfah District near the 3rd Ring Road, the Makkah HHR Station stands as a beacon of contemporary Islamic design. Designed by renowned architects Foster + Partners and Buro Happold, the station features vaulted roofs and walls with small openings that allow natural light to illuminate the concourse, creating a serene and atmospheric environment . The station is equipped with a range of amenities, including comfortable waiting areas, shopping outlets, eateries, dedicated prayer rooms for men and women, and accessible facilities for all passengers . ￼ ￼ ￼

The Journey: Speed, Comfort, and Efficiency

The Haramain High-Speed Railway spans approximately 450 kilometers, connecting the holy cities of Makkah and Madinah via Jeddah and King Abdullah Economic City. Operating at speeds up to 300 km/h, the journey between Makkah and Madinah takes around 2 hours and 20 minutes, significantly reducing travel time . ￼ ￼

Our economy class seats were spacious and comfortable, featuring foldable armrests, tables, headrests, and power plugs . The train was impeccably clean, well-lit, and maintained a punctual schedule throughout the journey. ￼

Connectivity and Signage

One notable shortcoming was the absence of free Wi-Fi at the station, which could be inconvenient for travelers needing internet access. Furthermore, the station could benefit from improved signage to assist passengers in navigating to their respective platforms and services.

Final Thoughts

The Haramain High-Speed Railway offers a remarkable travel experience, blending modern amenities with efficiency and comfort. Despite minor areas for improvement, such as onboard dining and station signage, the overall journey was seamless and enjoyable. We highly recommend this mode of transportation for anyone traveling between Makkah and Madinah. ￼

place_info.title: TWO SONS On The Park @ KLCC
place_info.address: Level 1, Lot 160 & Kiosk OS113, Petronas Twin Tower, Kuala Lumpur City Centre, 50088 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Two Sons Bistro @ Suria KLCC ￼

Two Sons Bistro at Suria KLCC offers an exceptional dining experience, blending Western and Malaysian cuisines in a stylish setting. The restaurant’s ambiance is enhanced by its location, featuring sliding doors that open to the KLCC park and fountain, providing a serene backdrop for meals.

Culinary Highlights

During a recent gathering of former ExxonMobil Material Department colleagues from the 1990s, we indulged in a selection of the bistro’s signature dishes:
•   Vongole and Butter Lala: These clam dishes, served in flavorful sauces, are a testament to the bistro’s reputation for seafood excellence.
•   Barramundi Fish and Chips: The fish was perfectly battered and fried, accompanied by crispy fries, offering a delightful take on this classic dish.
•   Grilled Salmon Steak: Cooked to perfection, the salmon was moist and flavorful, highlighting the quality of the ingredients used.
•   Mini Mantao Buns: These soft, fluffy buns served as an excellent accompaniment to the rich sauces of the clam dishes.

The menu also features a variety of other options, including steaks, pastas, and local Malaysian favorites like Nasi Kerabu Ayam Percik, catering to diverse palates.  ￼

Service and Ambiance

The staff at Two Sons Bistro are attentive and courteous, ensuring a pleasant dining experience. The restaurant’s design combines modern aesthetics with comfort, making it suitable for both casual lunches and special occasions.

Conclusion

Two Sons Bistro at Suria KLCC stands out for its delectable food, excellent service, and inviting atmosphere. Whether you’re reconnecting with old friends or seeking a quality dining experience in the heart of Kuala Lumpur, this bistro is a commendable choice. ￼

place_info.title: Thai Arch Kitchen & Bar @ Hartamas
place_info.address: Hartamas Shopping Centre, Lot G-15, Ground Floor Hartamas Shopping Center Main Entrance, 50480 Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Thai Arch Kitchen & Bar, situated on the ground floor of Hartamas Shopping Centre in Kuala Lumpur, offers a delightful fusion of authentic Thai cuisine and a vibrant dining atmosphere. Our recent lunchtime visit with a group of four provided a comprehensive experience of the establishment’s offerings.

Ambience & Setting

The restaurant boasts a spacious and aesthetically pleasing interior, characterized by modern Thai-inspired decor. The seating arrangement is comfortable, and the overall ambiance is enhanced by natural lighting, creating a warm and inviting environment. A small stage is present, presumably for live band performances during dinner hours, adding to the restaurant’s charm. Notably, there is a designated smoking section, catering to diverse patron preferences.

Culinary Experience

Our meal comprised the following dishes: ￼
•   Chicken Wings: These were particularly flavorful, with a crispy exterior and juicy interior, indicating adept preparation.
•   Spicy Seafood Tom Yum: While the soup had a commendable level of spiciness, it lacked the depth and richness typically associated with traditional Tom Yum, rendering it average in comparison. ￼
•   White Rice: Served as a staple accompaniment, the rice was well-cooked and complemented the main dishes effectively.
•   Coconut Drinks: These were refreshing and served in generous portions, providing a cooling counterbalance to the spicy dishes.

Portion sizes were notably large, which, while generous, may contribute to the perception of higher pricing, especially considering the restaurant’s location within a shopping centre.

Service & Hospitality

The staff demonstrated a high level of attentiveness and professionalism throughout our visit. They were prompt in addressing our needs and provided insightful recommendations, enhancing our dining experience. The restaurant was not particularly busy during our lunchtime visit, allowing for more personalized service.

Entertainment & Additional Features

Although there was no live performance during our visit, the presence of a stage suggests that live music is a feature during dinner hours, potentially enriching the evening dining experience. According to their social media updates, Thai Arch hosts live band performances from 8:30 PM to 10:30 PM daily, except Sundays, and features a DJ from midnight to 2:00 AM on Saturdays . These entertainment options, coupled with the restaurant’s ambiance, make it a suitable venue for both casual dining and special occasions. ￼

Pricing & Value

While the quality of food and service is commendable, the pricing leans towards the higher end, which may be attributed to the generous portion sizes and the restaurant’s upscale setting. Patrons should consider this when planning their visit, especially for larger groups or special events.

Overall Impression

Thai Arch Kitchen & Bar successfully combines authentic Thai flavors with a sophisticated dining environment. The attentive service, coupled with the restaurant’s ambiance and entertainment offerings, creates a memorable dining experience. While pricing is on the higher side, the quality and portion sizes justify the cost for those seeking a premium Thai dining experience in Kuala Lumpur. ￼

place_info.title: Tatsu Japanese Cuisine @ InterContinental
place_info.address: 165, Jln Ampang, Kuala Lumpur, 55000 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Tatsu Japanese Cuisine, InterContinental Kuala Lumpur

My recent visit to Tatsu Japanese Cuisine at InterContinental Kuala Lumpur was a thoroughly pleasant experience, and I would highly recommend it to those seeking a refined Japanese dining atmosphere in the heart of the city.

We visited during Tuesday lunchtime, and the restaurant was notably quiet, with only a few tables occupied. Its location on the mezzanine floor of the InterContinental Hotel provides an exclusive and tranquil setting, ideal for business discussions or private meals—a refreshing contrast to the typically crowded venues in the Kuala Lumpur business district (KLBD). The fact that my friend’s office is conveniently located just behind the hotel at Binjai Premium Soho added to the ease of access.

We ordered a variety of dishes:
•   Sushi set
•   Sashimi set
•   Grilled lamb
•   Hot green tea
•   Latte to finish

Each dish was expertly prepared and elegantly presented. The sushi and sashimi were fresh and well-balanced in flavour and texture, clearly reflecting high-quality ingredients. The grilled lamb stood out in particular, offering a perfectly cooked and flavourful alternative for those who prefer meat dishes. Though I did not pay the bill personally, I would say that the overall quality of food and service speaks well of the value offered.

The service was excellent—the staff were attentive, polite, and well-versed in the menu. Their professionalism contributed significantly to the comfort and ease of our lunch.

In summary, Tatsu offers a quiet, comfortable environment, making it suitable for both casual and professional gatherings. I would not hesitate to return, and I recommend it to anyone looking for authentic Japanese cuisine with excellent service in Kuala Lumpur.

response.snippet:
Dear Azmi Mahamad, 

We're delighted to hear about your fantastic dining experience at Tatsu Japanese Cuisine! Your kind words brightened our day. We strive to provide exceptional experiences, and it's guests like you who make our efforts worthwhile. Thank you for choosing our hotel and taking the time to share your thoughts. We can't wait to welcome you back for another memorable dining experience! 

Best Regards, 
Matthew Everson
General Manager

place_info.title: Rina Tomyam @‘Taman Minang
place_info.address: Pinggiran Minang 3, Taman Minang, 56000 Kuala Lumpur, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Rina Tomyam Stall

Location and Ambience
Rina Tomyam is a modest Thai food stall situated between shop lots and a residential area. The setting is informal, with a covered outdoor dining area that provides some comfort against the elements. Light music from a local radio station contributes to a relaxed and unpretentious atmosphere. One positive aspect is the ample car parking, which adds to the stall’s convenience.

Service
The staff were friendly and welcoming, creating a pleasant dining experience. Based on observation, it appears that the team may be the same individuals previously working at the now-closed Minang Tomyam, as they converse in Thai among themselves. This may suggest a level of authenticity in their food preparation.

Food
On this first visit, the following items were ordered for dinner:
•   Sup Ekor – The oxtail soup was described as just okay, suggesting it was neither particularly disappointing nor impressive.
•   Nasi Paprik – Served with chicken, the dish was somewhat salty, and the portion size was relatively small.
•   Iced Tea (served in a bowl) – An unconventional presentation but adds a local charm.

Price
The total cost was RM28, which is reasonable given current market prices for hawker-style Thai food in urban areas. However, the portion size may influence the perception of value for money.

Overall Impression
Rina Tomyam offers a basic, no-frills dining experience suitable for casual meals. While the food on this occasion was average, the stall benefits from good service, easy access, and a clean setting. It may appeal to regular patrons in the area looking for quick Thai meals, though there is room for improvement in taste and portion size.
