place_info.title: Siti Khadijah Grave Site
place_info.address: 4475 Al Hujoon St, Al Hujun, Makkah 24237, Saudi Arabia

reviews.snippet:
Maqām (Grave Site) of Sayyidah Khadījah رضي الله عنها

Biographical Background

Sayyidah Khadījah bint Khuwaylid al-Qurashiyyah al-Asadiyyah رضي الله عنها was the first wife of Prophet Muḥammad ﷺ and the first person to embrace Islam. She was born around 555 CE into the respected Quraysh tribe and was known as Ṭāhirah (the Pure One) due to her noble character. A wealthy and successful businesswoman in Makkah, she employed and later married the Prophet ﷺ when he was 25 and she was 40 years old. Their marriage was monogamous and full of mutual love, respect, and support.

She bore the Prophet ﷺ several children: Qāsim, ʿAbdullāh, Zaynab, Ruqayyah, Umm Kulthūm, and Fāṭimah al-Zahrāʾ رضي الله عنهم. Sayyidah Khadījah was instrumental in supporting the Prophet ﷺ emotionally and financially during the early years of his Prophethood, including during the harsh boycott imposed by the Quraysh. She passed away in the 10th year of Prophethood (619 CE), shortly after the lifting of the boycott. Her death, along with that of Abū Ṭālib, led to the period known as ʿĀm al-Ḥuzn (The Year of Sorrow).

Burial and Current Grave Site

Sayyidah Khadījah رضي الله عنها was buried in Jannat al-Muʿallā, an ancient cemetery in Makkah al-Mukarramah, just northeast of the Masjid al-Ḥarām. This cemetery is one of the oldest Islamic burial sites and was known even in pre-Islamic times. Her burial was simple, in accordance with the traditions of the time, and was performed by Prophet Muḥammad ﷺ himself.

Over the centuries, her grave was known and visited by Muslims with reverence. Historical accounts, particularly during the Ottoman period, mention that a dome was built over her grave, and a small mausoleum stood marking her resting place.

However, in the early 20th century (specifically 1925, under the leadership of King Abdulaziz), the Saudi government, influenced by Salafi interpretations of Islam, undertook a policy of removing all domes, mausoleums, and grave markers in Jannat al-Muʿallā and Jannat al-Baqīʿ (in Madinah). This was to prevent grave veneration, which they believed could lead to shirk (associating partners with Allah). Consequently, the grave of Sayyidah Khadījah is now unmarked and indistinguishable from the others.

Sunni Islamic View on Visiting Graves

In Sunni Islam, visiting graves is recommended (mustahabb) as a means of remembering death and the Hereafter. The Prophet ﷺ said:

Visit the graves, for indeed they remind you of the Hereafter." (Sahih Muslim)

However, Islam prohibits excessive practices at graves such as:
- Seeking intercession from the dead.
- Praying to or through the deceased.
- Building structures or domes over graves.
- Using graves as places of worship.

These prohibitions are rooted in the goal of preserving tawḥīd (pure monotheism) and avoiding any form of idolatry.

Present-Day Access and Observations

Today, Jannat al-Muʿallā is a walled cemetery with limited public access. Most of the graves, including that of Sayyidah Khadījah رضي الله عنها, are unmarked and uniform, following Saudi religious policies. While many pilgrims wish to visit her grave to pay respects, they often can only view the cemetery from the outside through the walls.

No official signs mark her grave, and photography or gatherings near the site are generally discouraged by local authorities. Despite this, Sayyidah Khadījah’s legacy continues to be honored by Muslims worldwide in prayers and historical memory.

place_info.title: Al Qassim Muhammad Grave
place_info.address: CRPH+M8Q, Al Masjid Al Haram Rd, Al Jummayzah, Makkah 24237, Saudi Arabia

reviews.snippet:
Maqam Qāsim ibn Muḥammad ﷺ

Qāsim ibn Muḥammad ﷺ was the first son of Prophet Muḥammad ﷺ and Sayyidah Khadījah al-Kubrā رضي الله عنها. He was born in Makkah, likely before the Prophet received revelation, which places his birth before 610 CE. Due to his early birth and untimely passing at a very young age—around two years old—Qāsim did not witness the beginning of Islam or his father's Prophethood. Despite his short life, Qāsim holds a significant place in Islamic history, as the Prophet ﷺ was known by the kunyah (honorific title) Abū al-Qāsim (أبو القاسم), meaning “father of Qāsim.” His death brought great sorrow to both parents, especially Sayyidah Khadījah رضي الله عنها.

The Prophet ﷺ experienced the loss of all his sons in childhood, including ʿAbdullāh and, later, Ibrāhīm from Māriyyah al-Qibṭiyyah. These repeated losses were used by some enemies among the Quraysh to mock the Prophet ﷺ, calling him abtar (cut off), referring to the lack of surviving male descendants. This insult was directly refuted by Allah ﷻ in Surah al-Kawthar (108:3), affirming the enduring spiritual legacy of the Prophet ﷺ.

Qāsim is believed to be buried in Jannat al-Muʿallā, a historic cemetery in Makkah where many of the Prophet’s family members, including Sayyidah Khadījah رضي الله عنها, are also buried. However, the exact location of his grave is unknown and unmarked. This is consistent with the policies implemented in the early 20th century under King Abdulaziz and the religious scholars of the Salafi movement, who demolished domes and shrines over graves to prevent grave worship and innovations (bid‘ah). Today, Jannat al-Muʿallā remains a walled cemetery with uniform, unmarked graves, and access is generally restricted.

From the Sunni Islamic perspective, visiting graves is encouraged to remind oneself of death and the Hereafter. This is supported by the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ: “I used to forbid you from visiting graves, but now visit them, for indeed they remind you of the Hereafter.” (Sahih Muslim). However, Islam strictly prohibits excessive veneration of graves, including building shrines, performing acts of worship at graves, or seeking intercession through the deceased. These prohibitions are rooted in numerous prophetic traditions aimed at safeguarding tawḥīd (the oneness of Allah) and preventing any form of shirk (association with Allah).

In summary, while Qāsim ibn Muḥammad ﷺ lived only briefly, his memory is preserved through his father’s noble title, Abū al-Qāsim. His life and death, like those of the other children of the Prophet ﷺ, are reminders of the personal trials endured by the Prophet ﷺ, and they reflect a deeply human side to his divine mission. The unmarked grave of Qāsim in Jannat al-Muʿallā aligns with Islamic teachings that emphasize simplicity in burial and caution against innovations related to graves.

place_info.title: Cinta Rimba @ Bukit Belacan
place_info.address: 45, Jalan 1A, Kampung Muhibbah Ampang, 68000 Ampang Jaya, Selangor, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Cinta Rimba – A Rustic Village-Style Eatery with Scenic Ambience

Located just before the Bukit Belacan waterfalls area, Cinta Rimba is a traditional Malay nasi campur (mixed rice) restaurant offering a kampung-style dining experience. I visited with two friends for Sunday lunch after a relaxing massage at a nearby kampung. The setting is peaceful, surrounded by greenery, and true to its name, gives off a charming rimba (jungle) vibe.

Ambience & Setting
The atmosphere is rustic yet clean, with basic facilities and a laid-back kampung charm. There’s also karaoke available, which may appeal to some diners looking to unwind, although it might not suit those who prefer a quieter setting. Tables and dining areas appeared clean and well-kept, with ample seating and open-air ventilation.

Food & Taste
The restaurant serves a wide variety of Malay dishes, catering to both breakfast and lunch crowds. Some of the more talked-about items include daging salai masak lemak cili api, kari kambing, and sambal belacan, which regulars describe as rich and spicy.

During my visit, I tried:
- Urat masak lemak – flavour was fair, mildly spiced and creamy.
- Ikan keli goreng – well-fried but taste-wise, also fair.
- Teh ais – standard iced tea, refreshing and reasonably sweet.

While my choices were more on the simple side, other diners have had positive experiences with the more robust and spicier dishes. The restaurant also surprisingly offers kopitiam-style and Western breakfast options, including freshly brewed coffee with medium-roast beans, which seems to appeal to coffee enthusiasts.

Service & Pricing
The staff and owner are noted to be friendly and attentive, enhancing the casual dining experience. Pricing is reasonable and reflects typical kampung-style eateries — affordable for most visitors, especially given the location and variety offered.

Verdict

Cinta Rimba offers a casual and scenic dining experience, ideal for those coming from or heading to Bukit Belacan or nearby nature spots. The food is decent with a wide variety of traditional Malay dishes, although the flavor may vary depending on your selection. Best enjoyed for its kampung vibes, clean environment, and value-for-money meals, especially if you're looking for a quiet break just outside the city.

✔️ Best for: Nature lovers, casual diners, kampung food seekers
✔️ Must-try (based on local feedback): Daging salai masak lemak, kari kambing, kopi brew
❌ Karaoke may not suit everyone; food taste can be hit or miss depending on dish choice

place_info.title: Erode Amman Mess , Malaysia
place_info.address: G9 (Retail),Suit Sentral, 248, Jalan Tun Sambanthan, Brickfields, 50470 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Erode Amman Mess – Authentic South Indian Flavors at Great Value

I recently had the opportunity to visit Erode Amman Mess, a South Indian restaurant in Kuala Lumpur that came highly recommended by an Indian friend. Located conveniently near KL Sentral and the Sentral Suites premises, this restaurant is steadily gaining a reputation for serving authentic Kongu-style cuisine that’s both delicious and reasonably priced.

Ambience & Service

We arrived during the peak lunch hour, and as expected, the restaurant was bustling with activity. Despite the crowd and energetic atmosphere, we could still **hold a conversation comfortably, and the service was impressively quick. The space was clean and well-organised, with a warm, welcoming vibe. Staff were attentive, and their ability to manage large volumes of customers efficiently was commendable.

Food & Flavour

I ordered the mutton biryani, which was made with seeraga samba rice — a signature of traditional Tamil Nadu cuisine. The taste was rich, aromatic, and satisfying, though slightly on the spicier side by my own standards (something to note for those sensitive to heat). Alongside it, I enjoyed a cup of masala tea, which was well-brewed and aromatic — the perfect complement to a hearty meal.

The portion size was reasonable, and the dish was well-balanced in flavor and texture. While I didn’t try other items on this visit, the variety on the menu suggests plenty of reasons to return — from banana leaf meals to side dishes like mutton chukka and chicken varuval, as well as traditional South Indian sweets and coffee.

Value for Money

At around RM24 for the mutton biryani, including tax, and additional for drinks, I found the pricing to be fair and competitive, especially considering the central location, food quality, and efficient service. It offers good value for a casual or hearty South Indian meal in the city.

Verdict

Erode Amman Mess delivers on what it promises — authentic South Indian cuisine served in a clean, comfortable environment at a reasonable price. The food is flavorful, freshly prepared, and clearly rooted in traditional cooking methods. Whether you're a fan of biryani, banana leaf rice, or simply looking for a satisfying meal near KL Sentral, this place is definitely worth a visit**.

✔️ Must-try: Mutton biryani, masala tea
✔️ Great for quick lunches, casual dinners, or group dining
✔️ Friendly service and clean ambience
❌ Spiciness may be high for some; arrive early to avoid the lunch crowd

details.recommended_dishes: Banana Leaf, Mutton Biryani Seeraga Samba, Fish Curry, Chapati

response.snippet:
Dear Azim,
Thank you so much for taking the time and effort to share such a beautiful review.

We are so pleased to read that you had such a lovely experience whilst dining in our restaurant. Our continued commitment lies in the complete satisfaction of each and every guest.

On behalf of the entire team at Erodu Amman Mess, we sincerely appreciate your patronage and hope to have the pleasure of welcoming you and your family back to our restaurant in the near future.

Thank you once again for choosing us!

Regards,
Erodu Amman Mess
Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

place_info.title: W (Sentul) Pickleball Centre
place_info.address: Harmoni OFF, Lot 2953, Jalan Sentul, Jln Sentul Pasar, Sentul, 51000 Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
W (Sentul) Pickleball Centre – A Mixed Bag for Casual and Company Sessions

Located within a shared sports complex in Sentul, W (Sentul) Pickleball Centre offers three indoor pickleball courts and is a popular choice for after-office hour games, particularly due to its manageable booking schedule (typically a 2–3 week wait) and its convenient proximity to central Kuala Lumpur, being less than 10 km from KLCC.

Pros: Convenience, Basic Facilities, and Friendly Service

For company sports sessions or casual beginner-level games, the center provides the essential services required for a recreational outing. Paddle and ball rental are available at affordable rates (RM5 for paddle, RM2 for ball), making it accessible for those new to the sport.

The staff are friendly and helpful, and the facility benefits from ample parking (RM1 for the first three hours), a rare plus in KL. Toilets and showers are clean, which adds comfort for players coming from work or playing longer sessions.

Those familiar with the venue from badminton may find the transition to pickleball straightforward, as the courts are integrated into a larger badminton facility.

Cons: Space Constraints, Court Conditions, and Safety Concerns

However, it is important to note that the court layout is compact, with limited space between the walls and adjacent courts. Some users have expressed difficulty moving freely, especially during serves or near the baseline, which may be uncomfortable for intermediate or competitive players. The absence of dividers between courts can also be distracting during multi-court play.

Ventilation is limited, which can lead to a stuffy environment, particularly in the evenings or after rainfall. In terms of safety, concerns have been raised about the uneven flooring and rough surface texture, which may contribute to ball bounce issues or, in some unfortunate cases, minor injuries. There are no formal first aid facilities on-site, and staff may not always be equipped to respond in emergencies.

Lastly, the RM60/hour court rate has been viewed by some players as high, given the limitations in space and overall infrastructure.

Verdict

W (Sentul) Pickleball Centre is a practical option for casual or corporate pickleball sessions, especially if proximity to the city center and ease of booking are your priorities. It is best suited for beginners or relaxed group play, rather than competitive or technical sessions. While the facility provides the basics, players seeking more space, proper court dimensions, and premium comfort may prefer exploring other options.

✔️ Pros: Strategic location, affordable rentals, friendly staff, ample parking
❌ Cons: Limited court space, poor ventilation, uneven surface, safety concerns for serious play

place_info.title: Meksu’s Kitchen
place_info.address: No. 19, Medan Selera, Jalan Raja Muda Abdul Aziz, Kampung Baru, 50300 Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Kelantanese Food Stall Near HKL

After a medical appointment at Hospital Kuala Lumpur (HKL), I stopped by the nearby food court for a quick lunch during the busy Monday lunch hour. Despite the crowd, I managed to secure a table close to a centrally located **Kelantanese food stall**.

Ambience & Location
The food court was bustling with activity, as expected during peak hours, but it was relatively clean and organized. The Kelantanese stall stood out for its variety of traditional dishes, and its central location made it easy to spot.

Food & Pricing
I ordered:
- Nasi Kerabu with added sambal kerang and ikan bayar
- A glass of iced tea

The portion size was reasonable, and the flavors were satisfying — true to Kelantanese culinary style with aromatic herbs, spicy sambal, and well-cooked accompaniments. The meal cost RM20, which I found acceptable given the location, add-ons, and overall quality.

Overall Impression
This stall offers a solid option for Kelantanese cuisine within the HKL food court. The food was tasty, the service was efficient despite the lunch rush, and the menu looked promising for future visits. I’d certainly consider returning to explore other traditional dishes they offer.

✔️ Convenient for hospital visitors or staff
✔️ Flavorful Kelantanese food at a fair price
✔️ Fast service even during peak hour

place_info.title: De Blue Door Hatyai
place_info.address: 52 Sangchan Rd, Tambon Hat Yai, Hatyai, Songkhla 90110, Thailand

reviews.snippet:
De Blue Door Hatyai – A Perfect Stay in the Heart of the City

If you are looking for a comfortable, clean, and well-located accommodation in Hat Yai, De Blue Door Hatyai should be at the top of your list. This charming guesthouse offers everything a traveler needs: strategic location, excellent hygiene, modern convenience, and affordable rates — all wrapped in a stylish, boutique atmosphere.

Prime Location

Located right in the heart of Hat Yai, De Blue Door is just a short walk from key attractions like Lee Gardens Plaza, popular **halal restaurants, night markets, and shopping areas. For those relying on public transportation or arriving by bus, the location is incredibly practical. Whether you're here for shopping, sightseeing, or food hunting, everything is within reach.

Spotlessly Clean & Well-Maintained

One of the standout features of De Blue Door is its exceptional cleanliness. The rooms and common areas are meticulously maintained, with a fresh, minimalist design that feels welcoming and serene. The bathrooms are spotless, and the beds are clean and comfortable — a big plus after a long day exploring the city.

Convenience & Comfort

Guests will appreciate the thoughtful amenities provided: free Wi-Fi, air-conditioning, modern bathroom fittings, and convenient self check-in and check-out.

The quiet environment also makes it ideal for restful sleep — despite being centrally located, the property offers a peaceful retreat from the bustle of the city.

Affordable & Great Value

For the level of cleanliness, comfort, and location, the price at De Blue Door is surprisingly reasonable. Whether you're travelling solo, as a couple, or with family, the value for money is outstanding. It strikes the perfect balance between budget accommodation and boutique hotel charm.

Verdict

De Blue Door Hatyai is a gem for travelers who appreciate cleanliness, comfort, convenience, and affordability. Its **central location, modern facilities, and reasonable pricing make it one of the best stays in Hat Yai. Highly recommended for anyone looking for quality lodging without breaking the budget.

✔️ Perfect for couples, solo travelers, and small families
✔️ Clean, central, quiet, and cost-effective
✔️ Excellent for both short stays and longer visits

place_info.title: Bang Lee Kung Tom​ Halal
place_info.address: Sangchan Rd, Hat Yai, Hat Yai District, Songkhla 90110, Thailand

reviews.snippet:
Bang Lee Kung Tom Halal – A Hidden Gem for Authentic Halal Thai Cuisine

Just a 5-minute walk from my homestay, I discovered Bang Lee Kung Tom Halal through Google Maps reviews — and it turned out to be a hidden culinary gem. Tucked along the roadside, this unassuming eatery offers a genuinely local Thai food experience that is halal, flavorful, and memorably spicy.

Local Flavors with Heart

I tried several dishes during my visit:
- Lidah goreng (fried beef tongue) – nicely done, tender and flavorful.
- Kangkung belacan – a Malaysian favorite, cooked well and packed with umami.
- Ikan goreng berempah (spiced fried fish) – crispy, aromatic, and satisfying.
- Kheng som ikan belanak – a traditional sour and spicy fish soup. Personally, I found the flavor a bit too strong and sharp, possibly due to regional differences in taste compared to Malaysian-style cooking.

Next time, I would like to try their signature sour prawn soup made with asam jawa (tamarind). It’s  must-try— bold, tangy, spicy, and deeply satisfying. As mentioned by other patrons, u\you won’t find this flavor profile in typical tourist Thai eateries. Just be warned: the spice level is intense, so be sure to request for "less spicy" if you're not used to Thai-level heat.

Ambience & Experience

The shop is located right beside the main road, which makes it easy to find but slightly tricky for parking. If you're taking a tuk-tuk, it's more convenient. The setting is simple and local-style, but the experience is genuine and charming.

What adds warmth to the experience is the family-run feel. The owner’s husband can speak Malay, and there is now a menu in Bahasa Melayu, which makes it far more accessible to Malaysian visitors. Interestingly, when I first came years ago, they couldn’t take our order due to the language barrier — a humorous memory that shows how much the place has grown.

There’s also a small surau/musalla available, which is a welcome facility for Muslim diners.

Pricing & Value

Prices are slightly on the higher side for a local eatery, especially compared to typical Thai street food. However, portions are reasonable, and considering the quality and authenticity, the food remains worth the value. A full meal with shrimp, vegetables, and fish can come up to around THB 500+, depending on your order.

Verdict

Bang Lee Kung Tom Halal is a true local treasure, perfect for those who appreciate bold flavors and authentic Thai halal food. While the spiciness can be intense and parking a little challenging, the taste, atmosphere, and friendly service make it a spot worth revisiting.

✔️ Great for food lovers seeking an off-the-beaten-path halal experience
✔️ Next time, Must-try: Prawn sour soup with tamarind, stir-fried beef, spicy vegetable dishes
❌ Not suitable for those sensitive to spicy food unless requested milder

details.parking_options: Free street parking, Paid street parking

place_info.title: Hamid Restaurant Hatyai
place_info.address: 73-75 Prachathipat Road, Tambon Hat Yai, Hat Yai District, Songkhla 90110, Thailand

reviews.snippet:
Hamid Restaurant Hatyai – A Must-Visit Halal Dining Spot in the Heart of Hat Yai

Strategically located just across the road from Lee Gardens Plaza Hotel, Hamid Restaurant Hatyai stands as one of the most well-known halal restaurants in the city, offering a delightful mix of Thai and Malaysian-style dishes. Whether you’re arriving by bus or staying at nearby hotels like Lee Garden or Centara, this restaurant is an ideal stop for a satisfying and familiar halal meal.

Location & Atmosphere

The restaurant is easy to locate, situated right at the center of Hat Yai along Prachathipat Road, where many public transport routes converge. It's spacious, clean, and well-lit, making it comfortable for both casual meals and group dining with family or friends. Although the parking space is limited, the accessibility and central location make up for it.

Food & Flavours

Hamid Restaurant is especially popular among Malaysian tourists — many of whom feel right at home here, as ordering in Bahasa Melayu is common and well understood by the staff. The menu is extensive, offering a wide range of halal Thai and local dishes: from tom yam, ikan tiga rasa, and petai sambal prawns, to daging bakar and various fried rice options.

During my visit, I ordered daging bakar, sotong in sauce, and tom yam soup. The food was rich in flavour, served in reasonable portions, and well-prepared. The roasted beef (daging bakar) was slightly on the chewy side but paired well with the accompanying sauce. The squid and tom yam were especially impressive — spicy, aromatic, and satisfying.

Also worth noting is the white tom yam soup, praised by many for its authentic taste. Dishes like nasi goreng kampung, though slightly different in preparation (with dark soy sauce), still deliver on flavor.

Service & Pricing

Service is generally fast and efficient, even during busy periods. The staff are friendly and welcoming, although during peak hours, drinks may arrive slower than expected. The overall dining experience is still positive, and staff are responsive if politely reminded.

In terms of pricing, I found that it slightly above average by local standards, but it is comparable to Malaysian prices and considered acceptable given the location, cleanliness, and halal certification. For Muslim travelers, that peace of mind adds value.

Verdict

Hamid Restaurant Hatyai is a top pick for those seeking halal food in a central and convenient location. With a clean environment, fast service, and a broad selection of flavorful dishes, it consistently delivers on quality. The only minor drawback is the pricing, which may feel a bit high for budget travelers — but overall, it remains fair and worthwhile for the experience offered.

✔️ Great for families, groups, and Muslim travelers
✔️ Must-try: white tom yam, daging bakar, seafood sambal
❌ Limited parking and potentially noisy during peak hours

details.noise_level: Loud, but you can still talk
details.parking_options: Paid parking lot, Paid street parking

place_info.title: Ushiya Halal (อุชิยะ ฮาลาล)
place_info.address: 482 14 ม.2, Mueang Songkhla District, Songkhla 90100, Thailand

reviews.snippet:
Ushiya Halal (อุชิยะ ฮาลาล), Hatyai – A Must-Visit for Halal Japanese Buffet Lovers

If you're craving an authentic su-kiya shabu-shabu buffet experience in southern Thailand and require halal options, look no further than Ushiya Halal (อุชิยะ ฮาลาล) in Hatyai. This delightful restaurant offers one of the best halal Japanese buffet experiences in the region — ideal for Muslim travelers, Malaysian tourists, and locals alike. The Japanese term "ushi-ya" (牛屋) translates to "cattle shop" or "beef shop" in English. It refers to a place where beef or cattle products are sold, such as a butcher shop specializing in beef.

Authentic Flavours, Generous Choices

The highlight of this establishment is undoubtedly its signature sukiya soup base, which impressively mirrors the flavour profile of Su-kiya outlets in Kuala Lumpur. The restaurant also offers two other soup bases: tomyam for those who love a spicy punch, and kimchi for fans of Korean fusion flavours.

There are three pricing tiers, tailored to suit different preferences and budgets:

1. Basic Buffet – Includes a wide range of meat selections.
2. Mid-Tier Buffet – Adds premium seafood like salmon, shrimp, and prawns to the selection.
3. Premium Wagyu Package – Features halal-certified Wagyu beef, though during our visit, this premium option was temporarily unavailable due to supply delays.

Despite the wagyu being unavailable during our visit, the variety and freshness of the available offerings were still outstanding.

Thoughtful Layout & Rich Variety

The buffet layout is intelligently organized into two main zones:
- One area features all the steamboat ingredients, sauces, and dipping condiments (which are handmade — the soy sauce broth in particular is a must-try, based on a Japanese recipe learned directly by the owner).
- The second section includes fried items, rice dishes, sushi, drinks, and desserts. Don’t miss the salmon sashimi, marinated soy crab, and prawns, available for order.

The restaurant also provides a broad array of beverages including iced tea (notably strong and flavourful), green tea, and soft drinks. While some drinks are on the sweeter side, they complement the meal well.

Atmosphere & Hospitality

The ambiance reflects a clean and cozy Japanese-inspired décor, enhanced by air-conditioning and a comfortable seating area. Muslim diners will appreciate the provision of a prayer room (surau), further reinforcing the restaurant’s commitment to halal hospitality.

Staff are friendly, helpful, and some are able to speak Bahasa Melayu, which is a great comfort for non-Thai-speaking customers. Service can vary slightly during peak or rainy hours, but overall, the team remains courteous and accommodating.

Dining Policy & Price

Dining time is capped at 1 hour 45 minutes, which is more than sufficient for a fulfilling meal. Guests are advised to finish what they take, as food wastage incurs an additional charge, in line with the restaurant’s sustainable and respectful dining practices.

The prices are very reasonable given the quality, variety, and halal assurance. For just THB289–399, diners can enjoy an abundant, satisfying buffet. Even if sushi quality is moderate, the meats, seafood, and cooked dishes more than make up for it.

Verdict

Ushiya Halal is truly a gem in Hatyai — the only known halal Japanese-style shabu buffet in the region. It stands out not only for its authentic taste and ingredient quality but also for its warm atmosphere and Muslim-friendly amenities. Whether you're a Malaysian tourist craving a halal Su-kiya fix or a local looking for a quality shabu experience, this place is highly recommended.

Rating: 4.9 / 5
✔️ Great for groups, families, and halal foodies.
✔️ Must-try: sukiya broth, salmon sashimi, soy-marinated crab.
✔️ Return-worthy for variety, value, and ambiance.

place_info.title: Makam Diraja Pekan
place_info.address: Jalan Sultan Ahmad, Kampung Pancur, 26600 Pekan, Pahang, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
The Pekan Royal Mausoleum (Makam Diraja Pekan) in Pahang stands as a testament to the rich history and enduring legacy of the Pahang Sultanate. Situated in Kampung Marhum, Kuala Pahang, this sacred site serves as the final resting place for numerous rulers and royal family members, offering visitors a profound connection to Malaysia's royal heritage.

Historical Significance

Established in the 18th century, the mausoleum initially served as the burial ground for the Bendahara dynasty, the predecessors of the modern Pahang sultans. Notably, Sultan Abdul Jalil Riayat Shah IV of Johor, who passed away in 1721, was among the first to be interred here. Subsequent rulers, including Bendahara Tun Abdul Majid (d. 1802), Bendahara Tun Muhammad (d. 1803), Bendahara Tun Koris (d. 1806), and Bendahara Tun Ali (d. 1857), were also laid to rest at this site. The mausoleum continued to serve as the royal burial ground for modern Pahang sultans until 1932, with Sultan Abdullah Al-Mu'tassim Billah Shah being the last sultan interred here .

Architectural Features

The mausoleum complex reflects traditional Malay-Islamic architectural elements, characterized by its serene ambiance and intricate designs. The tombstones, adorned with Islamic motifs, are arranged in a manner that denotes the hierarchical status of the interred. The site is meticulously maintained, ensuring that visitors can pay their respects in a tranquil environment.

Visiting the Mausoleum

Located adjacent to the Sultan Ahmad Shah Mosque, the Pekan Royal Mausoleum is accessible to the public. Visitors are encouraged to dress modestly and observe respectful behavior while on the premises. The mausoleum offers a unique opportunity to delve into the history of the Pahang Sultanate and reflect upon the contributions of its rulers to the state's development.

Directions

For those planning a visit, the mausoleum is situated in Kampung Marhum, Kuala Pahang, Pekan. It is easily accessible by road, and signage in the area provides clear directions to the site.

Conclusion

The Pekan Royal Mausoleum is more than just a burial site; it is a symbol of Pahang's rich royal history and cultural heritage. A visit to this solemn place offers a deeper understanding of the state's past and the legacies of its rulers.

place_info.title: Sultan Abdullah Mosque Museum
place_info.address: Kampung Pancur, 26600 Pekan, Pahang, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
A Tranquil Journey Through History and Faith
Sultan Abdullah Mosque Museum – Pekan, Pahang

Tucked away in the royal town of Pekan, the Sultan Abdullah Mosque Museum is an exceptional heritage site that gracefully bridges history, faith, and culture. Once the main royal mosque of the state, this majestic structure has been thoughtfully transformed into a museum dedicated to the spread of Islam in Pahang. Today, it stands as both a cultural treasure and a spiritual sanctuary.

A Glimpse into Pahang’s Islamic Heritage

Officially inaugurated as a museum in October 2016, the building originally served as Masjid Sultan Abdullah, built around the 1930s. It was once the primary place of worship for the local Muslim community, including members of the Pahang royal family. Rather than being retired or demolished, the mosque has been respectfully preserved and repurposed to celebrate Islamic heritage in the region. This transition from mosque to museum was carried out with great sensitivity, retaining much of the original charm and religious essence.

Architecture That Inspires

One of the most striking aspects of the museum is its architecture. With its pure white façade, domes, and minarets, it bears a remarkable resemblance to the famed Taj Mahal—evoking elegance, purity, and timeless beauty. The intricate design details, both on the exterior and interior, reflect classical Islamic art infused with local Malay elements. Walking through its halls, one cannot help but appreciate the craftsmanship that went into its construction, as well as the thoughtful renovations that have preserved its glory.

A Quiet, Spiritual Space Amidst History

What makes this museum stand out from others is the sense of peace that envelopes it. Entry is free, and the venue remains relatively uncrowded—even on weekends. For visitors who appreciate quiet reflection, this serene setting offers the perfect escape from tourist crowds. It is particularly ideal for those seeking a more contemplative experience, where history, architecture, and spirituality meet.

Despite its transformation into a museum, a dedicated prayer space has been preserved within the premises. Visitors are welcome to perform solat (prayers) here, making it one of the rare museums where one can still engage in spiritual acts within a historical structure. This feature gives the museum a unique dual purpose: as a place of learning and a space for devotion.

Educational and Enlightening

The exhibitions within the museum are thoughtfully curated. They cover the history of Islam in Pahang, its royal connections, and its social development. Through well-organized displays, visitors can gain a deeper understanding of how Islam has shaped local culture and governance over the decades. Islamic manuscripts, calligraphy, artifacts, and interpretive panels enrich the experience, making it both informative and inspiring.

Final Thoughts

In an age where many heritage sites are commercialized or overlooked, the Sultan Abdullah Mosque Museum stands as a beacon of respectful preservation and meaningful transformation. It offers visitors not just a journey through the history of Islam in Pahang, but also a rare opportunity to experience the spiritual soul of a mosque that continues to serve in a new way.

For those visiting Pekan, this museum is a must-see destination. Whether you're a history enthusiast, an admirer of Islamic architecture, or a spiritual traveler seeking calm, this serene and noble museum is sure to leave a lasting impression.

place_info.title: Masjid Sultan Ahmad Shah, Pekan
place_info.address: Lorong Tengku Talha, Kampung Pancur, 26600 Pekan, Pahang, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
During my visit to Pekan, one place that truly stood out was Masjid Sultan Ahmad Shah – the main mosque of this royal town. Situated in the heart of Pekan, it is more than just a place of worship; it is a prominent landmark that reflects the town’s religious and cultural heritage.

Architecture and Atmosphere

What immediately caught my eye was the mosque’s breathtaking architecture. The main golden dome, surrounded by smaller domes, reflects a Mughal-inspired design, giving it a majestic appearance that’s hard to miss. The tall minarets and beautifully crafted Islamic calligraphy inside create a truly spiritual ambiance.

Inside, the prayer hall is spacious, air-conditioned, and meticulously maintained. Whether you're there for Jum'ah (Friday prayers), Eid, or a regular daily prayer, the environment is always welcoming, calm, and conducive to focus and reflection.

Accessibility and Surroundings

Located centrally, the mosque is easily accessible. There’s ample parking, and the surrounding area is clean and well-kept. It's clear that the community takes great pride in preserving the mosque’s cleanliness and serenity. For me, walking into the mosque felt like entering a peaceful haven away from the hustle of daily life.

Community and Spiritual Engagement

One of the aspects I admired most was how active the mosque is beyond daily prayers. Regular religious classes, sermons, and community events are held here, making it a vibrant hub for learning and social connection. The mosque plays a key role in uniting the local Muslim community and nurturing spiritual growth.

Personal Reflection

My experience at Masjid Sultan Ahmad Shah left a deep impression on me. It’s not just a place to pray, but a place to reconnect with faith, appreciate the beauty of Islamic art and architecture, and feel the warmth of a close-knit community. The atmosphere was calm and respectful, with a real sense of reverence in every corner.

Final Thoughts

If you're ever in Pekan, I highly recommend visiting this mosque, whether you're a Muslim or someone interested in Islamic culture. It’s a shining example of how religious architecture, community service, and spiritual tradition can come together in a beautiful and meaningful way.

Masjid Sultan Ahmad Shah truly stands as a symbol of Islamic pride and cultural legacy in Pahang.

place_info.title: Lake Chini Resort
place_info.address: 26650 Chini, Pahang, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
On a recent road trip with my college friends from Pekan to Kuala Lumpur, we made a spontaneous detour to Lake Chini, hoping to reconnect with nature and perhaps experience the once-famous Lake Chini Resort. We had heard about its charm — nestled beside one of Malaysia’s most iconic freshwater lakes, rich with folklore, biodiversity, and serenity. But what awaited us was a scene of quiet abandonment.

Gaining Entry – A Glimpse Behind Closed Gates

When we arrived, it was immediately clear that the resort was no longer operational. The entrance was blocked, and signs of closure were everywhere. A security guard was stationed at the front, and after we explained that we were just passing through and meant no harm, he reluctantly allowed us inside for a short visit. His tone was apologetic, almost as if he wished he could offer us more.

Echoes of a Forgotten Destination

Walking through the resort grounds felt like stepping into the past. The chalets were in ruins, overrun by thick vegetation and moss. The main building stood eerily quiet, its once-proud structures now weathered and broken. The signage was faded, paths were overgrown, and broken furniture lay scattered under collapsing roofs.

It was heartbreaking to witness the state of total neglect. This was clearly not just a temporary closure; it looked as though the resort had been left untouched for years. It felt like nature was slowly reclaiming what once welcomed guests from near and far.

Stories from the Past – Meeting Former Staff

We were fortunate enough to strike up a conversation with a few former staff members who happened to be in the area. They spoke to us with warmth and honesty, reminiscing about the resort’s heyday in the late 80s and 90s. They told us it had officially closed in late 2019, due to dwindling visitor numbers and the growing environmental problems around the lake.

They shared their personal stories — of hosting school groups, foreign tourists, and eco-adventurers who once came to see the floating lotus flowers and visit the nearby Orang Asli villages. There was a deep sadness in their voices, as if they were mourning a lost part of themselves.

The Lake Itself – A Bigger Problem

As we looked out over Tasik Chini, we could see signs of environmental decline. The water level was low, and the surroundings showed the impact of pollution and nearby development. What used to be a UNESCO-recognized biosphere reserve is now struggling under the weight of logging, mining, and poor management.

It was disheartening to see such natural and cultural beauty being lost, both in the lake and in the resort that once celebrated it.

A Personal Reflection and Hope

While I left with a heavy heart, I also left with a strong sense of hope. Lake Chini Resort, despite its current condition, still holds potential. The foundations are there, the stories still live in the memories of those who worked there, and the location — surrounded by water, forests, and culture — remains unique and powerful.

I truly hope that one day, with the right commitment from authorities and communities, this resort can be revived and restored to its former glory. With proper environmental rehabilitation and sustainable tourism planning, Lake Chini could once again become a jewel of Pahang, offering education, heritage, and eco-tourism opportunities for future generations.

For now, I wouldn't recommend visiting unless you're fully aware that the resort is closed and in poor condition. But perhaps, someday soon, we can return to find this place reborn — not as a forgotten destination, but as a symbol of resilience and renewal.

place_info.title: Masjid Bandar Satelit Muadzam Shah (Masjid Tengku Ampuan Afzan)
place_info.address: Presint Perniagaan Bandar Satelit, 26700 Muadzam Shah, Pahang, Malaysia

reviews.snippet:
Masjid Tengku Ampuan Afzan, located in Bandar Satelit Muadzam Shah, Pahang, stands out as an exemplary mosque with modern management and a strong sense of community service. Since its official operation began on 1st June 2016, the mosque has played a vital role as a centre for worship, education, and social welfare — not only for the local community but also for travellers passing through the area.

Excellent Facilities for Travellers

Strategically situated along the Kuantan–Segamat highway, the mosque serves as a popular rest stop for travellers looking to perform their prayers or simply take a break. The mosque is equipped with spacious and comfortable prayer halls, clean ablution (wudu’) areas, and ample parking, making it a top choice for those on long-distance journeys.

The mosque’s toilet facilities have been awarded a 5-star cleanliness rating by the Rompin District Council consistently from 2021 through 2024 — a clear indicator of its commitment to hygiene and hospitality.

Awards & Recognition

Masjid Tengku Ampuan Afzan has received several awards and recognitions for its governance and services, including:

3-Star Award in the Pahang State Premier Mosque Programme (PMGP) 2019
Best Governance Award among Pahang Mosques (PMGP) 2019
Strategic Partner Recognition – Muadzam Shah, 2021
-Selected as a pilot project location for the “One-Stop Center” initiative by the Pahang Islamic Religious Department (JAIP)

The mosque has also developed a Strategic Planning Framework (MTAABS 2023–2027) aimed at positioning itself not only as a place of worship but as a hub for knowledge, welfare, education, economics, volunteerism, and even traveller-friendly facilities (rest & refresh).

Commitment to Community Welfare

The mosque is also active in social welfare and economic empowerment, launching initiatives such as:

- MTAABS Prihatin Programme – featuring 13 community support projects
- Collaborations with nearly 40 local, state, and national-level organisations
- “Pulut & Co.” economic sustainability project
- In-house healthcare and employment benefit schemes for mosque workers

These efforts clearly demonstrate the mosque's dedication to serving the broader community in a holistic and inclusive manner.

Easily accessible and close to other local amenities, the mosque is an ideal spiritual and physical rest stop for anyone travelling through the region.

Final Verdict

In conclusion, Masjid Tengku Ampuan Afzan is more than just a place of prayer — it is a model institution that integrates spiritual service with social responsibility, hospitality, and modern management. With excellent facilities for travellers, well-maintained cleanliness, forward-looking governance, and a strong focus on community outreach, this mosque is a shining example for others across the country.
